name: Around the World in Eighty Days

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PASSEPARTOUT ACCEPT EACH OTHER, THE ONE AS MASTER, THE OTHER AS MAN
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PASSEPARTOUT ACCEPT EACH OTHER THE ONE AS MASTER THE OTHER AS MAN

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814.  He was one of the most noticeable members of the Reform Club, though he seemed always to avoid attracting attention; an enigmatical personage, about whom little was known, except that he was a polished man of the world.  People said that he resembled Byron--at least that his head was Byronic; but he was a bearded, tranquil Byron, who might live on a thousand years without growing old.
children.prevalue: Mr Phileas Fogg lived in 1872 at No 7 Saville Row Burlington Gardens the house in which Sheridan died in 1814 He was one of the most noticeable members of the Reform Club though he seemed always to avoid attracting attention an enigmatical personage about whom little was known except that he was a polished man of the world People said that he resembled Byron at least that his head was Byronic but he was a bearded tranquil Byron who might live on a thousand years without growing old

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Certainly an Englishman, it was more doubtful whether Phileas Fogg was a Londoner.  He was never seen on 'Change, nor at the Bank, nor in the counting-rooms of the City; no ships ever came into London docks of which he was the owner; he had no public employment; he had never been entered at any of the Inns of Court, either at the Temple, or Lincoln's Inn, or Gray's Inn; nor had his voice ever resounded in the Court of Chancery, or in the Exchequer, or the Queen's Bench, or the Ecclesiastical Courts.  He certainly was not a manufacturer; nor was he a merchant or a gentleman farmer.  His name was strange to the scientific and learned societies, and he never was known to take part in the sage deliberations of the Royal Institution or the London Institution, the Artisan's Association, or the Institution of Arts and Sciences.  He belonged, in fact, to none of the numerous societies which swarm in the English capital, from the Harmonic to that of the Entomologists, founded mainly for the purpose of abolishing pernicious insects.
children.prevalue: Certainly an Englishman it was more doubtful whether Phileas Fogg was a Londoner He was never seen on Change nor at the Bank nor in the counting rooms of the City no ships ever came into London docks of which he was the owner he had no public employment he had never been entered at any of the Inns of Court either at the Temple or Lincoln s Inn or Gray s Inn nor had his voice ever resounded in the Court of Chancery or in the Exchequer or the Queen s Bench or the Ecclesiastical Courts He certainly was not a manufacturer nor was he a merchant or a gentleman farmer His name was strange to the scientific and learned societies and he never was known to take part in the sage deliberations of the Royal Institution or the London Institution the Artisan s Association or the Institution of Arts and Sciences He belonged in fact to none of the numerous societies which swarm in the English capital from the Harmonic to that of the Entomologists founded mainly for the purpose of abolishing pernicious insects

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, and that was all.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform and that was all

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough.
children.prevalue: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He was recommended by the Barings, with whom he had an open credit. His cheques were regularly paid at sight from his account current, which was always flush.
children.prevalue: He was recommended by the Barings with whom he had an open credit His cheques were regularly paid at sight from his account current which was always flush

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Was Phileas Fogg rich?  Undoubtedly.  But those who knew him best could not imagine how he had made his fortune, and Mr. Fogg was the last person to whom to apply for the information.  He was not lavish, nor, on the contrary, avaricious; for, whenever he knew that money was needed for a noble, useful, or benevolent purpose, he supplied it quietly and sometimes anonymously.  He was, in short, the least communicative of men.  He talked very little, and seemed all the more mysterious for his taciturn manner.  His daily habits were quite open to observation; but whatever he did was so exactly the same thing that he had always done before, that the wits of the curious were fairly puzzled.
children.prevalue: Was Phileas Fogg rich Undoubtedly But those who knew him best could not imagine how he had made his fortune and Mr Fogg was the last person to whom to apply for the information He was not lavish nor on the contrary avaricious for whenever he knew that money was needed for a noble useful or benevolent purpose he supplied it quietly and sometimes anonymously He was in short the least communicative of men He talked very little and seemed all the more mysterious for his taciturn manner His daily habits were quite open to observation but whatever he did was so exactly the same thing that he had always done before that the wits of the curious were fairly puzzled

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Had he travelled?  It was likely, for no one seemed to know the world more familiarly; there was no spot so secluded that he did not appear to have an intimate acquaintance with it.  He often corrected, with a few clear words, the thousand conjectures advanced by members of the club as to lost and unheard-of travellers, pointing out the true probabilities, and seeming as if gifted with a sort of second sight, so often did events justify his predictions.  He must have travelled everywhere, at least in the spirit.
children.prevalue: Had he travelled It was likely for no one seemed to know the world more familiarly there was no spot so secluded that he did not appear to have an intimate acquaintance with it He often corrected with a few clear words the thousand conjectures advanced by members of the club as to lost and unheard of travellers pointing out the true probabilities and seeming as if gifted with a sort of second sight so often did events justify his predictions He must have travelled everywhere at least in the spirit

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It was at least certain that Phileas Fogg had not absented himself from London for many years.  Those who were honoured by a better acquaintance with him than the rest, declared that nobody could pretend to have ever seen him anywhere else.  His sole pastimes were reading the papers and playing whist.  He often won at this game, which, as a silent one, harmonised with his nature; but his winnings never went into his purse, being reserved as a fund for his charities.  Mr. Fogg played, not to win, but for the sake of playing.  The game was in his eyes a contest, a struggle with a difficulty, yet a motionless, unwearying struggle, congenial to his tastes.
children.prevalue: It was at least certain that Phileas Fogg had not absented himself from London for many years Those who were honoured by a better acquaintance with him than the rest declared that nobody could pretend to have ever seen him anywhere else His sole pastimes were reading the papers and playing whist He often won at this game which as a silent one harmonised with his nature but his winnings never went into his purse being reserved as a fund for his charities Mr Fogg played not to win but for the sake of playing The game was in his eyes a contest a struggle with a difficulty yet a motionless unwearying struggle congenial to his tastes

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual.  He lived alone in his house in Saville Row, whither none penetrated.  A single domestic sufficed to serve him.  He breakfasted and dined at the club, at hours mathematically fixed, in the same room, at the same table, never taking his meals with other members, much less bringing a guest with him; and went home at exactly midnight, only to retire at once to bed.  He never used the cosy chambers which the Reform provides for its favoured members.  He passed ten hours out of the twenty-four in Saville Row, either in sleeping or making his toilet.  When he chose to take a walk it was with a regular step in the entrance hall with its mosaic flooring, or in the circular gallery with its dome supported by twenty red porphyry Ionic columns, and illumined by blue painted windows. When he breakfasted or dined all the resources of the club--its kitchens and pantries, its buttery and dairy--aided to crowd his table with their most succulent stores; he was served by the gravest waiters, in dress coats, and shoes with swan-skin soles, who proffered the viands in special porcelain, and on the finest linen; club decanters, of a lost mould, contained his sherry, his port, and his cinnamon-spiced claret; while his beverages were refreshingly cooled with ice, brought at great cost from the American lakes.

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: If to live in this style is to be eccentric, it must be confessed that there is something good in eccentricity.
children.prevalue: If to live in this style is to be eccentric it must be confessed that there is something good in eccentricity

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The mansion in Saville Row, though not sumptuous, was exceedingly comfortable.  The habits of its occupant were such as to demand but little from the sole domestic, but Phileas Fogg required him to be almost superhumanly prompt and regular.  On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster, because that luckless youth had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six; and he was awaiting his successor, who was due at the house between eleven and half-past.
children.prevalue: The mansion in Saville Row though not sumptuous was exceedingly comfortable The habits of its occupant were such as to demand but little from the sole domestic but Phileas Fogg required him to be almost superhumanly prompt and regular On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster because that luckless youth had brought him shaving water at eighty four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty six and he was awaiting his successor who was due at the house between eleven and half past

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Phileas Fogg was seated squarely in his armchair, his feet close together like those of a grenadier on parade, his hands resting on his knees, his body straight, his head erect; he was steadily watching a complicated clock which indicated the hours, the minutes, the seconds, the days, the months, and the years.  At exactly half-past eleven Mr. Fogg would, according to his daily habit, quit Saville Row, and repair to the Reform.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg was seated squarely in his armchair his feet close together like those of a grenadier on parade his hands resting on his knees his body straight his head erect he was steadily watching a complicated clock which indicated the hours the minutes the seconds the days the months and the years At exactly half past eleven Mr Fogg would according to his daily habit quit Saville Row and repair to the Reform

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.
children.prevalue: A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated and James Forster the dismissed servant appeared

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The new servant, said he.
children.prevalue: The new servant said he

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: A young man of thirty advanced and bowed.
children.prevalue: A young man of thirty advanced and bowed

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You are a Frenchman, I believe, asked Phileas Fogg, and your name is John?
children.prevalue: You are a Frenchman I believe asked Phileas Fogg and your name is John

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Jean, if monsieur pleases, replied the newcomer, Jean Passepartout, a surname which has clung to me because I have a natural aptness for going out of one business into another.  I believe I'm honest, monsieur, but, to be outspoken, I've had several trades.  I've been an itinerant singer, a circus-rider, when I used to vault like Leotard, and dance on a rope like Blondin.  Then I got to be a professor of gymnastics, so as to make better use of my talents; and then I was a sergeant fireman at Paris, and assisted at many a big fire.  But I quitted France five years ago, and, wishing to taste the sweets of domestic life, took service as a valet here in England.  Finding myself out of place, and hearing that Monsieur Phileas Fogg was the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to monsieur in the hope of living with him a tranquil life, and forgetting even the name of Passepartout.

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Passepartout suits me, responded Mr. Fogg.  You are well recommended to me; I hear a good report of you.  You know my conditions?
children.prevalue: Passepartout suits me responded Mr Fogg You are well recommended to me I hear a good report of you You know my conditions

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Good!  What time is it?
children.prevalue: Good What time is it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Twenty-two minutes after eleven, returned Passepartout, drawing an enormous silver watch from the depths of his pocket.
children.prevalue: Twenty two minutes after eleven returned Passepartout drawing an enormous silver watch from the depths of his pocket

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You are too slow, said Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: You are too slow said Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Pardon me, monsieur, it is impossible--
children.prevalue: Pardon me monsieur it is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: You are four minutes too slow.  No matter; it's enough to mention the error.  Now from this moment, twenty-nine minutes after eleven, a.m., this Wednesday, 2nd October, you are in my service.
children.prevalue: You are four minutes too slow No matter it s enough to mention the error Now from this moment twenty nine minutes after eleven a m this Wednesday 2nd October you are in my service

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Phileas Fogg got up, took his hat in his left hand, put it on his head with an automatic motion, and went off without a word.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg got up took his hat in his left hand put it on his head with an automatic motion and went off without a word

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Passepartout heard the street door shut once; it was his new master going out.  He heard it shut again; it was his predecessor, James Forster, departing in his turn.  Passepartout remained alone in the house in Saville Row.
children.prevalue: Passepartout heard the street door shut once it was his new master going out He heard it shut again it was his predecessor James Forster departing in his turn Passepartout remained alone in the house in Saville Row

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT IS CONVINCED THAT HE HAS AT LAST FOUND HIS IDEAL
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT IS CONVINCED THAT HE HAS AT LAST FOUND HIS IDEAL

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Faith, muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, I've seen people at Madame Tussaud's as lively as my new master!
children.prevalue: Faith muttered Passepartout somewhat flurried I ve seen people at Madame Tussaud s as lively as my new master

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Madame Tussaud's people, let it be said, are of wax, and are much visited in London; speech is all that is wanting to make them human.
children.prevalue: Madame Tussaud s people let it be said are of wax and are much visited in London speech is all that is wanting to make them human

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: During his brief interview with Mr. Fogg, Passepartout had been carefully observing him.  He appeared to be a man about forty years of age, with fine, handsome features, and a tall, well-shaped figure; his hair and whiskers were light, his forehead compact and unwrinkled, his face rather pale, his teeth magnificent.  His countenance possessed in the highest degree what physiognomists call repose in action, a quality of those who act rather than talk.  Calm and phlegmatic, with a clear eye, Mr. Fogg seemed a perfect type of that English composure which Angelica Kauffmann has so skilfully represented on canvas.  Seen in the various phases of his daily life, he gave the idea of being perfectly well-balanced, as exactly regulated as a Leroy chronometer. Phileas Fogg was, indeed, exactitude personified, and this was betrayed even in the expression of his very hands and feet; for in men, as well as in animals, the limbs themselves are expressive of the passions.
children.prevalue: During his brief interview with Mr Fogg Passepartout had been carefully observing him He appeared to be a man about forty years of age with fine handsome features and a tall well shaped figure his hair and whiskers were light his forehead compact and unwrinkled his face rather pale his teeth magnificent His countenance possessed in the highest degree what physiognomists call repose in action a quality of those who act rather than talk Calm and phlegmatic with a clear eye Mr Fogg seemed a perfect type of that English composure which Angelica Kauffmann has so skilfully represented on canvas Seen in the various phases of his daily life he gave the idea of being perfectly well balanced as exactly regulated as a Leroy chronometer Phileas Fogg was indeed exactitude personified and this was betrayed even in the expression of his very hands and feet for in men as well as in animals the limbs themselves are expressive of the passions

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He was so exact that he was never in a hurry, was always ready, and was economical alike of his steps and his motions.  He never took one step too many, and always went to his destination by the shortest cut; he made no superfluous gestures, and was never seen to be moved or agitated.  He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.
children.prevalue: He was so exact that he was never in a hurry was always ready and was economical alike of his steps and his motions He never took one step too many and always went to his destination by the shortest cut he made no superfluous gestures and was never seen to be moved or agitated He was the most deliberate person in the world yet always reached his destination at the exact moment

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
children.prevalue: He lived alone and so to speak outside of every social relation and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction and that friction retards he never rubbed against anybody

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: As for Passepartout, he was a true Parisian of Paris.  Since he had abandoned his own country for England, taking service as a valet, he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart.  Passepartout was by no means one of those pert dunces depicted by Moliere with a bold gaze and a nose held high in the air; he was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, soft-mannered and serviceable, with a good round head, such as one likes to see on the shoulders of a friend.  His eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his figure almost portly and well-built, his body muscular, and his physical powers fully developed by the exercises of his younger days. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for, while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva's tresses, Passepartout was familiar with but one of dressing his own: three strokes of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.
children.prevalue: As for Passepartout he was a true Parisian of Paris Since he had abandoned his own country for England taking service as a valet he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart Passepartout was by no means one of those pert dunces depicted by Moliere with a bold gaze and a nose held high in the air he was an honest fellow with a pleasant face lips a trifle protruding soft mannered and serviceable with a good round head such as one likes to see on the shoulders of a friend His eyes were blue his complexion rubicund his figure almost portly and well built his body muscular and his physical powers fully developed by the exercises of his younger days His brown hair was somewhat tumbled for while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva s tresses Passepartout was familiar with but one of dressing his own three strokes of a large tooth comb completed his toilet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It would be rash to predict how Passepartout's lively nature would agree with Mr. Fogg.  It was impossible to tell whether the new servant would turn out as absolutely methodical as his master required; experience alone could solve the question.  Passepartout had been a sort of vagrant in his early years, and now yearned for repose; but so far he had failed to find it, though he had already served in ten English houses.  But he could not take root in any of these; with chagrin, he found his masters invariably whimsical and irregular, constantly running about the country, or on the look-out for adventure. His last master, young Lord Longferry, Member of Parliament, after passing his nights in the Haymarket taverns, was too often brought home in the morning on policemen's shoulders.  Passepartout, desirous of respecting the gentleman whom he served, ventured a mild remonstrance on such conduct; which, being ill-received, he took his leave.  Hearing that Mr. Phileas Fogg was looking for a servant, and that his life was one of unbroken regularity, that he neither travelled nor stayed from home overnight, he felt sure that this would be the place he was after. He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.
children.prevalue: It would be rash to predict how Passepartout s lively nature would agree with Mr Fogg It was impossible to tell whether the new servant would turn out as absolutely methodical as his master required experience alone could solve the question Passepartout had been a sort of vagrant in his early years and now yearned for repose but so far he had failed to find it though he had already served in ten English houses But he could not take root in any of these with chagrin he found his masters invariably whimsical and irregular constantly running about the country or on the look out for adventure His last master young Lord Longferry Member of Parliament after passing his nights in the Haymarket taverns was too often brought home in the morning on policemen s shoulders Passepartout desirous of respecting the gentleman whom he served ventured a mild remonstrance on such conduct which being ill received he took his leave Hearing that Mr Phileas Fogg was looking for a servant and that his life was one of unbroken regularity that he neither travelled nor stayed from home overnight he felt sure that this would be the place he was after He presented himself and was accepted as has been seen

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row.  He began its inspection without delay, scouring it from cellar to garret.  So clean, well-arranged, solemn a mansion pleased him; it seemed to him like a snail's shell, lighted and warmed by gas, which sufficed for both these purposes.  When Passepartout reached the second story he recognised at once the room which he was to inhabit, and he was well satisfied with it.  Electric bells and speaking-tubes afforded communication with the lower stories; while on the mantel stood an electric clock, precisely like that in Mr. Fogg's bedchamber, both beating the same second at the same instant.  That's good, that'll do, said Passepartout to himself.
children.prevalue: At half past eleven then Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row He began its inspection without delay scouring it from cellar to garret So clean well arranged solemn a mansion pleased him it seemed to him like a snail s shell lighted and warmed by gas which sufficed for both these purposes When Passepartout reached the second story he recognised at once the room which he was to inhabit and he was well satisfied with it Electric bells and speaking tubes afforded communication with the lower stories while on the mantel stood an electric clock precisely like that in Mr Fogg s bedchamber both beating the same second at the same instant That s good that ll do said Passepartout to himself

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house. It comprised all that was required of the servant, from eight in the morning, exactly at which hour Phileas Fogg rose, till half-past eleven, when he left the house for the Reform Club--all the details of service, the tea and toast at twenty-three minutes past eight, the shaving-water at thirty-seven minutes past nine, and the toilet at twenty minutes before ten.  Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.
children.prevalue: He suddenly observed hung over the clock a card which upon inspection proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house It comprised all that was required of the servant from eight in the morning exactly at which hour Phileas Fogg rose till half past eleven when he left the house for the Reform Club all the details of service the tea and toast at twenty three minutes past eight the shaving water at thirty seven minutes past nine and the toilet at twenty minutes before ten Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half past eleven a m till midnight the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Mr. Fogg's wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste.  Each pair of trousers, coat, and vest bore a number, indicating the time of year and season at which they were in turn to be laid out for wearing; and the same system was applied to the master's shoes.  In short, the house in Saville Row, which must have been a very temple of disorder and unrest under the illustrious but dissipated Sheridan, was cosiness, comfort, and method idealised.  There was no study, nor were there books, which would have been quite useless to Mr. Fogg; for at the Reform two libraries, one of general literature and the other of law and politics, were at his service.  A moderate-sized safe stood in his bedroom, constructed so as to defy fire as well as burglars; but Passepartout found neither arms nor hunting weapons anywhere; everything betrayed the most tranquil and peaceable habits.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste Each pair of trousers coat and vest bore a number indicating the time of year and season at which they were in turn to be laid out for wearing and the same system was applied to the master s shoes In short the house in Saville Row which must have been a very temple of disorder and unrest under the illustrious but dissipated Sheridan was cosiness comfort and method idealised There was no study nor were there books which would have been quite useless to Mr Fogg for at the Reform two libraries one of general literature and the other of law and politics were at his service A moderate sized safe stood in his bedroom constructed so as to defy fire as well as burglars but Passepartout found neither arms nor hunting weapons anywhere everything betrayed the most tranquil and peaceable habits

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom, he rubbed his hands, a broad smile overspread his features, and he said joyfully, This is just what I wanted!  Ah, we shall get on together, Mr. Fogg and I! What a domestic and regular gentleman!  A real machine; well, I don't mind serving a machine.
children.prevalue: Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom he rubbed his hands a broad smile overspread his features and he said joyfully This is just what I wanted Ah we shall get on together Mr Fogg and I What a domestic and regular gentleman A real machine well I don t mind serving a machine

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH A CONVERSATION TAKES PLACE WHICH SEEMS LIKELY TO COST PHILEAS FOGG DEAR
children.prevalue: IN WHICH A CONVERSATION TAKES PLACE WHICH SEEMS LIKELY TO COST PHILEAS FOGG DEAR

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions.  He repaired at once to the dining-room, the nine windows of which open upon a tasteful garden, where the trees were already gilded with an autumn colouring; and took his place at the habitual table, the cover of which had already been laid for him.  His breakfast consisted of a side-dish, a broiled fish with Reading sauce, a scarlet slice of roast beef garnished with mushrooms, a rhubarb and gooseberry tart, and a morsel of Cheshire cheese, the whole being washed down with several cups of tea, for which the Reform is famous.  He rose at thirteen minutes to one, and directed his steps towards the large hall, a sumptuous apartment adorned with lavishly-framed paintings.  A flunkey handed him an uncut Times, which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed familiarity with this delicate operation.  The perusal of this paper absorbed Phileas Fogg until a quarter before four, whilst the Standard, his next task, occupied him till the dinner hour.  Dinner passed as breakfast had done, and Mr. Fogg re-appeared in the reading-room and sat down to the Pall Mall at twenty minutes before six.  Half an hour later several members of the Reform came in and drew up to the fireplace, where a coal fire was steadily burning.  They were Mr. Fogg's usual partners at whist: Andrew Stuart, an engineer; John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Thomas Flanagan, a brewer; and Gauthier Ralph, one of the Directors of the Bank of England--all rich and highly respectable personages, even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg having shut the door of his house at half past eleven and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy five times and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy six times reached the Reform Club an imposing edifice in Pall Mall which could not have cost less than three millions He repaired at once to the dining room the nine windows of which open upon a tasteful garden where the trees were already gilded with an autumn colouring and took his place at the habitual table the cover of which had already been laid for him His breakfast consisted of a side dish a broiled fish with Reading sauce a scarlet slice of roast beef garnished with mushrooms a rhubarb and gooseberry tart and a morsel of Cheshire cheese the whole being washed down with several cups of tea for which the Reform is famous He rose at thirteen minutes to one and directed his steps towards the large hall a sumptuous apartment adorned with lavishly framed paintings A flunkey handed him an uncut Times which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed familiarity with this delicate operation The perusal of this paper absorbed Phileas Fogg until a quarter before four whilst the Standard his next task occupied him till the dinner hour Dinner passed as breakfast had done and Mr Fogg re appeared in the reading room and sat down to the Pall Mall at twenty minutes before six Half an hour later several members of the Reform came in and drew up to the fireplace where a coal fire was steadily burning They were Mr Fogg s usual partners at whist Andrew Stuart an engineer John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin bankers Thomas Flanagan a brewer and Gauthier Ralph one of the Directors of the Bank of England all rich and highly respectable personages even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well, Ralph, said Thomas Flanagan, what about that robbery?
children.prevalue: Well Ralph said Thomas Flanagan what about that robbery

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Oh, replied Stuart, the Bank will lose the money.
children.prevalue: Oh replied Stuart the Bank will lose the money

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: On the contrary, broke in Ralph, I hope we may put our hands on the robber.  Skilful detectives have been sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent, and he'll be a clever fellow if he slips through their fingers.
children.prevalue: On the contrary broke in Ralph I hope we may put our hands on the robber Skilful detectives have been sent to all the principal ports of America and the Continent and he ll be a clever fellow if he slips through their fingers

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But have you got the robber's description? asked Stuart.
children.prevalue: But have you got the robber s description asked Stuart

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In the first place, he is no robber at all, returned Ralph, positively.
children.prevalue: In the first place he is no robber at all returned Ralph positively

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What! a fellow who makes off with fifty-five thousand pounds, no robber?
children.prevalue: What a fellow who makes off with fifty five thousand pounds no robber

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Perhaps he's a manufacturer, then.
children.prevalue: Perhaps he s a manufacturer then

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The Daily Telegraph says that he is a gentleman.
children.prevalue: The Daily Telegraph says that he is a gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: It was Phileas Fogg, whose head now emerged from behind his newspapers, who made this remark.  He bowed to his friends, and entered into the conversation.  The affair which formed its subject, and which was town talk, had occurred three days before at the Bank of England.  A package of banknotes, to the value of fifty-five thousand pounds, had been taken from the principal cashier's table, that functionary being at the moment engaged in registering the receipt of three shillings and sixpence.  Of course, he could not have his eyes everywhere.  Let it be observed that the Bank of England reposes a touching confidence in the honesty of the public.  There are neither guards nor gratings to protect its treasures; gold, silver, banknotes are freely exposed, at the mercy of the first comer.  A keen observer of English customs relates that, being in one of the rooms of the Bank one day, he had the curiosity to examine a gold ingot weighing some seven or eight pounds. He took it up, scrutinised it, passed it to his neighbour, he to the next man, and so on until the ingot, going from hand to hand, was transferred to the end of a dark entry; nor did it return to its place for half an hour.  Meanwhile, the cashier had not so much as raised his head.  But in the present instance things had not gone so smoothly. The package of notes not being found when five o'clock sounded from the ponderous clock in the drawing office, the amount was passed to the account of profit and loss.  As soon as the robbery was discovered, picked detectives hastened off to Liverpool, Glasgow, Havre, Suez, Brindisi, New York, and other ports, inspired by the proffered reward of two thousand pounds, and five per cent. on the sum that might be recovered.  Detectives were also charged with narrowly watching those who arrived at or left London by rail, and a judicial examination was at once entered upon.
children.prevalue: It was Phileas Fogg whose head now emerged from behind his newspapers who made this remark He bowed to his friends and entered into the conversation The affair which formed its subject and which was town talk had occurred three days before at the Bank of England A package of banknotes to the value of fifty five thousand pounds had been taken from the principal cashier s table that functionary being at the moment engaged in registering the receipt of three shillings and sixpence Of course he could not have his eyes everywhere Let it be observed that the Bank of England reposes a touching confidence in the honesty of the public There are neither guards nor gratings to protect its treasures gold silver banknotes are freely exposed at the mercy of the first comer A keen observer of English customs relates that being in one of the rooms of the Bank one day he had the curiosity to examine a gold ingot weighing some seven or eight pounds He took it up scrutinised it passed it to his neighbour he to the next man and so on until the ingot going from hand to hand was transferred to the end of a dark entry nor did it return to its place for half an hour Meanwhile the cashier had not so much as raised his head But in the present instance things had not gone so smoothly The package of notes not being found when five o clock sounded from the ponderous clock in the drawing office the amount was passed to the account of profit and loss As soon as the robbery was discovered picked detectives hastened off to Liverpool Glasgow Havre Suez Brindisi New York and other ports inspired by the proffered reward of two thousand pounds and five per cent on the sum that might be recovered Detectives were also charged with narrowly watching those who arrived at or left London by rail and a judicial examination was at once entered upon

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: There were real grounds for supposing, as the Daily Telegraph said, that the thief did not belong to a professional band.  On the day of the robbery a well-dressed gentleman of polished manners, and with a well-to-do air, had been observed going to and fro in the paying room where the crime was committed.  A description of him was easily procured and sent to the detectives; and some hopeful spirits, of whom Ralph was one, did not despair of his apprehension.  The papers and clubs were full of the affair, and everywhere people were discussing the probabilities of a successful pursuit; and the Reform Club was especially agitated, several of its members being Bank officials.
children.prevalue: There were real grounds for supposing as the Daily Telegraph said that the thief did not belong to a professional band On the day of the robbery a well dressed gentleman of polished manners and with a well to do air had been observed going to and fro in the paying room where the crime was committed A description of him was easily procured and sent to the detectives and some hopeful spirits of whom Ralph was one did not despair of his apprehension The papers and clubs were full of the affair and everywhere people were discussing the probabilities of a successful pursuit and the Reform Club was especially agitated several of its members being Bank officials

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Ralph would not concede that the work of the detectives was likely to be in vain, for he thought that the prize offered would greatly stimulate their zeal and activity.  But Stuart was far from sharing this confidence; and, as they placed themselves at the whist-table, they continued to argue the matter.  Stuart and Flanagan played together, while Phileas Fogg had Fallentin for his partner.  As the game proceeded the conversation ceased, excepting between the rubbers, when it revived again.
children.prevalue: Ralph would not concede that the work of the detectives was likely to be in vain for he thought that the prize offered would greatly stimulate their zeal and activity But Stuart was far from sharing this confidence and as they placed themselves at the whist table they continued to argue the matter Stuart and Flanagan played together while Phileas Fogg had Fallentin for his partner As the game proceeded the conversation ceased excepting between the rubbers when it revived again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I maintain, said Stuart, that the chances are in favour of the thief, who must be a shrewd fellow.
children.prevalue: I maintain said Stuart that the chances are in favour of the thief who must be a shrewd fellow

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, but where can he fly to? asked Ralph.  No country is safe for him.
children.prevalue: Well but where can he fly to asked Ralph No country is safe for him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Pshaw!
children.prevalue: Pshaw

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Where could he go, then?
children.prevalue: Where could he go then

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oh, I don't know that.  The world is big enough.
children.prevalue: Oh I don t know that The world is big enough

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It was once, said Phileas Fogg, in a low tone.  Cut, sir, he added, handing the cards to Thomas Flanagan.
children.prevalue: It was once said Phileas Fogg in a low tone Cut sir he added handing the cards to Thomas Flanagan

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The discussion fell during the rubber, after which Stuart took up its thread.
children.prevalue: The discussion fell during the rubber after which Stuart took up its thread

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What do you mean by `once'?  Has the world grown smaller?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by once Has the world grown smaller

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Certainly, returned Ralph.  I agree with Mr. Fogg.  The world has grown smaller, since a man can now go round it ten times more quickly than a hundred years ago.  And that is why the search for this thief will be more likely to succeed.
children.prevalue: Certainly returned Ralph I agree with Mr Fogg The world has grown smaller since a man can now go round it ten times more quickly than a hundred years ago And that is why the search for this thief will be more likely to succeed

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And also why the thief can get away more easily.
children.prevalue: And also why the thief can get away more easily

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Be so good as to play, Mr. Stuart, said Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: Be so good as to play Mr Stuart said Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But the incredulous Stuart was not convinced, and when the hand was finished, said eagerly: You have a strange way, Ralph, of proving that the world has grown smaller.  So, because you can go round it in three months--
children.prevalue: But the incredulous Stuart was not convinced and when the hand was finished said eagerly You have a strange way Ralph of proving that the world has grown smaller So because you can go round it in three months

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In eighty days, interrupted Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: In eighty days interrupted Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: That is true, gentlemen, added John Sullivan.  Only eighty days, now that the section between Rothal and Allahabad, on the Great Indian Peninsula Railway, has been opened.  Here is the estimate made by the Daily Telegraph:
children.prevalue: That is true gentlemen added John Sullivan Only eighty days now that the section between Rothal and Allahabad on the Great Indian Peninsula Railway has been opened Here is the estimate made by the Daily Telegraph

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: From London to Suez via Mont Cenis and     Brindisi, by rail and steamboats .................  7 days   From Suez to Bombay, by steamer .................... 13     From Bombay to Calcutta, by rail ...................  3     From Calcutta to Hong Kong, by steamer ............. 13     From Hong Kong to Yokohama (Japan), by steamer .....  6     From Yokohama to San Francisco, by steamer ......... 22     From San Francisco to New York, by rail ............. 7     From New York to London, by steamer and rail ........ 9                                                          ------     Total ............................................ 80 days.
children.prevalue: From London to Suez via Mont Cenis and Brindisi by rail and steamboats 7 days From Suez to Bombay by steamer 13 From Bombay to Calcutta by rail 3 From Calcutta to Hong Kong by steamer 13 From Hong Kong to Yokohama Japan by steamer 6 From Yokohama to San Francisco by steamer 22 From San Francisco to New York by rail 7 From New York to London by steamer and rail 9 Total 80 days

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, in eighty days! exclaimed Stuart, who in his excitement made a false deal.  But that doesn't take into account bad weather, contrary winds, shipwrecks, railway accidents, and so on.
children.prevalue: Yes in eighty days exclaimed Stuart who in his excitement made a false deal But that doesn t take into account bad weather contrary winds shipwrecks railway accidents and so on

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: All included, returned Phileas Fogg, continuing to play despite the discussion.
children.prevalue: All included returned Phileas Fogg continuing to play despite the discussion

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But suppose the Hindoos or Indians pull up the rails, replied Stuart; suppose they stop the trains, pillage the luggage-vans, and scalp the passengers!
children.prevalue: But suppose the Hindoos or Indians pull up the rails replied Stuart suppose they stop the trains pillage the luggage vans and scalp the passengers

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: All included, calmly retorted Fogg; adding, as he threw down the cards, Two trumps.
children.prevalue: All included calmly retorted Fogg adding as he threw down the cards Two trumps

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Stuart, whose turn it was to deal, gathered them up, and went on: You are right, theoretically, Mr. Fogg, but practically--
children.prevalue: Stuart whose turn it was to deal gathered them up and went on You are right theoretically Mr Fogg but practically

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Practically also, Mr. Stuart.
children.prevalue: Practically also Mr Stuart

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I'd like to see you do it in eighty days.
children.prevalue: I d like to see you do it in eighty days

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: It depends on you.  Shall we go?
children.prevalue: It depends on you Shall we go

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Heaven preserve me!  But I would wager four thousand pounds that such a journey, made under these conditions, is impossible.
children.prevalue: Heaven preserve me But I would wager four thousand pounds that such a journey made under these conditions is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Quite possible, on the contrary, returned Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Quite possible on the contrary returned Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, make it, then!
children.prevalue: Well make it then

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The journey round the world in eighty days?
children.prevalue: The journey round the world in eighty days

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I should like nothing better.
children.prevalue: I should like nothing better

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: When?
children.prevalue: When

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: At once.  Only I warn you that I shall do it at your expense.
children.prevalue: At once Only I warn you that I shall do it at your expense

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It's absurd! cried Stuart, who was beginning to be annoyed at the persistency of his friend.  Come, let's go on with the game.
children.prevalue: It s absurd cried Stuart who was beginning to be annoyed at the persistency of his friend Come let s go on with the game

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Deal over again, then, said Phileas Fogg.  There's a false deal.
children.prevalue: Deal over again then said Phileas Fogg There s a false deal

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Stuart took up the pack with a feverish hand; then suddenly put them down again.
children.prevalue: Stuart took up the pack with a feverish hand then suddenly put them down again

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well, Mr. Fogg, said he, it shall be so: I will wager the four thousand on it.
children.prevalue: Well Mr Fogg said he it shall be so I will wager the four thousand on it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Calm yourself, my dear Stuart, said Fallentin.  It's only a joke.
children.prevalue: Calm yourself my dear Stuart said Fallentin It s only a joke

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: When I say I'll wager, returned Stuart, I mean it.
children.prevalue: When I say I ll wager returned Stuart I mean it

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: All right, said Mr. Fogg; and, turning to the others, he continued: I have a deposit of twenty thousand at Baring's which I will willingly risk upon it.
children.prevalue: All right said Mr Fogg and turning to the others he continued I have a deposit of twenty thousand at Baring s which I will willingly risk upon it

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Twenty thousand pounds! cried Sullivan.  Twenty thousand pounds, which you would lose by a single accidental delay!
children.prevalue: Twenty thousand pounds cried Sullivan Twenty thousand pounds which you would lose by a single accidental delay

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The unforeseen does not exist, quietly replied Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: The unforeseen does not exist quietly replied Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But, Mr. Fogg, eighty days are only the estimate of the least possible time in which the journey can be made.
children.prevalue: But Mr Fogg eighty days are only the estimate of the least possible time in which the journey can be made

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: A well-used minimum suffices for everything.
children.prevalue: A well used minimum suffices for everything

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But, in order not to exceed it, you must jump mathematically from the trains upon the steamers, and from the steamers upon the trains again.
children.prevalue: But in order not to exceed it you must jump mathematically from the trains upon the steamers and from the steamers upon the trains again

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I will jump--mathematically.
children.prevalue: I will jump mathematically

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: You are joking.
children.prevalue: You are joking

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: A true Englishman doesn't joke when he is talking about so serious a thing as a wager, replied Phileas Fogg, solemnly.  I will bet twenty thousand pounds against anyone who wishes that I will make the tour of the world in eighty days or less; in nineteen hundred and twenty hours, or a hundred and fifteen thousand two hundred minutes.  Do you accept?
children.prevalue: A true Englishman doesn t joke when he is talking about so serious a thing as a wager replied Phileas Fogg solemnly I will bet twenty thousand pounds against anyone who wishes that I will make the tour of the world in eighty days or less in nineteen hundred and twenty hours or a hundred and fifteen thousand two hundred minutes Do you accept

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: We accept, replied Messrs. Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph, after consulting each other.
children.prevalue: We accept replied Messrs Stuart Fallentin Sullivan Flanagan and Ralph after consulting each other

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Good, said Mr. Fogg.  The train leaves for Dover at a quarter before nine.  I will take it.
children.prevalue: Good said Mr Fogg The train leaves for Dover at a quarter before nine I will take it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: This very evening? asked Stuart.
children.prevalue: This very evening asked Stuart

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: This very evening, returned Phileas Fogg.  He took out and consulted a pocket almanac, and added,  As today is Wednesday, the 2nd of October, I shall be due in London in this very room of the Reform Club, on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine p.m.; or else the twenty thousand pounds, now deposited in my name at Baring's, will belong to you, in fact and in right, gentlemen.  Here is a cheque for the amount.
children.prevalue: This very evening returned Phileas Fogg He took out and consulted a pocket almanac and added As today is Wednesday the 2nd of October I shall be due in London in this very room of the Reform Club on Saturday the 21st of December at a quarter before nine p m or else the twenty thousand pounds now deposited in my name at Baring s will belong to you in fact and in right gentlemen Here is a cheque for the amount

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A memorandum of the wager was at once drawn up and signed by the six parties, during which Phileas Fogg preserved a stoical composure.  He certainly did not bet to win, and had only staked the twenty thousand pounds, half of his fortune, because he foresaw that he might have to expend the other half to carry out this difficult, not to say unattainable, project.  As for his antagonists, they seemed much agitated; not so much by the value of their stake, as because they had some scruples about betting under conditions so difficult to their friend.
children.prevalue: A memorandum of the wager was at once drawn up and signed by the six parties during which Phileas Fogg preserved a stoical composure He certainly did not bet to win and had only staked the twenty thousand pounds half of his fortune because he foresaw that he might have to expend the other half to carry out this difficult not to say unattainable project As for his antagonists they seemed much agitated not so much by the value of their stake as because they had some scruples about betting under conditions so difficult to their friend

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The clock struck seven, and the party offered to suspend the game so that Mr. Fogg might make his preparations for departure.
children.prevalue: The clock struck seven and the party offered to suspend the game so that Mr Fogg might make his preparations for departure

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I am quite ready now, was his tranquil response.  Diamonds are trumps: be so good as to play, gentlemen.
children.prevalue: I am quite ready now was his tranquil response Diamonds are trumps be so good as to play gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ASTOUNDS PASSEPARTOUT, HIS SERVANT
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ASTOUNDS PASSEPARTOUT HIS SERVANT

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Having won twenty guineas at whist, and taken leave of his friends, Phileas Fogg, at twenty-five minutes past seven, left the Reform Club.
children.prevalue: Having won twenty guineas at whist and taken leave of his friends Phileas Fogg at twenty five minutes past seven left the Reform Club

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Passepartout, who had conscientiously studied the programme of his duties, was more than surprised to see his master guilty of the inexactness of appearing at this unaccustomed hour; for, according to rule, he was not due in Saville Row until precisely midnight.
children.prevalue: Passepartout who had conscientiously studied the programme of his duties was more than surprised to see his master guilty of the inexactness of appearing at this unaccustomed hour for according to rule he was not due in Saville Row until precisely midnight

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Mr. Fogg repaired to his bedroom, and called out, Passepartout!
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg repaired to his bedroom and called out Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Passepartout did not reply.  It could not be he who was called; it was not the right hour.
children.prevalue: Passepartout did not reply It could not be he who was called it was not the right hour

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Passepartout! repeated Mr. Fogg, without raising his voice.
children.prevalue: Passepartout repeated Mr Fogg without raising his voice

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Passepartout made his appearance.
children.prevalue: Passepartout made his appearance

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I've called you twice, observed his master.
children.prevalue: I ve called you twice observed his master

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But it is not midnight, responded the other, showing his watch.
children.prevalue: But it is not midnight responded the other showing his watch

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I know it; I don't blame you.  We start for Dover and Calais in ten minutes.
children.prevalue: I know it I don t blame you We start for Dover and Calais in ten minutes

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: A puzzled grin overspread Passepartout's round face; clearly he had not comprehended his master.
children.prevalue: A puzzled grin overspread Passepartout s round face clearly he had not comprehended his master

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Monsieur is going to leave home?
children.prevalue: Monsieur is going to leave home

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, returned Phileas Fogg.  We are going round the world.
children.prevalue: Yes returned Phileas Fogg We are going round the world

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Passepartout opened wide his eyes, raised his eyebrows, held up his hands, and seemed about to collapse, so overcome was he with stupefied astonishment.
children.prevalue: Passepartout opened wide his eyes raised his eyebrows held up his hands and seemed about to collapse so overcome was he with stupefied astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Round the world! he murmured.
children.prevalue: Round the world he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: In eighty days, responded Mr. Fogg.  So we haven't a moment to lose.
children.prevalue: In eighty days responded Mr Fogg So we haven t a moment to lose

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But the trunks? gasped Passepartout, unconsciously swaying his head from right to left.
children.prevalue: But the trunks gasped Passepartout unconsciously swaying his head from right to left

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: We'll have no trunks; only a carpet-bag, with two shirts and three pairs of stockings for me, and the same for you.  We'll buy our clothes on the way.  Bring down my mackintosh and traveling-cloak, and some stout shoes, though we shall do little walking.  Make haste!
children.prevalue: We ll have no trunks only a carpet bag with two shirts and three pairs of stockings for me and the same for you We ll buy our clothes on the way Bring down my mackintosh and traveling cloak and some stout shoes though we shall do little walking Make haste

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Passepartout tried to reply, but could not.  He went out, mounted to his own room, fell into a chair, and muttered: That's good, that is! And I, who wanted to remain quiet!
children.prevalue: Passepartout tried to reply but could not He went out mounted to his own room fell into a chair and muttered That s good that is And I who wanted to remain quiet

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: He mechanically set about making the preparations for departure. Around the world in eighty days!  Was his master a fool?  No.  Was this a joke, then?  They were going to Dover; good!  To Calais; good again! After all, Passepartout, who had been away from France five years, would not be sorry to set foot on his native soil again.  Perhaps they would go as far as Paris, and it would do his eyes good to see Paris once more.  But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there; no doubt--but, then, it was none the less true that he was going away, this so domestic person hitherto!
children.prevalue: He mechanically set about making the preparations for departure Around the world in eighty days Was his master a fool No Was this a joke then They were going to Dover good To Calais good again After all Passepartout who had been away from France five years would not be sorry to set foot on his native soil again Perhaps they would go as far as Paris and it would do his eyes good to see Paris once more But surely a gentleman so chary of his steps would stop there no doubt but then it was none the less true that he was going away this so domestic person hitherto

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: By eight o'clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet-bag, containing the wardrobes of his master and himself; then, still troubled in mind, he carefully shut the door of his room, and descended to Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: By eight o clock Passepartout had packed the modest carpet bag containing the wardrobes of his master and himself then still troubled in mind he carefully shut the door of his room and descended to Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Mr. Fogg was quite ready.  Under his arm might have been observed a red-bound copy of Bradshaw's Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide, with its timetables showing the arrival and departure of steamers and railways.  He took the carpet-bag, opened it, and slipped into it a goodly roll of Bank of England notes, which would pass wherever he might go.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg was quite ready Under his arm might have been observed a red bound copy of Bradshaw s Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide with its timetables showing the arrival and departure of steamers and railways He took the carpet bag opened it and slipped into it a goodly roll of Bank of England notes which would pass wherever he might go

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You have forgotten nothing? asked he.
children.prevalue: You have forgotten nothing asked he

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Nothing, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Nothing monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: My mackintosh and cloak?
children.prevalue: My mackintosh and cloak

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Here they are.
children.prevalue: Here they are

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Good!  Take this carpet-bag, handing it to Passepartout.  Take good care of it, for there are twenty thousand pounds in it.
children.prevalue: Good Take this carpet bag handing it to Passepartout Take good care of it for there are twenty thousand pounds in it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Passepartout nearly dropped the bag, as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold, and weighed him down.
children.prevalue: Passepartout nearly dropped the bag as if the twenty thousand pounds were in gold and weighed him down

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Master and man then descended, the street-door was double-locked, and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross.  The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight.  Passepartout jumped off the box and followed his master, who, after paying the cabman, was about to enter the station, when a poor beggar-woman, with a child in her arms, her naked feet smeared with mud, her head covered with a wretched bonnet, from which hung a tattered feather, and her shoulders shrouded in a ragged shawl, approached, and mournfully asked for alms.
children.prevalue: Master and man then descended the street door was double locked and at the end of Saville Row they took a cab and drove rapidly to Charing Cross The cab stopped before the railway station at twenty minutes past eight Passepartout jumped off the box and followed his master who after paying the cabman was about to enter the station when a poor beggar woman with a child in her arms her naked feet smeared with mud her head covered with a wretched bonnet from which hung a tattered feather and her shoulders shrouded in a ragged shawl approached and mournfully asked for alms

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Mr. Fogg took out the twenty guineas he had just won at whist, and handed them to the beggar, saying, Here, my good woman.  I'm glad that I met you; and passed on.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg took out the twenty guineas he had just won at whist and handed them to the beggar saying Here my good woman I m glad that I met you and passed on

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Passepartout had a moist sensation about the eyes; his master's action touched his susceptible heart.
children.prevalue: Passepartout had a moist sensation about the eyes his master s action touched his susceptible heart

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Two first-class tickets for Paris having been speedily purchased, Mr. Fogg was crossing the station to the train, when he perceived his five friends of the Reform.
children.prevalue: Two first class tickets for Paris having been speedily purchased Mr Fogg was crossing the station to the train when he perceived his five friends of the Reform

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, gentlemen, said he, I'm off, you see; and, if you will examine my passport when I get back, you will be able to judge whether I have accomplished the journey agreed upon.
children.prevalue: Well gentlemen said he I m off you see and if you will examine my passport when I get back you will be able to judge whether I have accomplished the journey agreed upon

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Oh, that would be quite unnecessary, Mr. Fogg, said Ralph politely. We will trust your word, as a gentleman of honour.
children.prevalue: Oh that would be quite unnecessary Mr Fogg said Ralph politely We will trust your word as a gentleman of honour

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You do not forget when you are due in London again?  asked Stuart.
children.prevalue: You do not forget when you are due in London again asked Stuart

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: In eighty days; on Saturday, the 21st of December, 1872, at a quarter before nine p.m.  Good-bye, gentlemen.
children.prevalue: In eighty days on Saturday the 21st of December 1872 at a quarter before nine p m Good bye gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first-class carriage at twenty minutes before nine; five minutes later the whistle screamed, and the train slowly glided out of the station.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg and his servant seated themselves in a first class carriage at twenty minutes before nine five minutes later the whistle screamed and the train slowly glided out of the station

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The night was dark, and a fine, steady rain was falling.  Phileas Fogg, snugly ensconced in his corner, did not open his lips.  Passepartout, not yet recovered from his stupefaction, clung mechanically to the carpet-bag, with its enormous treasure.
children.prevalue: The night was dark and a fine steady rain was falling Phileas Fogg snugly ensconced in his corner did not open his lips Passepartout not yet recovered from his stupefaction clung mechanically to the carpet bag with its enormous treasure

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Just as the train was whirling through Sydenham, Passepartout suddenly uttered a cry of despair.
children.prevalue: Just as the train was whirling through Sydenham Passepartout suddenly uttered a cry of despair

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What's the matter? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: What s the matter asked Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Alas!  In my hurry--I--I forgot--
children.prevalue: Alas In my hurry I I forgot

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: To turn off the gas in my room!
children.prevalue: To turn off the gas in my room

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Very well, young man, returned Mr. Fogg, coolly; it will burn--at your expense.
children.prevalue: Very well young man returned Mr Fogg coolly it will burn at your expense

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH A NEW SPECIES OF FUNDS, UNKNOWN TO THE MONEYED MEN, APPEARS ON 'CHANGE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH A NEW SPECIES OF FUNDS UNKNOWN TO THE MONEYED MEN APPEARS ON CHANGE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End.  The news of the bet spread through the Reform Club, and afforded an exciting topic of conversation to its members.  From the club it soon got into the papers throughout England.  The boasted tour of the world was talked about, disputed, argued with as much warmth as if the subject were another Alabama claim.  Some took sides with Phileas Fogg, but the large majority shook their heads and declared against him; it was absurd, impossible, they declared, that the tour of the world could be made, except theoretically and on paper, in this minimum of time, and with the existing means of travelling.  The Times, Standard, Morning Post, and Daily News, and twenty other highly respectable newspapers scouted Mr. Fogg's project as madness; the Daily Telegraph alone hesitatingly supported him.  People in general thought him a lunatic, and blamed his Reform Club friends for having accepted a wager which betrayed the mental aberration of its proposer.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg rightly suspected that his departure from London would create a lively sensation at the West End The news of the bet spread through the Reform Club and afforded an exciting topic of conversation to its members From the club it soon got into the papers throughout England The boasted tour of the world was talked about disputed argued with as much warmth as if the subject were another Alabama claim Some took sides with Phileas Fogg but the large majority shook their heads and declared against him it was absurd impossible they declared that the tour of the world could be made except theoretically and on paper in this minimum of time and with the existing means of travelling The Times Standard Morning Post and Daily News and twenty other highly respectable newspapers scouted Mr Fogg s project as madness the Daily Telegraph alone hesitatingly supported him People in general thought him a lunatic and blamed his Reform Club friends for having accepted a wager which betrayed the mental aberration of its proposer

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Articles no less passionate than logical appeared on the question, for geography is one of the pet subjects of the English; and the columns devoted to Phileas Fogg's venture were eagerly devoured by all classes of readers.  At first some rash individuals, principally of the gentler sex, espoused his cause, which became still more popular when the Illustrated London News came out with his portrait, copied from a photograph in the Reform Club.  A few readers of the Daily Telegraph even dared to say, Why not, after all?  Stranger things have come to pass.
children.prevalue: Articles no less passionate than logical appeared on the question for geography is one of the pet subjects of the English and the columns devoted to Phileas Fogg s venture were eagerly devoured by all classes of readers At first some rash individuals principally of the gentler sex espoused his cause which became still more popular when the Illustrated London News came out with his portrait copied from a photograph in the Reform Club A few readers of the Daily Telegraph even dared to say Why not after all Stranger things have come to pass

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: At last a long article appeared, on the 7th of October, in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society, which treated the question from every point of view, and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise.
children.prevalue: At last a long article appeared on the 7th of October in the bulletin of the Royal Geographical Society which treated the question from every point of view and demonstrated the utter folly of the enterprise

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Everything, it said, was against the travellers, every obstacle imposed alike by man and by nature.  A miraculous agreement of the times of departure and arrival, which was impossible, was absolutely necessary to his success.  He might, perhaps, reckon on the arrival of trains at the designated hours, in Europe, where the distances were relatively moderate; but when he calculated upon crossing India in three days, and the United States in seven, could he rely beyond misgiving upon accomplishing his task?  There were accidents to machinery, the liability of trains to run off the line, collisions, bad weather, the blocking up by snow--were not all these against Phileas Fogg?  Would he not find himself, when travelling by steamer in winter, at the mercy of the winds and fogs?  Is it uncommon for the best ocean steamers to be two or three days behind time?  But a single delay would suffice to fatally break the chain of communication; should Phileas Fogg once miss, even by an hour; a steamer, he would have to wait for the next, and that would irrevocably render his attempt vain.
children.prevalue: Everything it said was against the travellers every obstacle imposed alike by man and by nature A miraculous agreement of the times of departure and arrival which was impossible was absolutely necessary to his success He might perhaps reckon on the arrival of trains at the designated hours in Europe where the distances were relatively moderate but when he calculated upon crossing India in three days and the United States in seven could he rely beyond misgiving upon accomplishing his task There were accidents to machinery the liability of trains to run off the line collisions bad weather the blocking up by snow were not all these against Phileas Fogg Would he not find himself when travelling by steamer in winter at the mercy of the winds and fogs Is it uncommon for the best ocean steamers to be two or three days behind time But a single delay would suffice to fatally break the chain of communication should Phileas Fogg once miss even by an hour a steamer he would have to wait for the next and that would irrevocably render his attempt vain

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: This article made a great deal of noise, and, being copied into all the papers, seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist.
children.prevalue: This article made a great deal of noise and being copied into all the papers seriously depressed the advocates of the rash tourist

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men, who are of a higher class than mere gamblers; to bet is in the English temperament. Not only the members of the Reform, but the general public, made heavy wagers for or against Phileas Fogg, who was set down in the betting books as if he were a race-horse.  Bonds were issued, and made their appearance on 'Change; Phileas Fogg bonds were offered at par or at a premium, and a great business was done in them.  But five days after the article in the bulletin of the Geographical Society appeared, the demand began to subside:  Phileas Fogg declined.  They were offered by packages, at first of five, then of ten, until at last nobody would take less than twenty, fifty, a hundred!
children.prevalue: Everybody knows that England is the world of betting men who are of a higher class than mere gamblers to bet is in the English temperament Not only the members of the Reform but the general public made heavy wagers for or against Phileas Fogg who was set down in the betting books as if he were a race horse Bonds were issued and made their appearance on Change Phileas Fogg bonds were offered at par or at a premium and a great business was done in them But five days after the article in the bulletin of the Geographical Society appeared the demand began to subside Phileas Fogg declined They were offered by packages at first of five then of ten until at last nobody would take less than twenty fifty a hundred

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Lord Albemarle, an elderly paralytic gentleman, was now the only advocate of Phileas Fogg left.  This noble lord, who was fastened to his chair, would have given his fortune to be able to make the tour of the world, if it took ten years; and he bet five thousand pounds on Phileas Fogg.  When the folly as well as the uselessness of the adventure was pointed out to him, he contented himself with replying, If the thing is feasible, the first to do it ought to be an Englishman.
children.prevalue: Lord Albemarle an elderly paralytic gentleman was now the only advocate of Phileas Fogg left This noble lord who was fastened to his chair would have given his fortune to be able to make the tour of the world if it took ten years and he bet five thousand pounds on Phileas Fogg When the folly as well as the uselessness of the adventure was pointed out to him he contented himself with replying If the thing is feasible the first to do it ought to be an Englishman

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Fogg party dwindled more and more, everybody was going against him, and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one; and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price.
