children.prevalue: The Fogg party dwindled more and more everybody was going against him and the bets stood a hundred and fifty and two hundred to one and a week after his departure an incident occurred which deprived him of backers at any price

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o'clock one evening, when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands:
children.prevalue: The commissioner of police was sitting in his office at nine o clock one evening when the following telegraphic dispatch was put into his hands

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Suez to London.
children.prevalue: Suez to London

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Rowan, Commissioner of Police, Scotland Yard:
children.prevalue: Rowan Commissioner of Police Scotland Yard

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I've found the bank robber, Phileas Fogg.  Send with out delay warrant of arrest to Bombay.
children.prevalue: I ve found the bank robber Phileas Fogg Send with out delay warrant of arrest to Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Fix, Detective.
children.prevalue: Fix Detective

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The effect of this dispatch was instantaneous.  The polished gentleman disappeared to give place to the bank robber.  His photograph, which was hung with those of the rest of the members at the Reform Club, was minutely examined, and it betrayed, feature by feature, the description of the robber which had been provided to the police.  The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled; his solitary ways, his sudden departure; and it seemed clear that, in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager, he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives, and throw them off his track.
children.prevalue: The effect of this dispatch was instantaneous The polished gentleman disappeared to give place to the bank robber His photograph which was hung with those of the rest of the members at the Reform Club was minutely examined and it betrayed feature by feature the description of the robber which had been provided to the police The mysterious habits of Phileas Fogg were recalled his solitary ways his sudden departure and it seemed clear that in undertaking a tour round the world on the pretext of a wager he had had no other end in view than to elude the detectives and throw them off his track

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, BETRAYS A VERY NATURAL IMPATIENCE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH FIX THE DETECTIVE BETRAYS A VERY NATURAL IMPATIENCE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows:
children.prevalue: The circumstances under which this telegraphic dispatch about Phileas Fogg was sent were as follows

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The steamer Mongolia, belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company, built of iron, of two thousand eight hundred tons burden, and five hundred horse-power, was due at eleven o'clock a.m. on Wednesday, the 9th of October, at Suez.  The Mongolia plied regularly between Brindisi and Bombay via the Suez Canal, and was one of the fastest steamers belonging to the company, always making more than ten knots an hour between Brindisi and Suez, and nine and a half between Suez and Bombay.
children.prevalue: The steamer Mongolia belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company built of iron of two thousand eight hundred tons burden and five hundred horse power was due at eleven o clock a m on Wednesday the 9th of October at Suez The Mongolia plied regularly between Brindisi and Bombay via the Suez Canal and was one of the fastest steamers belonging to the company always making more than ten knots an hour between Brindisi and Suez and nine and a half between Suez and Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Two men were promenading up and down the wharves, among the crowd of natives and strangers who were sojourning at this once straggling village--now, thanks to the enterprise of M. Lesseps, a fast-growing town.  One was the British consul at Suez, who, despite the prophecies of the English Government, and the unfavourable predictions of Stephenson, was in the habit of seeing, from his office window, English ships daily passing to and fro on the great canal, by which the old roundabout route from England to India by the Cape of Good Hope was abridged by at least a half.  The other was a small, slight-built personage, with a nervous, intelligent face, and bright eyes peering out from under eyebrows which he was incessantly twitching.  He was just now manifesting unmistakable signs of impatience, nervously pacing up and down, and unable to stand still for a moment.  This was Fix, one of the detectives who had been dispatched from England in search of the bank robber; it was his task to narrowly watch every passenger who arrived at Suez, and to follow up all who seemed to be suspicious characters, or bore a resemblance to the description of the criminal, which he had received two days before from the police headquarters at London.  The detective was evidently inspired by the hope of obtaining the splendid reward which would be the prize of success, and awaited with a feverish impatience, easy to understand, the arrival of the steamer Mongolia.
children.prevalue: Two men were promenading up and down the wharves among the crowd of natives and strangers who were sojourning at this once straggling village now thanks to the enterprise of M Lesseps a fast growing town One was the British consul at Suez who despite the prophecies of the English Government and the unfavourable predictions of Stephenson was in the habit of seeing from his office window English ships daily passing to and fro on the great canal by which the old roundabout route from England to India by the Cape of Good Hope was abridged by at least a half The other was a small slight built personage with a nervous intelligent face and bright eyes peering out from under eyebrows which he was incessantly twitching He was just now manifesting unmistakable signs of impatience nervously pacing up and down and unable to stand still for a moment This was Fix one of the detectives who had been dispatched from England in search of the bank robber it was his task to narrowly watch every passenger who arrived at Suez and to follow up all who seemed to be suspicious characters or bore a resemblance to the description of the criminal which he had received two days before from the police headquarters at London The detective was evidently inspired by the hope of obtaining the splendid reward which would be the prize of success and awaited with a feverish impatience easy to understand the arrival of the steamer Mongolia

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: So you say, consul, asked he for the twentieth time, that this steamer is never behind time?
children.prevalue: So you say consul asked he for the twentieth time that this steamer is never behind time

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: No, Mr. Fix, replied the consul.  She was bespoken yesterday at Port Said, and the rest of the way is of no account to such a craft.  I repeat that the Mongolia has been in advance of the time required by the company's regulations, and gained the prize awarded for excess of speed.
children.prevalue: No Mr Fix replied the consul She was bespoken yesterday at Port Said and the rest of the way is of no account to such a craft I repeat that the Mongolia has been in advance of the time required by the company s regulations and gained the prize awarded for excess of speed

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Does she come directly from Brindisi?
children.prevalue: Does she come directly from Brindisi

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Directly from Brindisi; she takes on the Indian mails there, and she left there Saturday at five p.m.  Have patience, Mr. Fix; she will not be late.  But really, I don't see how, from the description you have, you will be able to recognise your man, even if he is on board the Mongolia.
children.prevalue: Directly from Brindisi she takes on the Indian mails there and she left there Saturday at five p m Have patience Mr Fix she will not be late But really I don t see how from the description you have you will be able to recognise your man even if he is on board the Mongolia

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: A man rather feels the presence of these fellows, consul, than recognises them.  You must have a scent for them, and a scent is like a sixth sense which combines hearing, seeing, and smelling.  I've arrested more than one of these gentlemen in my time, and, if my thief is on board, I'll answer for it; he'll not slip through my fingers.
children.prevalue: A man rather feels the presence of these fellows consul than recognises them You must have a scent for them and a scent is like a sixth sense which combines hearing seeing and smelling I ve arrested more than one of these gentlemen in my time and if my thief is on board I ll answer for it he ll not slip through my fingers

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I hope so, Mr. Fix, for it was a heavy robbery.
children.prevalue: I hope so Mr Fix for it was a heavy robbery

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: A magnificent robbery, consul; fifty-five thousand pounds!  We don't often have such windfalls.  Burglars are getting to be so contemptible nowadays!  A fellow gets hung for a handful of shillings!
children.prevalue: A magnificent robbery consul fifty five thousand pounds We don t often have such windfalls Burglars are getting to be so contemptible nowadays A fellow gets hung for a handful of shillings

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Mr. Fix, said the consul, I like your way of talking, and hope you'll succeed; but I fear you will find it far from easy.  Don't you see, the description which you have there has a singular resemblance to an honest man?
children.prevalue: Mr Fix said the consul I like your way of talking and hope you ll succeed but I fear you will find it far from easy Don t you see the description which you have there has a singular resemblance to an honest man

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Consul, remarked the detective, dogmatically, great robbers always resemble honest folks.  Fellows who have rascally faces have only one course to take, and that is to remain honest; otherwise they would be arrested off-hand.  The artistic thing is, to unmask honest countenances; it's no light task, I admit, but a real art.
children.prevalue: Consul remarked the detective dogmatically great robbers always resemble honest folks Fellows who have rascally faces have only one course to take and that is to remain honest otherwise they would be arrested off hand The artistic thing is to unmask honest countenances it s no light task I admit but a real art

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Mr. Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self-conceit.
children.prevalue: Mr Fix evidently was not wanting in a tinge of self conceit

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated; sailors of various nations, merchants, ship-brokers, porters, fellahs, bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected.  The weather was clear, and slightly chilly.  The minarets of the town loomed above the houses in the pale rays of the sun.  A jetty pier, some two thousand yards along, extended into the roadstead.  A number of fishing-smacks and coasting boats, some retaining the fantastic fashion of ancient galleys, were discernible on the Red Sea.
children.prevalue: Little by little the scene on the quay became more animated sailors of various nations merchants ship brokers porters fellahs bustled to and fro as if the steamer were immediately expected The weather was clear and slightly chilly The minarets of the town loomed above the houses in the pale rays of the sun A jetty pier some two thousand yards along extended into the roadstead A number of fishing smacks and coasting boats some retaining the fantastic fashion of ancient galleys were discernible on the Red Sea

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: As he passed among the busy crowd, Fix, according to habit, scrutinised the passers-by with a keen, rapid glance.
children.prevalue: As he passed among the busy crowd Fix according to habit scrutinised the passers by with a keen rapid glance

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It was now half-past ten.
children.prevalue: It was now half past ten

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The steamer doesn't come! he exclaimed, as the port clock struck.
children.prevalue: The steamer doesn t come he exclaimed as the port clock struck

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: She can't be far off now, returned his companion.
children.prevalue: She can t be far off now returned his companion

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: How long will she stop at Suez?
children.prevalue: How long will she stop at Suez

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Four hours; long enough to get in her coal.  It is thirteen hundred and ten miles from Suez to Aden, at the other end of the Red Sea, and she has to take in a fresh coal supply.
children.prevalue: Four hours long enough to get in her coal It is thirteen hundred and ten miles from Suez to Aden at the other end of the Red Sea and she has to take in a fresh coal supply

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And does she go from Suez directly to Bombay?
children.prevalue: And does she go from Suez directly to Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Without putting in anywhere.
children.prevalue: Without putting in anywhere

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Good! said Fix.  If the robber is on board he will no doubt get off at Suez, so as to reach the Dutch or French colonies in Asia by some other route.  He ought to know that he would not be safe an hour in India, which is English soil.
children.prevalue: Good said Fix If the robber is on board he will no doubt get off at Suez so as to reach the Dutch or French colonies in Asia by some other route He ought to know that he would not be safe an hour in India which is English soil

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Unless, objected the consul, he is exceptionally shrewd.  An English criminal, you know, is always better concealed in London than anywhere else.
children.prevalue: Unless objected the consul he is exceptionally shrewd An English criminal you know is always better concealed in London than anywhere else

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: This observation furnished the detective food for thought, and meanwhile the consul went away to his office.  Fix, left alone, was more impatient than ever, having a presentiment that the robber was on board the Mongolia.  If he had indeed left London intending to reach the New World, he would naturally take the route via India, which was less watched and more difficult to watch than that of the Atlantic. But Fix's reflections were soon interrupted by a succession of sharp whistles, which announced the arrival of the Mongolia.  The porters and fellahs rushed down the quay, and a dozen boats pushed off from the shore to go and meet the steamer.  Soon her gigantic hull appeared passing along between the banks, and eleven o'clock struck as she anchored in the road.  She brought an unusual number of passengers, some of whom remained on deck to scan the picturesque panorama of the town, while the greater part disembarked in the boats, and landed on the quay.
children.prevalue: This observation furnished the detective food for thought and meanwhile the consul went away to his office Fix left alone was more impatient than ever having a presentiment that the robber was on board the Mongolia If he had indeed left London intending to reach the New World he would naturally take the route via India which was less watched and more difficult to watch than that of the Atlantic But Fix s reflections were soon interrupted by a succession of sharp whistles which announced the arrival of the Mongolia The porters and fellahs rushed down the quay and a dozen boats pushed off from the shore to go and meet the steamer Soon her gigantic hull appeared passing along between the banks and eleven o clock struck as she anchored in the road She brought an unusual number of passengers some of whom remained on deck to scan the picturesque panorama of the town while the greater part disembarked in the boats and landed on the quay

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Fix took up a position, and carefully examined each face and figure which made its appearance.  Presently one of the passengers, after vigorously pushing his way through the importunate crowd of porters, came up to him and politely asked if he could point out the English consulate, at the same time showing a passport which he wished to have visaed.  Fix instinctively took the passport, and with a rapid glance read the description of its bearer.  An involuntary motion of surprise nearly escaped him, for the description in the passport was identical with that of the bank robber which he had received from Scotland Yard.

children.value: Is this your passport? asked he.
children.prevalue: Is this your passport asked he

children.value: No, it's my master's.
children.prevalue: No it s my master s

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And your master is--
children.prevalue: And your master is

children.value: He stayed on board.
children.prevalue: He stayed on board

children.value: But he must go to the consul's in person, so as to establish his identity.
children.prevalue: But he must go to the consul s in person so as to establish his identity

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oh, is that necessary?
children.prevalue: Oh is that necessary

children.prevalue: And where is the consulate

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: There, on the corner of the square, said Fix, pointing to a house two hundred steps off.
children.prevalue: There on the corner of the square said Fix pointing to a house two hundred steps off

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I'll go and fetch my master, who won't be much pleased, however, to be disturbed.
children.prevalue: I ll go and fetch my master who won t be much pleased however to be disturbed

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The passenger bowed to Fix, and returned to the steamer.
children.prevalue: The passenger bowed to Fix and returned to the steamer

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WHICH ONCE MORE DEMONSTRATES THE USELESSNESS OF PASSPORTS AS AIDS TO DETECTIVES
children.prevalue: WHICH ONCE MORE DEMONSTRATES THE USELESSNESS OF PASSPORTS AS AIDS TO DETECTIVES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The detective passed down the quay, and rapidly made his way to the consul's office, where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official.
children.prevalue: The detective passed down the quay and rapidly made his way to the consul s office where he was at once admitted to the presence of that official

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Consul, said he, without preamble, I have strong reasons for believing that my man is a passenger on the Mongolia. And he narrated what had just passed concerning the passport.
children.prevalue: Consul said he without preamble I have strong reasons for believing that my man is a passenger on the Mongolia And he narrated what had just passed concerning the passport

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Well, Mr. Fix, replied the consul, I shall not be sorry to see the rascal's face; but perhaps he won't come here--that is, if he is the person you suppose him to be.  A robber doesn't quite like to leave traces of his flight behind him; and, besides, he is not obliged to have his passport countersigned.
children.prevalue: Well Mr Fix replied the consul I shall not be sorry to see the rascal s face but perhaps he won t come here that is if he is the person you suppose him to be A robber doesn t quite like to leave traces of his flight behind him and besides he is not obliged to have his passport countersigned

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: If he is as shrewd as I think he is, consul, he will come.
children.prevalue: If he is as shrewd as I think he is consul he will come

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: To have his passport visaed?
children.prevalue: To have his passport visaed

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes.  Passports are only good for annoying honest folks, and aiding in the flight of rogues.  I assure you it will be quite the thing for him to do; but I hope you will not visa the passport.
children.prevalue: Yes Passports are only good for annoying honest folks and aiding in the flight of rogues I assure you it will be quite the thing for him to do but I hope you will not visa the passport

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why not?  If the passport is genuine I have no right to refuse.
children.prevalue: Why not If the passport is genuine I have no right to refuse

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Still, I must keep this man here until I can get a warrant to arrest him from London.
children.prevalue: Still I must keep this man here until I can get a warrant to arrest him from London

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Ah, that's your look-out.  But I cannot--
children.prevalue: Ah that s your look out But I cannot

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The consul did not finish his sentence, for as he spoke a knock was heard at the door, and two strangers entered, one of whom was the servant whom Fix had met on the quay.  The other, who was his master, held out his passport with the request that the consul would do him the favour to visa it.  The consul took the document and carefully read it, whilst Fix observed, or rather devoured, the stranger with his eyes from a corner of the room.
children.prevalue: The consul did not finish his sentence for as he spoke a knock was heard at the door and two strangers entered one of whom was the servant whom Fix had met on the quay The other who was his master held out his passport with the request that the consul would do him the favour to visa it The consul took the document and carefully read it whilst Fix observed or rather devoured the stranger with his eyes from a corner of the room

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You are Mr. Phileas Fogg? said the consul, after reading the passport.
children.prevalue: You are Mr Phileas Fogg said the consul after reading the passport

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I am.
children.prevalue: I am

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And this man is your servant?
children.prevalue: And this man is your servant

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He is: a Frenchman, named Passepartout.
children.prevalue: He is a Frenchman named Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You are from London?
children.prevalue: You are from London

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And you are going--
children.prevalue: And you are going

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: To Bombay.
children.prevalue: To Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Very good, sir.  You know that a visa is useless, and that no passport is required?
children.prevalue: Very good sir You know that a visa is useless and that no passport is required

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I know it, sir, replied Phileas Fogg; but I wish to prove, by your visa, that I came by Suez.
children.prevalue: I know it sir replied Phileas Fogg but I wish to prove by your visa that I came by Suez

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Very well, sir.
children.prevalue: Very well sir

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The consul proceeded to sign and date the passport, after which he added his official seal.  Mr. Fogg paid the customary fee, coldly bowed, and went out, followed by his servant.
children.prevalue: The consul proceeded to sign and date the passport after which he added his official seal Mr Fogg paid the customary fee coldly bowed and went out followed by his servant

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Well? queried the detective.
children.prevalue: Well queried the detective

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Well, he looks and acts like a perfectly honest man, replied the consul.
children.prevalue: Well he looks and acts like a perfectly honest man replied the consul

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Possibly; but that is not the question.  Do you think, consul, that this phlegmatic gentleman resembles, feature by feature, the robber whose description I have received?
children.prevalue: Possibly but that is not the question Do you think consul that this phlegmatic gentleman resembles feature by feature the robber whose description I have received

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I concede that; but then, you know, all descriptions--
children.prevalue: I concede that but then you know all descriptions

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I'll make certain of it, interrupted Fix.  The servant seems to me less mysterious than the master; besides, he's a Frenchman, and can't help talking.  Excuse me for a little while, consul.
children.prevalue: I ll make certain of it interrupted Fix The servant seems to me less mysterious than the master besides he s a Frenchman and can t help talking Excuse me for a little while consul

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Fix started off in search of Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Fix started off in search of Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Meanwhile Mr. Fogg, after leaving the consulate, repaired to the quay, gave some orders to Passepartout, went off to the    Mongolia in a boat, and descended to his cabin.  He took up his note-book, which contained the following memoranda:

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Left London, Wednesday, October 2nd, at 8.45 p.m.  Reached Paris, Thursday, October 3rd, at 7.20 a.m.  Left Paris, Thursday, at 8.40 a.m.  Reached Turin by Mont Cenis, Friday, October 4th, at 6.35 a.m. Left Turin, Friday, at 7.20 a.m.  Arrived at Brindisi, Saturday, October 5th, at 4 p.m.  Sailed on the Mongolia, Saturday, at 5 p.m. Reached Suez, Wednesday, October 9th, at 11 a.m.  Total of hours spent, 158+; or, in days, six days and a half.
children.prevalue: Left London Wednesday October 2nd at 8 45 p m Reached Paris Thursday October 3rd at 7 20 a m Left Paris Thursday at 8 40 a m Reached Turin by Mont Cenis Friday October 4th at 6 35 a m Left Turin Friday at 7 20 a m Arrived at Brindisi Saturday October 5th at 4 p m Sailed on the Mongolia Saturday at 5 p m Reached Suez Wednesday October 9th at 11 a m Total of hours spent 158 or in days six days and a half

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: These dates were inscribed in an itinerary divided into columns, indicating the month, the day of the month, and the day for the stipulated and actual arrivals at each principal point Paris, Brindisi, Suez, Bombay, Calcutta, Singapore, Hong Kong, Yokohama, San Francisco, New York, and London--from the 2nd of October to the 21st of December; and giving a space for setting down the gain made or the loss suffered on arrival at each locality.  This methodical record thus contained an account of everything needed, and Mr. Fogg always knew whether he was behind-hand or in advance of his time.  On this Friday, October 9th, he noted his arrival at Suez, and observed that he had as yet neither gained nor lost.  He sat down quietly to breakfast in his cabin, never once thinking of inspecting the town, being one of those Englishmen who are wont to see foreign countries through the eyes of their domestics.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TALKS RATHER MORE, PERHAPS, THAN IS PRUDENT
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TALKS RATHER MORE PERHAPS THAN IS PRUDENT

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Fix soon rejoined Passepartout, who was lounging and looking about on the quay, as if he did not feel that he, at least, was obliged not to see anything.
children.prevalue: Fix soon rejoined Passepartout who was lounging and looking about on the quay as if he did not feel that he at least was obliged not to see anything

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well, my friend, said the detective, coming up with him, is your passport visaed?
children.prevalue: Well my friend said the detective coming up with him is your passport visaed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Ah, it's you, is it, monsieur? responded Passepartout.  Thanks, yes, the passport is all right.
children.prevalue: Ah it s you is it monsieur responded Passepartout Thanks yes the passport is all right

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And you are looking about you?
children.prevalue: And you are looking about you

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes; but we travel so fast that I seem to be journeying in a dream. So this is Suez?
children.prevalue: Yes but we travel so fast that I seem to be journeying in a dream So this is Suez

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: In Egypt?
children.prevalue: In Egypt

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Certainly, in Egypt.
children.prevalue: Certainly in Egypt

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And in Africa?
children.prevalue: And in Africa

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: In Africa.
children.prevalue: In Africa

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In Africa! repeated Passepartout.  Just think, monsieur, I had no idea that we should go farther than Paris; and all that I saw of Paris was between twenty minutes past seven and twenty minutes before nine in the morning, between the Northern and the Lyons stations, through the windows of a car, and in a driving rain!  How I regret not having seen once more Pere la Chaise and the circus in the Champs Elysees!
children.prevalue: In Africa repeated Passepartout Just think monsieur I had no idea that we should go farther than Paris and all that I saw of Paris was between twenty minutes past seven and twenty minutes before nine in the morning between the Northern and the Lyons stations through the windows of a car and in a driving rain How I regret not having seen once more Pere la Chaise and the circus in the Champs Elysees

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You are in a great hurry, then?
children.prevalue: You are in a great hurry then

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I am not, but my master is.  By the way, I must buy some shoes and shirts.  We came away without trunks, only with a carpet-bag.
children.prevalue: I am not but my master is By the way I must buy some shoes and shirts We came away without trunks only with a carpet bag

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I will show you an excellent shop for getting what you want.
children.prevalue: I will show you an excellent shop for getting what you want

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Really, monsieur, you are very kind.
children.prevalue: Really monsieur you are very kind

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And they walked off together, Passepartout chatting volubly as they went along.
children.prevalue: And they walked off together Passepartout chatting volubly as they went along

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Above all, said he; don't let me lose the steamer.
children.prevalue: Above all said he don t let me lose the steamer

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You have plenty of time; it's only twelve o'clock.
children.prevalue: You have plenty of time it s only twelve o clock

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Passepartout pulled out his big watch.  Twelve! he exclaimed; why, it's only eight minutes before ten.
children.prevalue: Passepartout pulled out his big watch Twelve he exclaimed why it s only eight minutes before ten

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Your watch is slow.
children.prevalue: Your watch is slow

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: My watch?  A family watch, monsieur, which has come down from my great-grandfather!  It doesn't vary five minutes in the year.  It's a perfect chronometer, look you.
children.prevalue: My watch A family watch monsieur which has come down from my great grandfather It doesn t vary five minutes in the year It s a perfect chronometer look you

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I see how it is, said Fix.  You have kept London time, which is two hours behind that of Suez.  You ought to regulate your watch at noon in each country.
children.prevalue: I see how it is said Fix You have kept London time which is two hours behind that of Suez You ought to regulate your watch at noon in each country

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I regulate my watch?  Never!
children.prevalue: I regulate my watch Never

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Well, then, it will not agree with the sun.
children.prevalue: Well then it will not agree with the sun

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: So much the worse for the sun, monsieur.  The sun will be wrong, then!
children.prevalue: So much the worse for the sun monsieur The sun will be wrong then

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And the worthy fellow returned the watch to its fob with a defiant gesture.  After a few minutes silence, Fix resumed: You left London hastily, then?
children.prevalue: And the worthy fellow returned the watch to its fob with a defiant gesture After a few minutes silence Fix resumed You left London hastily then

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I rather think so!  Last Friday at eight o'clock in the evening, Monsieur Fogg came home from his club, and three-quarters of an hour afterwards we were off.
children.prevalue: I rather think so Last Friday at eight o clock in the evening Monsieur Fogg came home from his club and three quarters of an hour afterwards we were off

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But where is your master going?
children.prevalue: But where is your master going

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Always straight ahead.  He is going round the world.
children.prevalue: Always straight ahead He is going round the world

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Round the world? cried Fix.
children.prevalue: Round the world cried Fix

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, and in eighty days!  He says it is on a wager; but, between us, I don't believe a word of it.  That wouldn't be common sense.  There's something else in the wind.
children.prevalue: Yes and in eighty days He says it is on a wager but between us I don t believe a word of it That wouldn t be common sense There s something else in the wind

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Ah!  Mr. Fogg is a character, is he?
children.prevalue: Ah Mr Fogg is a character is he

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I should say he was.
children.prevalue: I should say he was

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Is he rich?
children.prevalue: Is he rich

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No doubt, for he is carrying an enormous sum in brand new banknotes with him.  And he doesn't spare the money on the way, either: he has offered a large reward to the engineer of the Mongolia if he gets us to Bombay well in advance of time.
children.prevalue: No doubt for he is carrying an enormous sum in brand new banknotes with him And he doesn t spare the money on the way either he has offered a large reward to the engineer of the Mongolia if he gets us to Bombay well in advance of time

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And you have known your master a long time?
children.prevalue: And you have known your master a long time

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Why, no; I entered his service the very day we left London.
children.prevalue: Why no I entered his service the very day we left London

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The effect of these replies upon the already suspicious and excited detective may be imagined.  The hasty departure from London soon after the robbery; the large sum carried by Mr. Fogg; his eagerness to reach distant countries; the pretext of an eccentric and foolhardy bet--all confirmed Fix in his theory.  He continued to pump poor Passepartout, and learned that he really knew little or nothing of his master, who lived a solitary existence in London, was said to be rich, though no one knew whence came his riches, and was mysterious and impenetrable in his affairs and habits.  Fix felt sure that Phileas Fogg would not land at Suez, but was really going on to Bombay.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Is Bombay far from here? asked Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Is Bombay far from here asked Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Pretty far.  It is a ten days' voyage by sea.
children.prevalue: Pretty far It is a ten days voyage by sea

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And in what country is Bombay?
children.prevalue: And in what country is Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: India.
children.prevalue: India

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: In Asia?
children.prevalue: In Asia

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The deuce!  I was going to tell you there's one thing that worries me--my burner!
children.prevalue: The deuce I was going to tell you there s one thing that worries me my burner

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What burner?
children.prevalue: What burner

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: My gas-burner, which I forgot to turn off, and which is at this moment burning at my expense.  I have calculated, monsieur, that I lose two shillings every four and twenty hours, exactly sixpence more than I earn; and you will understand that the longer our journey--
children.prevalue: My gas burner which I forgot to turn off and which is at this moment burning at my expense I have calculated monsieur that I lose two shillings every four and twenty hours exactly sixpence more than I earn and you will understand that the longer our journey

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Did Fix pay any attention to Passepartout's trouble about the gas?  It is not probable.  He was not listening, but was cogitating a project. Passepartout and he had now reached the shop, where Fix left his companion to make his purchases, after recommending him not to miss the steamer, and hurried back to the consulate.  Now that he was fully convinced, Fix had quite recovered his equanimity.

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Consul, said he, I have no longer any doubt.  I have spotted my man. He passes himself off as an odd stick who is going round the world in eighty days.
children.prevalue: Consul said he I have no longer any doubt I have spotted my man He passes himself off as an odd stick who is going round the world in eighty days

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Then he's a sharp fellow, returned the consul, and counts on returning to London after putting the police of the two countries off his track.
children.prevalue: Then he s a sharp fellow returned the consul and counts on returning to London after putting the police of the two countries off his track

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: We'll see about that, replied Fix.
children.prevalue: We ll see about that replied Fix

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But are you not mistaken?
children.prevalue: But are you not mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I am not mistaken.
children.prevalue: I am not mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Why was this robber so anxious to prove, by the visa, that he had passed through Suez?
children.prevalue: Why was this robber so anxious to prove by the visa that he had passed through Suez

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Why?  I have no idea; but listen to me.
children.prevalue: Why I have no idea but listen to me

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: He reported in a few words the most important parts of his conversation with Passepartout.
children.prevalue: He reported in a few words the most important parts of his conversation with Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: In short, said the consul, appearances are wholly against this man. And what are you going to do?
children.prevalue: In short said the consul appearances are wholly against this man And what are you going to do

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Send a dispatch to London for a warrant of arrest to be dispatched instantly to Bombay, take passage on board the Mongolia, follow my rogue to India, and there, on English ground, arrest him politely, with my warrant in my hand, and my hand on his shoulder.
children.prevalue: Send a dispatch to London for a warrant of arrest to be dispatched instantly to Bombay take passage on board the Mongolia follow my rogue to India and there on English ground arrest him politely with my warrant in my hand and my hand on his shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Having uttered these words with a cool, careless air, the detective took leave of the consul, and repaired to the telegraph office, whence he sent the dispatch which we have seen to the London police office.  A quarter of an hour later found Fix, with a small bag in his hand, proceeding on board the Mongolia; and, ere many moments longer, the noble steamer rode out at full steam upon the waters of the Red Sea.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH THE RED SEA AND THE INDIAN OCEAN PROVE PROPITIOUS TO THE DESIGNS OF PHILEAS FOGG
children.prevalue: IN WHICH THE RED SEA AND THE INDIAN OCEAN PROVE PROPITIOUS TO THE DESIGNS OF PHILEAS FOGG

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The distance between Suez and Aden is precisely thirteen hundred and ten miles, and the regulations of the company allow the steamers one hundred and thirty-eight hours in which to traverse it.  The Mongolia, thanks to the vigorous exertions of the engineer, seemed likely, so rapid was her speed, to reach her destination considerably within that time.  The greater part of the passengers from Brindisi were bound for India some for Bombay, others for Calcutta by way of Bombay, the nearest route thither, now that a railway crosses the Indian peninsula. Among the passengers was a number of officials and military officers of various grades, the latter being either attached to the regular British forces or commanding the Sepoy troops, and receiving high salaries ever since the central government has assumed the powers of the East India Company: for the sub-lieutenants get 280 pounds, brigadiers, 2,400 pounds, and generals of divisions, 4,000 pounds.  What with the military men, a number of rich young Englishmen on their travels, and the hospitable efforts of the purser, the time passed quickly on the Mongolia.  The best of fare was spread upon the cabin tables at breakfast, lunch, dinner, and the eight o'clock supper, and the ladies scrupulously changed their toilets twice a day; and the hours were whirled away, when the sea was tranquil, with music, dancing, and games.
children.prevalue: The distance between Suez and Aden is precisely thirteen hundred and ten miles and the regulations of the company allow the steamers one hundred and thirty eight hours in which to traverse it The Mongolia thanks to the vigorous exertions of the engineer seemed likely so rapid was her speed to reach her destination considerably within that time The greater part of the passengers from Brindisi were bound for India some for Bombay others for Calcutta by way of Bombay the nearest route thither now that a railway crosses the Indian peninsula Among the passengers was a number of officials and military officers of various grades the latter being either attached to the regular British forces or commanding the Sepoy troops and receiving high salaries ever since the central government has assumed the powers of the East India Company for the sub lieutenants get 280 pounds brigadiers 2 400 pounds and generals of divisions 4 000 pounds What with the military men a number of rich young Englishmen on their travels and the hospitable efforts of the purser the time passed quickly on the Mongolia The best of fare was spread upon the cabin tables at breakfast lunch dinner and the eight o clock supper and the ladies scrupulously changed their toilets twice a day and the hours were whirled away when the sea was tranquil with music dancing and games

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But the Red Sea is full of caprice, and often boisterous, like most long and narrow gulfs.  When the wind came from the African or Asian coast the Mongolia, with her long hull, rolled fearfully.  Then the ladies speedily disappeared below; the pianos were silent; singing and dancing suddenly ceased.  Yet the good ship ploughed straight on, unretarded by wind or wave, towards the straits of Bab-el-Mandeb.  What was Phileas Fogg doing all this time?  It might be thought that, in his anxiety, he would be constantly watching the changes of the wind, the disorderly raging of the billows--every chance, in short, which might force the Mongolia to slacken her speed, and thus interrupt his journey.  But, if he thought of these possibilities, he did not betray the fact by any outward sign.
children.prevalue: But the Red Sea is full of caprice and often boisterous like most long and narrow gulfs When the wind came from the African or Asian coast the Mongolia with her long hull rolled fearfully Then the ladies speedily disappeared below the pianos were silent singing and dancing suddenly ceased Yet the good ship ploughed straight on unretarded by wind or wave towards the straits of Bab el Mandeb What was Phileas Fogg doing all this time It might be thought that in his anxiety he would be constantly watching the changes of the wind the disorderly raging of the billows every chance in short which might force the Mongolia to slacken her speed and thus interrupt his journey But if he thought of these possibilities he did not betray the fact by any outward sign

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Always the same impassible member of the Reform Club, whom no incident could surprise, as unvarying as the ship's chronometers, and seldom having the curiosity even to go upon the deck, he passed through the memorable scenes of the Red Sea with cold indifference; did not care to recognise the historic towns and villages which, along its borders, raised their picturesque outlines against the sky; and betrayed no fear of the dangers of the Arabic Gulf, which the old historians always spoke of with horror, and upon which the ancient navigators never ventured without propitiating the gods by ample sacrifices.  How did this eccentric personage pass his time on the Mongolia?  He made his four hearty meals every day, regardless of the most persistent rolling and pitching on the part of the steamer; and he played whist indefatigably, for he had found partners as enthusiastic in the game as himself.  A tax-collector, on the way to his post at Goa; the Rev. Decimus Smith, returning to his parish at Bombay; and a brigadier-general of the English army, who was about to rejoin his brigade at Benares, made up the party, and, with Mr. Fogg, played whist by the hour together in absorbing silence.
children.prevalue: Always the same impassible member of the Reform Club whom no incident could surprise as unvarying as the ship s chronometers and seldom having the curiosity even to go upon the deck he passed through the memorable scenes of the Red Sea with cold indifference did not care to recognise the historic towns and villages which along its borders raised their picturesque outlines against the sky and betrayed no fear of the dangers of the Arabic Gulf which the old historians always spoke of with horror and upon which the ancient navigators never ventured without propitiating the gods by ample sacrifices How did this eccentric personage pass his time on the Mongolia He made his four hearty meals every day regardless of the most persistent rolling and pitching on the part of the steamer and he played whist indefatigably for he had found partners as enthusiastic in the game as himself A tax collector on the way to his post at Goa the Rev Decimus Smith returning to his parish at Bombay and a brigadier general of the English army who was about to rejoin his brigade at Benares made up the party and with Mr Fogg played whist by the hour together in absorbing silence

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: As for Passepartout, he, too, had escaped sea-sickness, and took his meals conscientiously in the forward cabin.  He rather enjoyed the voyage, for he was well fed and well lodged, took a great interest in the scenes through which they were passing, and consoled himself with the delusion that his master's whim would end at Bombay.  He was pleased, on the day after leaving Suez, to find on deck the obliging person with whom he had walked and chatted on the quays.
children.prevalue: As for Passepartout he too had escaped sea sickness and took his meals conscientiously in the forward cabin He rather enjoyed the voyage for he was well fed and well lodged took a great interest in the scenes through which they were passing and consoled himself with the delusion that his master s whim would end at Bombay He was pleased on the day after leaving Suez to find on deck the obliging person with whom he had walked and chatted on the quays

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: If I am not mistaken, said he, approaching this person, with his most amiable smile, you are the gentleman who so kindly volunteered to guide me at Suez?
children.prevalue: If I am not mistaken said he approaching this person with his most amiable smile you are the gentleman who so kindly volunteered to guide me at Suez

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Ah!  I quite recognise you.  You are the servant of the strange Englishman--
children.prevalue: Ah I quite recognise you You are the servant of the strange Englishman

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Just so, monsieur--
children.prevalue: Just so monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Fix.
children.prevalue: Fix

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Monsieur Fix, resumed Passepartout, I'm charmed to find you on board.  Where are you bound?
children.prevalue: Monsieur Fix resumed Passepartout I m charmed to find you on board Where are you bound

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Like you, to Bombay.
children.prevalue: Like you to Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That's capital!  Have you made this trip before?
children.prevalue: That s capital Have you made this trip before

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Several times.  I am one of the agents of the Peninsular Company.
children.prevalue: Several times I am one of the agents of the Peninsular Company

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Then you know India?
children.prevalue: Then you know India

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Why yes, replied Fix, who spoke cautiously.
children.prevalue: Why yes replied Fix who spoke cautiously

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: A curious place, this India?
children.prevalue: A curious place this India

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Oh, very curious.  Mosques, minarets, temples, fakirs, pagodas, tigers, snakes, elephants!  I hope you will have ample time to see the sights.
children.prevalue: Oh very curious Mosques minarets temples fakirs pagodas tigers snakes elephants I hope you will have ample time to see the sights

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I hope so, Monsieur Fix.  You see, a man of sound sense ought not to spend his life jumping from a steamer upon a railway train, and from a railway train upon a steamer again, pretending to make the tour of the world in eighty days!  No; all these gymnastics, you may be sure, will cease at Bombay.
children.prevalue: I hope so Monsieur Fix You see a man of sound sense ought not to spend his life jumping from a steamer upon a railway train and from a railway train upon a steamer again pretending to make the tour of the world in eighty days No all these gymnastics you may be sure will cease at Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: And Mr. Fogg is getting on well? asked Fix, in the most natural tone in the world.
children.prevalue: And Mr Fogg is getting on well asked Fix in the most natural tone in the world

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Quite well, and I too.  I eat like a famished ogre; it's the sea air.
children.prevalue: Quite well and I too I eat like a famished ogre it s the sea air

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But I never see your master on deck.
children.prevalue: But I never see your master on deck

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Never; he hasn't the least curiosity.
children.prevalue: Never he hasn t the least curiosity

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Do you know, Mr. Passepartout, that this pretended tour in eighty days may conceal some secret errand--perhaps a diplomatic mission?
children.prevalue: Do you know Mr Passepartout that this pretended tour in eighty days may conceal some secret errand perhaps a diplomatic mission

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Faith, Monsieur Fix, I assure you I know nothing about it, nor would I give half a crown to find out.
children.prevalue: Faith Monsieur Fix I assure you I know nothing about it nor would I give half a crown to find out

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: After this meeting, Passepartout and Fix got into the habit of chatting together, the latter making it a point to gain the worthy man's confidence.  He frequently offered him a glass of whiskey or pale ale in the steamer bar-room, which Passepartout never failed to accept with graceful alacrity, mentally pronouncing Fix the best of good fellows.
children.prevalue: After this meeting Passepartout and Fix got into the habit of chatting together the latter making it a point to gain the worthy man s confidence He frequently offered him a glass of whiskey or pale ale in the steamer bar room which Passepartout never failed to accept with graceful alacrity mentally pronouncing Fix the best of good fellows

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Meanwhile the Mongolia was pushing forward rapidly; on the 13th, Mocha, surrounded by its ruined walls whereon date-trees were growing, was sighted, and on the mountains beyond were espied vast coffee-fields. Passepartout was ravished to behold this celebrated place, and thought that, with its circular walls and dismantled fort, it looked like an immense coffee-cup and saucer. The following night they passed through the Strait of Bab-el-Mandeb, which means in Arabic The Bridge of Tears, and the next day they put in at Steamer Point, north-west of Aden harbour, to take in coal.  This matter of fuelling steamers is a serious one at such distances from the coal-mines; it costs the Peninsular Company some eight hundred thousand pounds a year.  In these distant seas, coal is worth three or four pounds sterling a ton.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the Mongolia was pushing forward rapidly on the 13th Mocha surrounded by its ruined walls whereon date trees were growing was sighted and on the mountains beyond were espied vast coffee fields Passepartout was ravished to behold this celebrated place and thought that with its circular walls and dismantled fort it looked like an immense coffee cup and saucer The following night they passed through the Strait of Bab el Mandeb which means in Arabic The Bridge of Tears and the next day they put in at Steamer Point north west of Aden harbour to take in coal This matter of fuelling steamers is a serious one at such distances from the coal mines it costs the Peninsular Company some eight hundred thousand pounds a year In these distant seas coal is worth three or four pounds sterling a ton

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The Mongolia had still sixteen hundred and fifty miles to traverse before reaching Bombay, and was obliged to remain four hours at Steamer Point to coal up.  But this delay, as it was foreseen, did not affect Phileas Fogg's programme; besides, the Mongolia, instead of reaching Aden on the morning of the 15th, when she was due, arrived there on the evening of the 14th, a gain of fifteen hours.
children.prevalue: The Mongolia had still sixteen hundred and fifty miles to traverse before reaching Bombay and was obliged to remain four hours at Steamer Point to coal up But this delay as it was foreseen did not affect Phileas Fogg s programme besides the Mongolia instead of reaching Aden on the morning of the 15th when she was due arrived there on the evening of the 14th a gain of fifteen hours

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Mr. Fogg and his servant went ashore at Aden to have the passport again visaed; Fix, unobserved, followed them.  The visa procured, Mr. Fogg returned on board to resume his former habits; while Passepartout, according to custom, sauntered about among the mixed population of Somalis, Banyans, Parsees, Jews, Arabs, and Europeans who comprise the twenty-five thousand inhabitants of Aden.  He gazed with wonder upon the fortifications which make this place the Gibraltar of the Indian Ocean, and the vast cisterns where the English engineers were still at work, two thousand years after the engineers of Solomon.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg and his servant went ashore at Aden to have the passport again visaed Fix unobserved followed them The visa procured Mr Fogg returned on board to resume his former habits while Passepartout according to custom sauntered about among the mixed population of Somalis Banyans Parsees Jews Arabs and Europeans who comprise the twenty five thousand inhabitants of Aden He gazed with wonder upon the fortifications which make this place the Gibraltar of the Indian Ocean and the vast cisterns where the English engineers were still at work two thousand years after the engineers of Solomon

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Very curious, very curious, said Passepartout to himself, on returning to the steamer.  I see that it is by no means useless to travel, if a man wants to see something new.  At six p.m.  the Mongolia slowly moved out of the roadstead, and was soon once more on the Indian Ocean.  She had a hundred and sixty-eight hours in which to reach Bombay, and the sea was favourable, the wind being in the north-west, and all sails aiding the engine.  The steamer rolled but little, the ladies, in fresh toilets, reappeared on deck, and the singing and dancing were resumed.  The trip was being accomplished most successfully, and Passepartout was enchanted with the congenial companion which chance had secured him in the person of the delightful Fix.  On Sunday, October 20th, towards noon, they came in sight of the Indian coast: two hours later the pilot came on board.  A range of hills lay against the sky in the horizon, and soon the rows of palms which adorn Bombay came distinctly into view.  The steamer entered the road formed by the islands in the bay, and at half-past four she hauled up at the quays of Bombay.
children.prevalue: Very curious very curious said Passepartout to himself on returning to the steamer I see that it is by no means useless to travel if a man wants to see something new At six p m the Mongolia slowly moved out of the roadstead and was soon once more on the Indian Ocean She had a hundred and sixty eight hours in which to reach Bombay and the sea was favourable the wind being in the north west and all sails aiding the engine The steamer rolled but little the ladies in fresh toilets reappeared on deck and the singing and dancing were resumed The trip was being accomplished most successfully and Passepartout was enchanted with the congenial companion which chance had secured him in the person of the delightful Fix On Sunday October 20th towards noon they came in sight of the Indian coast two hours later the pilot came on board A range of hills lay against the sky in the horizon and soon the rows of palms which adorn Bombay came distinctly into view The steamer entered the road formed by the islands in the bay and at half past four she hauled up at the quays of Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Phileas Fogg was in the act of finishing the thirty-third rubber of the voyage, and his partner and himself having, by a bold stroke, captured all thirteen of the tricks, concluded this fine campaign with a brilliant victory.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg was in the act of finishing the thirty third rubber of the voyage and his partner and himself having by a bold stroke captured all thirteen of the tricks concluded this fine campaign with a brilliant victory

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The Mongolia was due at Bombay on the 22nd; she arrived on the 20th. This was a gain to Phileas Fogg of two days since his departure from London, and he calmly entered the fact in the itinerary, in the column of gains.
children.prevalue: The Mongolia was due at Bombay on the 22nd she arrived on the 20th This was a gain to Phileas Fogg of two days since his departure from London and he calmly entered the fact in the itinerary in the column of gains

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT IS ONLY TOO GLAD TO GET OFF WITH THE LOSS OF HIS SHOES
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT IS ONLY TOO GLAD TO GET OFF WITH THE LOSS OF HIS SHOES

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Everybody knows that the great reversed triangle of land, with its base in the north and its apex in the south, which is called India, embraces fourteen hundred thousand square miles, upon which is spread unequally a population of one hundred and eighty millions of souls.  The British Crown exercises a real and despotic dominion over the larger portion of this vast country, and has a governor-general stationed at Calcutta, governors at Madras, Bombay, and in Bengal, and a lieutenant-governor at Agra.
children.prevalue: Everybody knows that the great reversed triangle of land with its base in the north and its apex in the south which is called India embraces fourteen hundred thousand square miles upon which is spread unequally a population of one hundred and eighty millions of souls The British Crown exercises a real and despotic dominion over the larger portion of this vast country and has a governor general stationed at Calcutta governors at Madras Bombay and in Bengal and a lieutenant governor at Agra

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But British India, properly so called, only embraces seven hundred thousand square miles, and a population of from one hundred to one hundred and ten millions of inhabitants.  A considerable portion of India is still free from British authority; and there are certain ferocious rajahs in the interior who are absolutely independent.  The celebrated East India Company was all-powerful from 1756, when the English first gained a foothold on the spot where now stands the city of Madras, down to the time of the great Sepoy insurrection.  It gradually annexed province after province, purchasing them of the native chiefs, whom it seldom paid, and appointed the governor-general and his subordinates, civil and military.  But the East India Company has now passed away, leaving the British possessions in India directly under the control of the Crown.  The aspect of the country, as well as the manners and distinctions of race, is daily changing.
children.prevalue: But British India properly so called only embraces seven hundred thousand square miles and a population of from one hundred to one hundred and ten millions of inhabitants A considerable portion of India is still free from British authority and there are certain ferocious rajahs in the interior who are absolutely independent The celebrated East India Company was all powerful from 1756 when the English first gained a foothold on the spot where now stands the city of Madras down to the time of the great Sepoy insurrection It gradually annexed province after province purchasing them of the native chiefs whom it seldom paid and appointed the governor general and his subordinates civil and military But the East India Company has now passed away leaving the British possessions in India directly under the control of the Crown The aspect of the country as well as the manners and distinctions of race is daily changing

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Formerly one was obliged to travel in India by the old cumbrous methods of going on foot or on horseback, in palanquins or unwieldy coaches; now fast steamboats ply on the Indus and the Ganges, and a great railway, with branch lines joining the main line at many points on its route, traverses the peninsula from Bombay to Calcutta in three days. This railway does not run in a direct line across India.  The distance between Bombay and Calcutta, as the bird flies, is only from one thousand to eleven hundred miles; but the deflections of the road increase this distance by more than a third.
children.prevalue: Formerly one was obliged to travel in India by the old cumbrous methods of going on foot or on horseback in palanquins or unwieldy coaches now fast steamboats ply on the Indus and the Ganges and a great railway with branch lines joining the main line at many points on its route traverses the peninsula from Bombay to Calcutta in three days This railway does not run in a direct line across India The distance between Bombay and Calcutta as the bird flies is only from one thousand to eleven hundred miles but the deflections of the road increase this distance by more than a third

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The general route of the Great Indian Peninsula Railway is as follows: Leaving Bombay, it passes through Salcette, crossing to the continent opposite Tannah, goes over the chain of the Western Ghauts, runs thence north-east as far as Burhampoor, skirts the nearly independent territory of Bundelcund, ascends to Allahabad, turns thence eastwardly, meeting the Ganges at Benares, then departs from the river a little, and, descending south-eastward by Burdivan and the French town of Chandernagor, has its terminus at Calcutta.
children.prevalue: The general route of the Great Indian Peninsula Railway is as follows Leaving Bombay it passes through Salcette crossing to the continent opposite Tannah goes over the chain of the Western Ghauts runs thence north east as far as Burhampoor skirts the nearly independent territory of Bundelcund ascends to Allahabad turns thence eastwardly meeting the Ganges at Benares then departs from the river a little and descending south eastward by Burdivan and the French town of Chandernagor has its terminus at Calcutta

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The passengers of the Mongolia went ashore at half-past four p.m.; at exactly eight the train would start for Calcutta.
children.prevalue: The passengers of the Mongolia went ashore at half past four p m at exactly eight the train would start for Calcutta

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Mr. Fogg, after bidding good-bye to his whist partners, left the steamer, gave his servant several errands to do, urged it upon him to be at the station promptly at eight, and, with his regular step, which beat to the second, like an astronomical clock, directed his steps to the passport office.  As for the wonders of Bombay--its famous city hall, its splendid library, its forts and docks, its bazaars, mosques, synagogues, its Armenian churches, and the noble pagoda on Malabar Hill, with its two polygonal towers--he cared not a straw to see them. He would not deign to examine even the masterpieces of Elephanta, or the mysterious hypogea, concealed south-east from the docks, or those fine remains of Buddhist architecture, the Kanherian grottoes of the island of Salcette.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg after bidding good bye to his whist partners left the steamer gave his servant several errands to do urged it upon him to be at the station promptly at eight and with his regular step which beat to the second like an astronomical clock directed his steps to the passport office As for the wonders of Bombay its famous city hall its splendid library its forts and docks its bazaars mosques synagogues its Armenian churches and the noble pagoda on Malabar Hill with its two polygonal towers he cared not a straw to see them He would not deign to examine even the masterpieces of Elephanta or the mysterious hypogea concealed south east from the docks or those fine remains of Buddhist architecture the Kanherian grottoes of the island of Salcette

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Having transacted his business at the passport office, Phileas Fogg repaired quietly to the railway station, where he ordered dinner. Among the dishes served up to him, the landlord especially recommended a certain giblet of native rabbit, on which he prided himself.
children.prevalue: Having transacted his business at the passport office Phileas Fogg repaired quietly to the railway station where he ordered dinner Among the dishes served up to him the landlord especially recommended a certain giblet of native rabbit on which he prided himself

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Mr. Fogg accordingly tasted the dish, but, despite its spiced sauce, found it far from palatable.  He rang for the landlord, and, on his appearance, said, fixing his clear eyes upon him, Is this rabbit, sir?
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg accordingly tasted the dish but despite its spiced sauce found it far from palatable He rang for the landlord and on his appearance said fixing his clear eyes upon him Is this rabbit sir

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, my lord, the rogue boldly replied, rabbit from the jungles.
children.prevalue: Yes my lord the rogue boldly replied rabbit from the jungles

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And this rabbit did not mew when he was killed?
children.prevalue: And this rabbit did not mew when he was killed

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Mew, my lord!  What, a rabbit mew!  I swear to you--
children.prevalue: Mew my lord What a rabbit mew I swear to you

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Be so good, landlord, as not to swear, but remember this: cats were formerly considered, in India, as sacred animals.  That was a good time.
children.prevalue: Be so good landlord as not to swear but remember this cats were formerly considered in India as sacred animals That was a good time

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: For the cats, my lord?
children.prevalue: For the cats my lord

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Perhaps for the travellers as well!
children.prevalue: Perhaps for the travellers as well

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: After which Mr. Fogg quietly continued his dinner.  Fix had gone on shore shortly after Mr. Fogg, and his first destination was the headquarters of the Bombay police.  He made himself known as a London detective, told his business at Bombay, and the position of affairs relative to the supposed robber, and nervously asked if a warrant had arrived from London.  It had not reached the office; indeed, there had not yet been time for it to arrive.  Fix was sorely disappointed, and tried to obtain an order of arrest from the director of the Bombay police.  This the director refused, as the matter concerned the London office, which alone could legally deliver the warrant.  Fix did not insist, and was fain to resign himself to await the arrival of the important document; but he was determined not to lose sight of the mysterious rogue as long as he stayed in Bombay.  He did not doubt for a moment, any more than Passepartout, that Phileas Fogg would remain there, at least until it was time for the warrant to arrive.

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Passepartout, however, had no sooner heard his master's orders on leaving the Mongolia than he saw at once that they were to leave Bombay as they had done Suez and Paris, and that the journey would be extended at least as far as Calcutta, and perhaps beyond that place.  He began to ask himself if this bet that Mr. Fogg talked about was not really in good earnest, and whether his fate was not in truth forcing him, despite his love of repose, around the world in eighty days!
children.prevalue: Passepartout however had no sooner heard his master s orders on leaving the Mongolia than he saw at once that they were to leave Bombay as they had done Suez and Paris and that the journey would be extended at least as far as Calcutta and perhaps beyond that place He began to ask himself if this bet that Mr Fogg talked about was not really in good earnest and whether his fate was not in truth forcing him despite his love of repose around the world in eighty days

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Having purchased the usual quota of shirts and shoes, he took a leisurely promenade about the streets, where crowds of people of many nationalities--Europeans, Persians with pointed caps, Banyas with round turbans, Sindes with square bonnets, Parsees with black mitres, and long-robed Armenians--were collected.  It happened to be the day of a Parsee festival.  These descendants of the sect of Zoroaster--the most thrifty, civilised, intelligent, and austere of the East Indians, among whom are counted the richest native merchants of Bombay--were celebrating a sort of religious carnival, with processions and shows, in the midst of which Indian dancing-girls, clothed in rose-coloured gauze, looped up with gold and silver, danced airily, but with perfect modesty, to the sound of viols and the clanging of tambourines.  It is needless to say that Passepartout watched these curious ceremonies with staring eyes and gaping mouth, and that his countenance was that of the greenest booby imaginable.
children.prevalue: Having purchased the usual quota of shirts and shoes he took a leisurely promenade about the streets where crowds of people of many nationalities Europeans Persians with pointed caps Banyas with round turbans Sindes with square bonnets Parsees with black mitres and long robed Armenians were collected It happened to be the day of a Parsee festival These descendants of the sect of Zoroaster the most thrifty civilised intelligent and austere of the East Indians among whom are counted the richest native merchants of Bombay were celebrating a sort of religious carnival with processions and shows in the midst of which Indian dancing girls clothed in rose coloured gauze looped up with gold and silver danced airily but with perfect modesty to the sound of viols and the clanging of tambourines It is needless to say that Passepartout watched these curious ceremonies with staring eyes and gaping mouth and that his countenance was that of the greenest booby imaginable

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Unhappily for his master, as well as himself, his curiosity drew him unconsciously farther off than he intended to go.  At last, having seen the Parsee carnival wind away in the distance, he was turning his steps towards the station, when he happened to espy the splendid pagoda on Malabar Hill, and was seized with an irresistible desire to see its interior.  He was quite ignorant that it is forbidden to Christians to enter certain Indian temples, and that even the faithful must not go in without first leaving their shoes outside the door.  It may be said here that the wise policy of the British Government severely punishes a disregard of the practices of the native religions.
children.prevalue: Unhappily for his master as well as himself his curiosity drew him unconsciously farther off than he intended to go At last having seen the Parsee carnival wind away in the distance he was turning his steps towards the station when he happened to espy the splendid pagoda on Malabar Hill and was seized with an irresistible desire to see its interior He was quite ignorant that it is forbidden to Christians to enter certain Indian temples and that even the faithful must not go in without first leaving their shoes outside the door It may be said here that the wise policy of the British Government severely punishes a disregard of the practices of the native religions

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Passepartout, however, thinking no harm, went in like a simple tourist, and was soon lost in admiration of the splendid Brahmin ornamentation which everywhere met his eyes, when of a sudden he found himself sprawling on the sacred flagging.  He looked up to behold three enraged priests, who forthwith fell upon him; tore off his shoes, and began to beat him with loud, savage exclamations.  The agile Frenchman was soon upon his feet again, and lost no time in knocking down two of his long-gowned adversaries with his fists and a vigorous application of his toes; then, rushing out of the pagoda as fast as his legs could carry him, he soon escaped the third priest by mingling with the crowd in the streets.

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At five minutes before eight, Passepartout, hatless, shoeless, and having in the squabble lost his package of shirts and shoes, rushed breathlessly into the station.
children.prevalue: At five minutes before eight Passepartout hatless shoeless and having in the squabble lost his package of shirts and shoes rushed breathlessly into the station

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Fix, who had followed Mr. Fogg to the station, and saw that he was really going to leave Bombay, was there, upon the platform.  He had resolved to follow the supposed robber to Calcutta, and farther, if necessary.  Passepartout did not observe the detective, who stood in an obscure corner; but Fix heard him relate his adventures in a few words to Mr. Fogg.

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I hope that this will not happen again, said Phileas Fogg coldly, as he got into the train.  Poor Passepartout, quite crestfallen, followed his master without a word.  Fix was on the point of entering another carriage, when an idea struck him which induced him to alter his plan.

children.value: No, I'll stay, muttered he.  An offence has been committed on Indian soil.  I've got my man.

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Just then the locomotive gave a sharp screech, and the train passed out into the darkness of the night.
