Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula.  The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma's agency, it descends to the earth.
children.prevalue: The young woman was placed in one of the waiting rooms of the station whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet a dress shawl and some furs for which his master gave him unlimited credit Passepartout started off forthwith and found himself in the streets of Allahabad that is the City of God one of the most venerated in India being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers Ganges and Jumna the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula The Ganges according to the legends of the Ramayana rises in heaven whence owing to Brahma s agency it descends to the earth

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city.  It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street.  At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds.  He then returned triumphantly to the station.
children.prevalue: Passepartout made it a point as he made his purchases to take a good look at the city It was formerly defended by a noble fort which has since become a state prison its commerce has dwindled away and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street At last he came upon an elderly crusty Jew who sold second hand articles and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff a large mantle and a fine otter skin pelisse for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy five pounds He then returned triumphantly to the station

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
children.prevalue: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield and she became more herself so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
children.prevalue: When the poet king Ucaf Uddaul celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara he speaks thus

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness.  Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes.  Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower's half-enveloped breast.  Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda.  Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.
children.prevalue: Her shining tresses divided in two parts encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks brilliant in their glow and freshness Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama the god of love and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya in the black pupils of her great clear eyes Her teeth fine equal and white glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion flower s half enveloped breast Her delicately formed ears her vermilion hands her little feet curved and tender as the lotus bud glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda Her narrow and supple waist which a hand may clasp around sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma the immortal sculptor

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase.  She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
children.prevalue: It is enough to say without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda that she was a charming woman in all the European acceptation of the phrase She spoke English with great purity and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide's devotion.  He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance.  Kiouni, also, must be disposed of.  What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased?  Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
children.prevalue: The train was about to start from Allahabad and Mr Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service and not a farthing more which astonished Passepartout who remembered all that his master owed to the guide s devotion He had indeed risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji and if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians he would with difficulty escape their vengeance Kiouni also must be disposed of What should be done with the elephant which had been so dearly purchased Phileas Fogg had already determined this question

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Parsee, said he to the guide, you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion.  Would you like to have this elephant?  He is yours.
children.prevalue: Parsee said he to the guide you have been serviceable and devoted I have paid for your service but not for your devotion Would you like to have this elephant He is yours

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The guide's eyes glistened.
children.prevalue: The guide s eyes glistened

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Your honour is giving me a fortune! cried he.
children.prevalue: Your honour is giving me a fortune cried he

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Take him, guide, returned Mr. Fogg, and I shall still be your debtor.
children.prevalue: Take him guide returned Mr Fogg and I shall still be your debtor

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Good! exclaimed Passepartout.  Take him, friend.  Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.  And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, Here, Kiouni, here, here.
children.prevalue: Good exclaimed Passepartout Take him friend Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast And going up to the elephant he gave him several lumps of sugar saying Here Kiouni here here

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.
children.prevalue: The elephant grunted out his satisfaction and clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk lifted him as high as his head Passepartout not in the least alarmed caressed the animal which replaced him gently on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares.  It was a run of eighty miles, and was accomplished in two hours.  During the journey, the young woman fully recovered her senses.  What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage, on the railway, dressed in European habiliments, and with travellers who were quite strangers to her!  Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor, and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed, dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her, and recounting the happy sequel of the venture, the result of Passepartout's rash idea.  Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that it wasn't worth telling.
children.prevalue: Soon after Phileas Fogg Sir Francis Cromarty and Passepartout installed in a carriage with Aouda who had the best seat were whirling at full speed towards Benares It was a run of eighty miles and was accomplished in two hours During the journey the young woman fully recovered her senses What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage on the railway dressed in European habiliments and with travellers who were quite strangers to her Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her and recounting the happy sequel of the venture the result of Passepartout s rash idea Mr Fogg said nothing while Passepartout abashed kept repeating that it wasn t worth telling

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice, and recalled the dangers which still menaced her, she shuddered with terror.
children.prevalue: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers rather with tears than words her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips Then as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice and recalled the dangers which still menaced her she shuddered with terror

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda's mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up--an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted.  She had, it seems, a Parsee relation, who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is wholly an English city, though on an island on the Chinese coast.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda s mind and offered in order to reassure her to escort her to Hong Kong where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted She had it seems a Parsee relation who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong which is wholly an English city though on an island on the Chinese coast

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares.  The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet's tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth, Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving an aspect of desolation to the place, as the train entered it.
children.prevalue: At half past twelve the train stopped at Benares The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi which like Mahomet s tomb was once suspended between heaven and earth though the Benares of to day which the Orientalists call the Athens of India stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts giving an aspect of desolation to the place as the train entered it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty's destination, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city.  He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.  Mr. Fogg lightly pressed him by the hand.  The parting of Aouda, who did not forget what she owed to Sir Francis, betrayed more warmth; and, as for Passepartout, he received a hearty shake of the hand from the gallant general.
children.prevalue: Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty s destination the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg wishing him all success and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion Mr Fogg lightly pressed him by the hand The parting of Aouda who did not forget what she owed to Sir Francis betrayed more warmth and as for Passepartout he received a hearty shake of the hand from the gallant general

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges.  Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests.  Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions.  These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators.  What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
children.prevalue: The railway on leaving Benares passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar with its mountains clothed in verdure its fields of barley wheat and corn its jungles peopled with green alligators its neat villages and its still thickly leaved forests Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river and groups of Indians despite the advanced season and chilly air were performing solemnly their pious ablutions These were fervent Brahmins the bitterest foes of Buddhism their deities being Vishnu the solar god Shiva the divine impersonation of natural forces and Brahma the supreme ruler of priests and legislators What would these divinities think of India anglicised as it is to day with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges frightening the gulls which float upon its surface the turtles swarming along its banks and the faithful dwelling upon its borders

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
children.prevalue: The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie twenty miles south westward from Benares the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar or Ghazipur and its famous rose water factories or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis rising on the left bank of the Ganges the fortified town of Buxar or Patna a large manufacturing and trading place where is held the principal opium market of India or Monghir a more than European town for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham with its iron foundries edgetool factories and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country's flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
children.prevalue: Night came on the train passed on at full speed in the midst of the roaring of the tigers bears and wolves which fled before the locomotive and the marvels of Bengal Golconda ruined Gour Murshedabad the ancient capital Burdwan Hugly and the French town of Chandernagor where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country s flag flying were hidden from their view in the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
children.prevalue: Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival.  He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time.  The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India.  But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.
children.prevalue: According to his journal he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October and that was the exact date of his actual arrival He was therefore neither behind hand nor ahead of time The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost as has been seen in the journey across India But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage.  He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
children.prevalue: The train entered the station and Passepartout jumping out first was followed by Mr Fogg who assisted his fair companion to descend Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, Mr. Phileas Fogg?
children.prevalue: Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him and said Mr Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I am he.
children.prevalue: I am he

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Is this man your servant? added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Is this man your servant added the policeman pointing to Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.
children.prevalue: Be so good both of you as to follow me

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever.  The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever The policeman was a representative of the law and law is sacred to an Englishman Passepartout tried to reason about the matter but the policeman tapped him with his stick and Mr Fogg made him a signal to obey

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: May this young lady go with us? asked he.
children.prevalue: May this young lady go with us asked he

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: She may, replied the policeman.
children.prevalue: She may replied the policeman

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away.  No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination.  They first passed through the black town, with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the European town, which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg Aouda and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri a sort of four wheeled carriage drawn by two horses in which they took their places and were driven away No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination They first passed through the black town with its narrow streets its miserable dirty huts and squalid population then through the European town which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions shaded by coconut trees and bristling with masts where although it was early morning elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion.  The policeman having requested his prisoners--for so, truly, they might be called--to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said:  You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.
children.prevalue: The carriage stopped before a modest looking house which however did not have the appearance of a private mansion The policeman having requested his prisoners for so truly they might be called to descend conducted them into a room with barred windows and said You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half past eight

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He then retired, and closed the door.
children.prevalue: He then retired and closed the door

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Why, we are prisoners! exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
children.prevalue: Why we are prisoners exclaimed Passepartout falling into a chair

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: Sir, you must leave me to my fate!  It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!
children.prevalue: Aouda with an emotion she tried to conceal said to Mr Fogg Sir you must leave me to my fate It is on my account that you receive this treatment it is for having saved me

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible.  It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake.  Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge There was some mistake Moreover he would not in any event abandon Aouda but would escort her to Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But the steamer leaves at noon! observed Passepartout, nervously.
children.prevalue: But the steamer leaves at noon observed Passepartout nervously

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: We shall be on board by noon, replied his master, placidly.
children.prevalue: We shall be on board by noon replied his master placidly

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, Parbleu that's certain!  Before noon we shall be on board. But he was by no means reassured.
children.prevalue: It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself Parbleu that s certain Before noon we shall be on board But he was by no means reassured

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall.  It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
children.prevalue: At half past eight the door opened the policeman appeared and requesting them to follow him led the way to an adjoining hall It was evidently a court room and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk.  Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered.  He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk Immediately after Judge Obadiah a fat round man followed by the clerk entered He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail and put it hurriedly on his head

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The first case, said he.  Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, Heh!  This is not my wig!
children.prevalue: The first case said he Then putting his hand to his head he exclaimed Heh This is not my wig

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: No, your worship, returned the clerk, it is mine.
children.prevalue: No your worship returned the clerk it is mine

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk's wig?
children.prevalue: My dear Mr Oysterpuff how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk s wig

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The wigs were exchanged.
children.prevalue: The wigs were exchanged

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was getting nervous for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The first case, repeated Judge Obadiah.
children.prevalue: The first case repeated Judge Obadiah

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Phileas Fogg? demanded Oysterpuff.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg demanded Oysterpuff

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I am here, replied Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: I am here replied Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Passepartout?
children.prevalue: Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Present, responded Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Present responded Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Good, said the judge.  You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.
children.prevalue: Good said the judge You have been looked for prisoners for two days on the trains from Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But of what are we accused? asked Passepartout, impatiently.
children.prevalue: But of what are we accused asked Passepartout impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You are about to be informed.
children.prevalue: You are about to be informed

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I am an English subject, sir, said Mr. Fogg, and I have the right--
children.prevalue: I am an English subject sir said Mr Fogg and I have the right

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Have you been ill-treated?
children.prevalue: Have you been ill treated

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Not at all.
children.prevalue: Not at all

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very well; let the complainants come in.
children.prevalue: Very well let the complainants come in

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
children.prevalue: A door was swung open by order of the judge and three Indian priests entered

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: That's it, muttered Passepartout; these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady.
children.prevalue: That s it muttered Passepartout these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The priests took their places in front of the judge, and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant, who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion.
children.prevalue: The priests took their places in front of the judge and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You hear the charge? asked the judge.
children.prevalue: You hear the charge asked the judge

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, sir, replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, and I admit it.
children.prevalue: Yes sir replied Mr Fogg consulting his watch and I admit it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: You admit it?
children.prevalue: You admit it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I admit it, and I wish to hear these priests admit, in their turn, what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji.
children.prevalue: I admit it and I wish to hear these priests admit in their turn what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The priests looked at each other; they did not seem to understand what was said.
children.prevalue: The priests looked at each other they did not seem to understand what was said

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Yes, cried Passepartout, warmly; at the pagoda of Pillaji, where they were on the point of burning their victim.
children.prevalue: Yes cried Passepartout warmly at the pagoda of Pillaji where they were on the point of burning their victim

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The judge stared with astonishment, and the priests were stupefied.
children.prevalue: The judge stared with astonishment and the priests were stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What victim? said Judge Obadiah.  Burn whom?  In Bombay itself?
children.prevalue: What victim said Judge Obadiah Burn whom In Bombay itself

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Bombay? cried Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Bombay cried Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Certainly.  We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji, but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay.
children.prevalue: Certainly We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill at Bombay

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And as a proof, added the clerk, here are the desecrator's very shoes, which he left behind him.
children.prevalue: And as a proof added the clerk here are the desecrator s very shoes which he left behind him

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.
children.prevalue: Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: My shoes! cried Passepartout, in his surprise permitting this imprudent exclamation to escape him.
children.prevalue: My shoes cried Passepartout in his surprise permitting this imprudent exclamation to escape him

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The confusion of master and man, who had quite forgotten the affair at Bombay, for which they were now detained at Calcutta, may be imagined.
children.prevalue: The confusion of master and man who had quite forgotten the affair at Bombay for which they were now detained at Calcutta may be imagined

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Fix the detective, had foreseen the advantage which Passepartout's escapade gave him, and, delaying his departure for twelve hours, had consulted the priests of Malabar Hill.  Knowing that the English authorities dealt very severely with this kind of misdemeanour, he promised them a goodly sum in damages, and sent them forward to Calcutta by the next train.  Owing to the delay caused by the rescue of the young widow, Fix and the priests reached the Indian capital before Mr. Fogg and his servant, the magistrates having been already warned by a dispatch to arrest them should they arrive.  Fix's disappointment when he learned that Phileas Fogg had not made his appearance in Calcutta may be imagined.  He made up his mind that the robber had stopped somewhere on the route and taken refuge in the southern provinces.  For twenty-four hours Fix watched the station with feverish anxiety; at last he was rewarded by seeing Mr. Fogg and Passepartout arrive, accompanied by a young woman, whose presence he was wholly at a loss to explain.  He hastened for a policeman; and this was how the party came to be arrested and brought before Judge Obadiah.
children.prevalue: Fix the detective had foreseen the advantage which Passepartout s escapade gave him and delaying his departure for twelve hours had consulted the priests of Malabar Hill Knowing that the English authorities dealt very severely with this kind of misdemeanour he promised them a goodly sum in damages and sent them forward to Calcutta by the next train Owing to the delay caused by the rescue of the young widow Fix and the priests reached the Indian capital before Mr Fogg and his servant the magistrates having been already warned by a dispatch to arrest them should they arrive Fix s disappointment when he learned that Phileas Fogg had not made his appearance in Calcutta may be imagined He made up his mind that the robber had stopped somewhere on the route and taken refuge in the southern provinces For twenty four hours Fix watched the station with feverish anxiety at last he was rewarded by seeing Mr Fogg and Passepartout arrive accompanied by a young woman whose presence he was wholly at a loss to explain He hastened for a policeman and this was how the party came to be arrested and brought before Judge Obadiah

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied, he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court-room, watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood; for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta, as it had done at Bombay and Suez.
children.prevalue: Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court room watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta as it had done at Bombay and Suez

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Judge Obadiah had unfortunately caught Passepartout's rash exclamation, which the poor fellow would have given the world to recall.
children.prevalue: Judge Obadiah had unfortunately caught Passepartout s rash exclamation which the poor fellow would have given the world to recall

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The facts are admitted? asked the judge.
children.prevalue: The facts are admitted asked the judge

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Admitted, replied Mr. Fogg, coldly.
children.prevalue: Admitted replied Mr Fogg coldly

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Inasmuch, resumed the judge, as the English law protects equally and sternly the religions of the Indian people, and as the man Passepartout has admitted that he violated the sacred pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay, on the 20th of October, I condemn the said Passepartout to imprisonment for fifteen days and a fine of three hundred pounds.
children.prevalue: Inasmuch resumed the judge as the English law protects equally and sternly the religions of the Indian people and as the man Passepartout has admitted that he violated the sacred pagoda of Malabar Hill at Bombay on the 20th of October I condemn the said Passepartout to imprisonment for fifteen days and a fine of three hundred pounds

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Three hundred pounds! cried Passepartout, startled at the largeness of the sum.
children.prevalue: Three hundred pounds cried Passepartout startled at the largeness of the sum

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Silence! shouted the constable.
children.prevalue: Silence shouted the constable

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And inasmuch, continued the judge, as it is not proved that the act was not done by the connivance of the master with the servant, and as the master in any case must be held responsible for the acts of his paid servant, I condemn Phileas Fogg to a week's imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds.
children.prevalue: And inasmuch continued the judge as it is not proved that the act was not done by the connivance of the master with the servant and as the master in any case must be held responsible for the acts of his paid servant I condemn Phileas Fogg to a week s imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Fix rubbed his hands softly with satisfaction; if Phileas Fogg could be detained in Calcutta a week, it would be more than time for the warrant to arrive.  Passepartout was stupefied.  This sentence ruined his master.  A wager of twenty thousand pounds lost, because he, like a precious fool, had gone into that abominable pagoda!
children.prevalue: Fix rubbed his hands softly with satisfaction if Phileas Fogg could be detained in Calcutta a week it would be more than time for the warrant to arrive Passepartout was stupefied This sentence ruined his master A wager of twenty thousand pounds lost because he like a precious fool had gone into that abominable pagoda

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Phileas Fogg, as self-composed as if the judgment did not in the least concern him, did not even lift his eyebrows while it was being pronounced.  Just as the clerk was calling the next case, he rose, and said, I offer bail.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg as self composed as if the judgment did not in the least concern him did not even lift his eyebrows while it was being pronounced Just as the clerk was calling the next case he rose and said I offer bail

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: You have that right, returned the judge.
children.prevalue: You have that right returned the judge

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Fix's blood ran cold, but he resumed his composure when he heard the judge announce that the bail required for each prisoner would be one thousand pounds.
children.prevalue: Fix s blood ran cold but he resumed his composure when he heard the judge announce that the bail required for each prisoner would be one thousand pounds

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I will pay it at once, said Mr. Fogg, taking a roll of bank-bills from the carpet-bag, which Passepartout had by him, and placing them on the clerk's desk.
children.prevalue: I will pay it at once said Mr Fogg taking a roll of bank bills from the carpet bag which Passepartout had by him and placing them on the clerk s desk

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: This sum will be restored to you upon your release from prison, said the judge.  Meanwhile, you are liberated on bail.
children.prevalue: This sum will be restored to you upon your release from prison said the judge Meanwhile you are liberated on bail

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Come! said Phileas Fogg to his servant.
children.prevalue: Come said Phileas Fogg to his servant

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: But let them at least give me back my shoes! cried Passepartout angrily.
children.prevalue: But let them at least give me back my shoes cried Passepartout angrily

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Ah, these are pretty dear shoes! he muttered, as they were handed to him.  More than a thousand pounds apiece; besides, they pinch my feet.
children.prevalue: Ah these are pretty dear shoes he muttered as they were handed to him More than a thousand pounds apiece besides they pinch my feet

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Mr. Fogg, offering his arm to Aouda, then departed, followed by the crestfallen Passepartout.  Fix still nourished hopes that the robber would not, after all, leave the two thousand pounds behind him, but would decide to serve out his week in jail, and issued forth on Mr. Fogg's traces.  That gentleman took a carriage, and the party were soon landed on one of the quays.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg offering his arm to Aouda then departed followed by the crestfallen Passepartout Fix still nourished hopes that the robber would not after all leave the two thousand pounds behind him but would decide to serve out his week in jail and issued forth on Mr Fogg s traces That gentleman took a carriage and the party were soon landed on one of the quays

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The Rangoon was moored half a mile off in the harbour, its signal of departure hoisted at the mast-head.  Eleven o'clock was striking; Mr. Fogg was an hour in advance of time.  Fix saw them leave the carriage and push off in a boat for the steamer, and stamped his feet with disappointment.
children.prevalue: The Rangoon was moored half a mile off in the harbour its signal of departure hoisted at the mast head Eleven o clock was striking Mr Fogg was an hour in advance of time Fix saw them leave the carriage and push off in a boat for the steamer and stamped his feet with disappointment

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The rascal is off, after all! he exclaimed.  Two thousand pounds sacrificed!  He's as prodigal as a thief!  I'll follow him to the end of the world if necessary; but, at the rate he is going on, the stolen money will soon be exhausted.
children.prevalue: The rascal is off after all he exclaimed Two thousand pounds sacrificed He s as prodigal as a thief I ll follow him to the end of the world if necessary but at the rate he is going on the stolen money will soon be exhausted

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The detective was not far wrong in making this conjecture.  Since leaving London, what with travelling expenses, bribes, the purchase of the elephant, bails, and fines, Mr. Fogg had already spent more than five thousand pounds on the way, and the percentage of the sum recovered from the bank robber promised to the detectives, was rapidly diminishing.
children.prevalue: The detective was not far wrong in making this conjecture Since leaving London what with travelling expenses bribes the purchase of the elephant bails and fines Mr Fogg had already spent more than five thousand pounds on the way and the percentage of the sum recovered from the bank robber promised to the detectives was rapidly diminishing

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH FIX DOES NOT SEEM TO UNDERSTAND IN THE LEAST WHAT IS SAID TO HIM
children.prevalue: IN WHICH FIX DOES NOT SEEM TO UNDERSTAND IN THE LEAST WHAT IS SAID TO HIM

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The Rangoon--one of the Peninsular and Oriental Company's boats plying in the Chinese and Japanese seas--was a screw steamer, built of iron, weighing about seventeen hundred and seventy tons, and with engines of four hundred horse-power.  She was as fast, but not as well fitted up, as the Mongolia, and Aouda was not as comfortably provided for on board of her as Phileas Fogg could have wished.  However, the trip from Calcutta to Hong Kong only comprised some three thousand five hundred miles, occupying from ten to twelve days, and the young woman was not difficult to please.
children.prevalue: The Rangoon one of the Peninsular and Oriental Company s boats plying in the Chinese and Japanese seas was a screw steamer built of iron weighing about seventeen hundred and seventy tons and with engines of four hundred horse power She was as fast but not as well fitted up as the Mongolia and Aouda was not as comfortably provided for on board of her as Phileas Fogg could have wished However the trip from Calcutta to Hong Kong only comprised some three thousand five hundred miles occupying from ten to twelve days and the young woman was not difficult to please

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: During the first days of the journey Aouda became better acquainted with her protector, and constantly gave evidence of her deep gratitude for what he had done.  The phlegmatic gentleman listened to her, apparently at least, with coldness, neither his voice nor his manner betraying the slightest emotion; but he seemed to be always on the watch that nothing should be wanting to Aouda's comfort.  He visited her regularly each day at certain hours, not so much to talk himself, as to sit and hear her talk.  He treated her with the strictest politeness, but with the precision of an automaton, the movements of which had been arranged for this purpose.  Aouda did not quite know what to make of him, though Passepartout had given her some hints of his master's eccentricity, and made her smile by telling her of the wager which was sending him round the world.  After all, she owed Phileas Fogg her life, and she always regarded him through the exalting medium of her gratitude.
children.prevalue: During the first days of the journey Aouda became better acquainted with her protector and constantly gave evidence of her deep gratitude for what he had done The phlegmatic gentleman listened to her apparently at least with coldness neither his voice nor his manner betraying the slightest emotion but he seemed to be always on the watch that nothing should be wanting to Aouda s comfort He visited her regularly each day at certain hours not so much to talk himself as to sit and hear her talk He treated her with the strictest politeness but with the precision of an automaton the movements of which had been arranged for this purpose Aouda did not quite know what to make of him though Passepartout had given her some hints of his master s eccentricity and made her smile by telling her of the wager which was sending him round the world After all she owed Phileas Fogg her life and she always regarded him through the exalting medium of her gratitude

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Aouda confirmed the Parsee guide's narrative of her touching history. She did, indeed, belong to the highest of the native races of India. Many of the Parsee merchants have made great fortunes there by dealing in cotton; and one of them, Sir Jametsee Jeejeebhoy, was made a baronet by the English government.  Aouda was a relative of this great man, and it was his cousin, Jeejeeh, whom she hoped to join at Hong Kong. Whether she would find a protector in him she could not tell; but Mr. Fogg essayed to calm her anxieties, and to assure her that everything would be mathematically--he used the very word--arranged.  Aouda fastened her great eyes, clear as the sacred lakes of the Himalaya, upon him; but the intractable Fogg, as reserved as ever, did not seem at all inclined to throw himself into this lake.
children.prevalue: Aouda confirmed the Parsee guide s narrative of her touching history She did indeed belong to the highest of the native races of India Many of the Parsee merchants have made great fortunes there by dealing in cotton and one of them Sir Jametsee Jeejeebhoy was made a baronet by the English government Aouda was a relative of this great man and it was his cousin Jeejeeh whom she hoped to join at Hong Kong Whether she would find a protector in him she could not tell but Mr Fogg essayed to calm her anxieties and to assure her that everything would be mathematically he used the very word arranged Aouda fastened her great eyes clear as the sacred lakes of the Himalaya upon him but the intractable Fogg as reserved as ever did not seem at all inclined to throw himself into this lake

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The first few days of the voyage passed prosperously, amid favourable weather and propitious winds, and they soon came in sight of the great Andaman, the principal of the islands in the Bay of Bengal, with its picturesque Saddle Peak, two thousand four hundred feet high, looming above the waters.  The steamer passed along near the shores, but the savage Papuans, who are in the lowest scale of humanity, but are not, as has been asserted, cannibals, did not make their appearance.
children.prevalue: The first few days of the voyage passed prosperously amid favourable weather and propitious winds and they soon came in sight of the great Andaman the principal of the islands in the Bay of Bengal with its picturesque Saddle Peak two thousand four hundred feet high looming above the waters The steamer passed along near the shores but the savage Papuans who are in the lowest scale of humanity but are not as has been asserted cannibals did not make their appearance

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The panorama of the islands, as they steamed by them, was superb.  Vast forests of palms, arecs, bamboo, teakwood, of the gigantic mimosa, and tree-like ferns covered the foreground, while behind, the graceful outlines of the mountains were traced against the sky; and along the coasts swarmed by thousands the precious swallows whose nests furnish a luxurious dish to the tables of the Celestial Empire.  The varied landscape afforded by the Andaman Islands was soon passed, however, and the Rangoon rapidly approached the Straits of Malacca, which gave access to the China seas.
children.prevalue: The panorama of the islands as they steamed by them was superb Vast forests of palms arecs bamboo teakwood of the gigantic mimosa and tree like ferns covered the foreground while behind the graceful outlines of the mountains were traced against the sky and along the coasts swarmed by thousands the precious swallows whose nests furnish a luxurious dish to the tables of the Celestial Empire The varied landscape afforded by the Andaman Islands was soon passed however and the Rangoon rapidly approached the Straits of Malacca which gave access to the China seas

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What was detective Fix, so unluckily drawn on from country to country, doing all this while?  He had managed to embark on the Rangoon at Calcutta without being seen by Passepartout, after leaving orders that, if the warrant should arrive, it should be forwarded to him at Hong Kong; and he hoped to conceal his presence to the end of the voyage. It would have been difficult to explain why he was on board without awakening Passepartout's suspicions, who thought him still at Bombay. But necessity impelled him, nevertheless, to renew his acquaintance with the worthy servant, as will be seen.
children.prevalue: What was detective Fix so unluckily drawn on from country to country doing all this while He had managed to embark on the Rangoon at Calcutta without being seen by Passepartout after leaving orders that if the warrant should arrive it should be forwarded to him at Hong Kong and he hoped to conceal his presence to the end of the voyage It would have been difficult to explain why he was on board without awakening Passepartout s suspicions who thought him still at Bombay But necessity impelled him nevertheless to renew his acquaintance with the worthy servant as will be seen

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: All the detective's hopes and wishes were now centred on Hong Kong; for the steamer's stay at Singapore would be too brief to enable him to take any steps there.  The arrest must be made at Hong Kong, or the robber would probably escape him for ever.  Hong Kong was the last English ground on which he would set foot; beyond, China, Japan, America offered to Fogg an almost certain refuge.  If the warrant should at last make its appearance at Hong Kong, Fix could arrest him and give him into the hands of the local police, and there would be no further trouble.  But beyond Hong Kong, a simple warrant would be of no avail; an extradition warrant would be necessary, and that would result in delays and obstacles, of which the rascal would take advantage to elude justice.
children.prevalue: All the detective s hopes and wishes were now centred on Hong Kong for the steamer s stay at Singapore would be too brief to enable him to take any steps there The arrest must be made at Hong Kong or the robber would probably escape him for ever Hong Kong was the last English ground on which he would set foot beyond China Japan America offered to Fogg an almost certain refuge If the warrant should at last make its appearance at Hong Kong Fix could arrest him and give him into the hands of the local police and there would be no further trouble But beyond Hong Kong a simple warrant would be of no avail an extradition warrant would be necessary and that would result in delays and obstacles of which the rascal would take advantage to elude justice

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Fix thought over these probabilities during the long hours which he spent in his cabin, and kept repeating to himself, Now, either the warrant will be at Hong Kong, in which case I shall arrest my man, or it will not be there; and this time it is absolutely necessary that I should delay his departure.  I have failed at Bombay, and I have failed at Calcutta; if I fail at Hong Kong, my reputation is lost:  Cost what it may, I must succeed!  But how shall I prevent his departure, if that should turn out to be my last resource?
children.prevalue: Fix thought over these probabilities during the long hours which he spent in his cabin and kept repeating to himself Now either the warrant will be at Hong Kong in which case I shall arrest my man or it will not be there and this time it is absolutely necessary that I should delay his departure I have failed at Bombay and I have failed at Calcutta if I fail at Hong Kong my reputation is lost Cost what it may I must succeed But how shall I prevent his departure if that should turn out to be my last resource

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Fix made up his mind that, if worst came to worst, he would make a confidant of Passepartout, and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was.  That Passepartout was not Fogg's accomplice, he was very certain.  The servant, enlightened by his disclosure, and afraid of being himself implicated in the crime, would doubtless become an ally of the detective.  But this method was a dangerous one, only to be employed when everything else had failed.  A word from Passepartout to his master would ruin all.  The detective was therefore in a sore strait.  But suddenly a new idea struck him.  The presence of Aouda on the Rangoon, in company with Phileas Fogg, gave him new material for reflection.
children.prevalue: Fix made up his mind that if worst came to worst he would make a confidant of Passepartout and tell him what kind of a fellow his master really was That Passepartout was not Fogg s accomplice he was very certain The servant enlightened by his disclosure and afraid of being himself implicated in the crime would doubtless become an ally of the detective But this method was a dangerous one only to be employed when everything else had failed A word from Passepartout to his master would ruin all The detective was therefore in a sore strait But suddenly a new idea struck him The presence of Aouda on the Rangoon in company with Phileas Fogg gave him new material for reflection

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Who was this woman?  What combination of events had made her Fogg's travelling companion?  They had evidently met somewhere between Bombay and Calcutta; but where?  Had they met accidentally, or had Fogg gone into the interior purposely in quest of this charming damsel?  Fix was fairly puzzled.  He asked himself whether there had not been a wicked elopement; and this idea so impressed itself upon his mind that he determined to make use of the supposed intrigue.  Whether the young woman were married or not, he would be able to create such difficulties for Mr. Fogg at Hong Kong that he could not escape by paying any amount of money.
children.prevalue: Who was this woman What combination of events had made her Fogg s travelling companion They had evidently met somewhere between Bombay and Calcutta but where Had they met accidentally or had Fogg gone into the interior purposely in quest of this charming damsel Fix was fairly puzzled He asked himself whether there had not been a wicked elopement and this idea so impressed itself upon his mind that he determined to make use of the supposed intrigue Whether the young woman were married or not he would be able to create such difficulties for Mr Fogg at Hong Kong that he could not escape by paying any amount of money

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But could he even wait till they reached Hong Kong?  Fogg had an abominable way of jumping from one boat to another, and, before anything could be effected, might get full under way again for Yokohama.
children.prevalue: But could he even wait till they reached Hong Kong Fogg had an abominable way of jumping from one boat to another and before anything could be effected might get full under way again for Yokohama

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Fix decided that he must warn the English authorities, and signal the Rangoon before her arrival.  This was easy to do, since the steamer stopped at Singapore, whence there is a telegraphic wire to Hong Kong. He finally resolved, moreover, before acting more positively, to question Passepartout.  It would not be difficult to make him talk; and, as there was no time to lose, Fix prepared to make himself known.
children.prevalue: Fix decided that he must warn the English authorities and signal the Rangoon before her arrival This was easy to do since the steamer stopped at Singapore whence there is a telegraphic wire to Hong Kong He finally resolved moreover before acting more positively to question Passepartout It would not be difficult to make him talk and as there was no time to lose Fix prepared to make himself known

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: It was now the 30th of October, and on the following day the Rangoon was due at Singapore.
children.prevalue: It was now the 30th of October and on the following day the Rangoon was due at Singapore

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Fix emerged from his cabin and went on deck.  Passepartout was promenading up and down in the forward part of the steamer.  The detective rushed forward with every appearance of extreme surprise, and exclaimed, You here, on the Rangoon?
children.prevalue: Fix emerged from his cabin and went on deck Passepartout was promenading up and down in the forward part of the steamer The detective rushed forward with every appearance of extreme surprise and exclaimed You here on the Rangoon

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What, Monsieur Fix, are you on board? returned the really astonished Passepartout, recognising his crony of the Mongolia.  Why, I left you at Bombay, and here you are, on the way to Hong Kong!  Are you going round the world too?
children.prevalue: What Monsieur Fix are you on board returned the really astonished Passepartout recognising his crony of the Mongolia Why I left you at Bombay and here you are on the way to Hong Kong Are you going round the world too

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No, no, replied Fix; I shall stop at Hong Kong--at least for some days.
children.prevalue: No no replied Fix I shall stop at Hong Kong at least for some days

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Hum! said Passepartout, who seemed for an instant perplexed.  But how is it I have not seen you on board since we left Calcutta?
children.prevalue: Hum said Passepartout who seemed for an instant perplexed But how is it I have not seen you on board since we left Calcutta

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oh, a trifle of sea-sickness--I've been staying in my berth.  The Gulf of Bengal does not agree with me as well as the Indian Ocean.  And how is Mr. Fogg?
children.prevalue: Oh a trifle of sea sickness I ve been staying in my berth The Gulf of Bengal does not agree with me as well as the Indian Ocean And how is Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: As well and as punctual as ever, not a day behind time!  But, Monsieur Fix, you don't know that we have a young lady with us.
children.prevalue: As well and as punctual as ever not a day behind time But Monsieur Fix you don t know that we have a young lady with us

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: A young lady? replied the detective, not seeming to comprehend what was said.
children.prevalue: A young lady replied the detective not seeming to comprehend what was said

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Passepartout thereupon recounted Aouda's history, the affair at the Bombay pagoda, the purchase of the elephant for two thousand pounds, the rescue, the arrest, and sentence of the Calcutta court, and the restoration of Mr. Fogg and himself to liberty on bail.  Fix, who was familiar with the last events, seemed to be equally ignorant of all that Passepartout related; and the later was charmed to find so interested a listener.
children.prevalue: Passepartout thereupon recounted Aouda s history the affair at the Bombay pagoda the purchase of the elephant for two thousand pounds the rescue the arrest and sentence of the Calcutta court and the restoration of Mr Fogg and himself to liberty on bail Fix who was familiar with the last events seemed to be equally ignorant of all that Passepartout related and the later was charmed to find so interested a listener

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But does your master propose to carry this young woman to Europe?
children.prevalue: But does your master propose to carry this young woman to Europe

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Not at all.  We are simply going to place her under the protection of one of her relatives, a rich merchant at Hong Kong.
children.prevalue: Not at all We are simply going to place her under the protection of one of her relatives a rich merchant at Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Nothing to be done there, said Fix to himself, concealing his disappointment.  A glass of gin, Mr. Passepartout?
children.prevalue: Nothing to be done there said Fix to himself concealing his disappointment A glass of gin Mr Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Willingly, Monsieur Fix.  We must at least have a friendly glass on board the Rangoon.
children.prevalue: Willingly Monsieur Fix We must at least have a friendly glass on board the Rangoon

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: SHOWING WHAT HAPPENED ON THE VOYAGE FROM SINGAPORE TO HONG KONG
children.prevalue: SHOWING WHAT HAPPENED ON THE VOYAGE FROM SINGAPORE TO HONG KONG

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview, though Fix was reserved, and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr. Fogg.  He caught a glimpse of that mysterious gentleman once or twice; but Mr. Fogg usually confined himself to the cabin, where he kept Aouda company, or, according to his inveterate habit, took a hand at whist.
children.prevalue: The detective and Passepartout met often on deck after this interview though Fix was reserved and did not attempt to induce his companion to divulge any more facts concerning Mr Fogg He caught a glimpse of that mysterious gentleman once or twice but Mr Fogg usually confined himself to the cabin where he kept Aouda company or according to his inveterate habit took a hand at whist

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Passepartout began very seriously to conjecture what strange chance kept Fix still on the route that his master was pursuing.  It was really worth considering why this certainly very amiable and complacent person, whom he had first met at Suez, had then encountered on board the Mongolia, who disembarked at Bombay, which he announced as his destination, and now turned up so unexpectedly on the Rangoon, was following Mr. Fogg's tracks step by step.  What was Fix's object? Passepartout was ready to wager his Indian shoes--which he religiously preserved--that Fix would also leave Hong Kong at the same time with them, and probably on the same steamer.
children.prevalue: Passepartout began very seriously to conjecture what strange chance kept Fix still on the route that his master was pursuing It was really worth considering why this certainly very amiable and complacent person whom he had first met at Suez had then encountered on board the Mongolia who disembarked at Bombay which he announced as his destination and now turned up so unexpectedly on the Rangoon was following Mr Fogg s tracks step by step What was Fix s object Passepartout was ready to wager his Indian shoes which he religiously preserved that Fix would also leave Hong Kong at the same time with them and probably on the same steamer

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Passepartout might have cudgelled his brain for a century without hitting upon the real object which the detective had in view.  He never could have imagined that Phileas Fogg was being tracked as a robber around the globe.  But, as it is in human nature to attempt the solution of every mystery, Passepartout suddenly discovered an explanation of Fix's movements, which was in truth far from unreasonable.  Fix, he thought, could only be an agent of Mr. Fogg's friends at the Reform Club, sent to follow him up, and to ascertain that he really went round the world as had been agreed upon.
children.prevalue: Passepartout might have cudgelled his brain for a century without hitting upon the real object which the detective had in view He never could have imagined that Phileas Fogg was being tracked as a robber around the globe But as it is in human nature to attempt the solution of every mystery Passepartout suddenly discovered an explanation of Fix s movements which was in truth far from unreasonable Fix he thought could only be an agent of Mr Fogg s friends at the Reform Club sent to follow him up and to ascertain that he really went round the world as had been agreed upon

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It's clear! repeated the worthy servant to himself, proud of his shrewdness.  He's a spy sent to keep us in view!  That isn't quite the thing, either, to be spying Mr. Fogg, who is so honourable a man!  Ah, gentlemen of the Reform, this shall cost you dear!
children.prevalue: It s clear repeated the worthy servant to himself proud of his shrewdness He s a spy sent to keep us in view That isn t quite the thing either to be spying Mr Fogg who is so honourable a man Ah gentlemen of the Reform this shall cost you dear

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Passepartout, enchanted with his discovery, resolved to say nothing to his master, lest he should be justly offended at this mistrust on the part of his adversaries.  But he determined to chaff Fix, when he had the chance, with mysterious allusions, which, however, need not betray his real suspicions.
children.prevalue: Passepartout enchanted with his discovery resolved to say nothing to his master lest he should be justly offended at this mistrust on the part of his adversaries But he determined to chaff Fix when he had the chance with mysterious allusions which however need not betray his real suspicions

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: During the afternoon of Wednesday, 30th October, the Rangoon entered the Strait of Malacca, which separates the peninsula of that name from Sumatra.  The mountainous and craggy islets intercepted the beauties of this noble island from the view of the travellers.  The Rangoon weighed anchor at Singapore the next day at four a.m., to receive coal, having gained half a day on the prescribed time of her arrival.  Phileas Fogg noted this gain in his journal, and then, accompanied by Aouda, who betrayed a desire for a walk on shore, disembarked.
children.prevalue: During the afternoon of Wednesday 30th October the Rangoon entered the Strait of Malacca which separates the peninsula of that name from Sumatra The mountainous and craggy islets intercepted the beauties of this noble island from the view of the travellers The Rangoon weighed anchor at Singapore the next day at four a m to receive coal having gained half a day on the prescribed time of her arrival Phileas Fogg noted this gain in his journal and then accompanied by Aouda who betrayed a desire for a walk on shore disembarked

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Fix, who suspected Mr. Fogg's every movement, followed them cautiously, without being himself perceived; while Passepartout, laughing in his sleeve at Fix's manoeuvres, went about his usual errands.
children.prevalue: Fix who suspected Mr Fogg s every movement followed them cautiously without being himself perceived while Passepartout laughing in his sleeve at Fix s manoeuvres went about his usual errands

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect, for there are no mountains; yet its appearance is not without attractions.  It is a park checkered by pleasant highways and avenues.  A handsome carriage, drawn by a sleek pair of New Holland horses, carried Phileas Fogg and Aouda into the midst of rows of palms with brilliant foliage, and of clove-trees, whereof the cloves form the heart of a half-open flower. Pepper plants replaced the prickly hedges of European fields; sago-bushes, large ferns with gorgeous branches, varied the aspect of this tropical clime; while nutmeg-trees in full foliage filled the air with a penetrating perfume.  Agile and grinning bands of monkeys skipped about in the trees, nor were tigers wanting in the jungles.
children.prevalue: The island of Singapore is not imposing in aspect for there are no mountains yet its appearance is not without attractions It is a park checkered by pleasant highways and avenues A handsome carriage drawn by a sleek pair of New Holland horses carried Phileas Fogg and Aouda into the midst of rows of palms with brilliant foliage and of clove trees whereof the cloves form the heart of a half open flower Pepper plants replaced the prickly hedges of European fields sago bushes large ferns with gorgeous branches varied the aspect of this tropical clime while nutmeg trees in full foliage filled the air with a penetrating perfume Agile and grinning bands of monkeys skipped about in the trees nor were tigers wanting in the jungles

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: After a drive of two hours through the country, Aouda and Mr. Fogg returned to the town, which is a vast collection of heavy-looking, irregular houses, surrounded by charming gardens rich in tropical fruits and plants; and at ten o'clock they re-embarked, closely followed by the detective, who had kept them constantly in sight.
children.prevalue: After a drive of two hours through the country Aouda and Mr Fogg returned to the town which is a vast collection of heavy looking irregular houses surrounded by charming gardens rich in tropical fruits and plants and at ten o clock they re embarked closely followed by the detective who had kept them constantly in sight

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Passepartout, who had been purchasing several dozen mangoes--a fruit as large as good-sized apples, of a dark-brown colour outside and a bright red within, and whose white pulp, melting in the mouth, affords gourmands a delicious sensation--was waiting for them on deck.  He was only too glad to offer some mangoes to Aouda, who thanked him very gracefully for them.
children.prevalue: Passepartout who had been purchasing several dozen mangoes a fruit as large as good sized apples of a dark brown colour outside and a bright red within and whose white pulp melting in the mouth affords gourmands a delicious sensation was waiting for them on deck He was only too glad to offer some mangoes to Aouda who thanked him very gracefully for them

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At eleven o'clock the Rangoon rode out of Singapore harbour, and in a few hours the high mountains of Malacca, with their forests, inhabited by the most beautifully-furred tigers in the world, were lost to view. Singapore is distant some thirteen hundred miles from the island of Hong Kong, which is a little English colony near the Chinese coast. Phileas Fogg hoped to accomplish the journey in six days, so as to be in time for the steamer which would leave on the 6th of November for Yokohama, the principal Japanese port.
children.prevalue: At eleven o clock the Rangoon rode out of Singapore harbour and in a few hours the high mountains of Malacca with their forests inhabited by the most beautifully furred tigers in the world were lost to view Singapore is distant some thirteen hundred miles from the island of Hong Kong which is a little English colony near the Chinese coast Phileas Fogg hoped to accomplish the journey in six days so as to be in time for the steamer which would leave on the 6th of November for Yokohama the principal Japanese port

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The Rangoon had a large quota of passengers, many of whom disembarked at Singapore, among them a number of Indians, Ceylonese, Chinamen, Malays, and Portuguese, mostly second-class travellers.
children.prevalue: The Rangoon had a large quota of passengers many of whom disembarked at Singapore among them a number of Indians Ceylonese Chinamen Malays and Portuguese mostly second class travellers

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The weather, which had hitherto been fine, changed with the last quarter of the moon.  The sea rolled heavily, and the wind at intervals rose almost to a storm, but happily blew from the south-west, and thus aided the steamer's progress.  The captain as often as possible put up his sails, and under the double action of steam and sail the vessel made rapid progress along the coasts of Anam and Cochin China.  Owing to the defective construction of the Rangoon, however, unusual precautions became necessary in unfavourable weather; but the loss of time which resulted from this cause, while it nearly drove Passepartout out of his senses, did not seem to affect his master in the least. Passepartout blamed the captain, the engineer, and the crew, and consigned all who were connected with the ship to the land where the pepper grows.  Perhaps the thought of the gas, which was remorselessly burning at his expense in Saville Row, had something to do with his hot impatience.
children.prevalue: The weather which had hitherto been fine changed with the last quarter of the moon The sea rolled heavily and the wind at intervals rose almost to a storm but happily blew from the south west and thus aided the steamer s progress The captain as often as possible put up his sails and under the double action of steam and sail the vessel made rapid progress along the coasts of Anam and Cochin China Owing to the defective construction of the Rangoon however unusual precautions became necessary in unfavourable weather but the loss of time which resulted from this cause while it nearly drove Passepartout out of his senses did not seem to affect his master in the least Passepartout blamed the captain the engineer and the crew and consigned all who were connected with the ship to the land where the pepper grows Perhaps the thought of the gas which was remorselessly burning at his expense in Saville Row had something to do with his hot impatience

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: You are in a great hurry, then, said Fix to him one day, to reach Hong Kong?
children.prevalue: You are in a great hurry then said Fix to him one day to reach Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: A very great hurry!
children.prevalue: A very great hurry

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Mr. Fogg, I suppose, is anxious to catch the steamer for Yokohama?
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg I suppose is anxious to catch the steamer for Yokohama

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Terribly anxious.
children.prevalue: Terribly anxious

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You believe in this journey around the world, then?
children.prevalue: You believe in this journey around the world then

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Absolutely.  Don't you, Mr. Fix?
children.prevalue: Absolutely Don t you Mr Fix

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I?  I don't believe a word of it.
children.prevalue: I I don t believe a word of it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You're a sly dog! said Passepartout, winking at him.
children.prevalue: You re a sly dog said Passepartout winking at him

children.name: Paragraph_23
