children.value: This expression rather disturbed Fix, without his knowing why.  Had the Frenchman guessed his real purpose?  He knew not what to think.  But how could Passepartout have discovered that he was a detective?  Yet, in speaking as he did, the man evidently meant more than he expressed.
children.prevalue: This expression rather disturbed Fix without his knowing why Had the Frenchman guessed his real purpose He knew not what to think But how could Passepartout have discovered that he was a detective Yet in speaking as he did the man evidently meant more than he expressed

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Passepartout went still further the next day; he could not hold his tongue.
children.prevalue: Passepartout went still further the next day he could not hold his tongue

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Mr. Fix, said he, in a bantering tone, shall we be so unfortunate as to lose you when we get to Hong Kong?
children.prevalue: Mr Fix said he in a bantering tone shall we be so unfortunate as to lose you when we get to Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Why, responded Fix, a little embarrassed, I don't know; perhaps--
children.prevalue: Why responded Fix a little embarrassed I don t know perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Ah, if you would only go on with us!  An agent of the Peninsular Company, you know, can't stop on the way!  You were only going to Bombay, and here you are in China.  America is not far off, and from America to Europe is only a step.
children.prevalue: Ah if you would only go on with us An agent of the Peninsular Company you know can t stop on the way You were only going to Bombay and here you are in China America is not far off and from America to Europe is only a step

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Fix looked intently at his companion, whose countenance was as serene as possible, and laughed with him.  But Passepartout persisted in chaffing him by asking him if he made much by his present occupation.
children.prevalue: Fix looked intently at his companion whose countenance was as serene as possible and laughed with him But Passepartout persisted in chaffing him by asking him if he made much by his present occupation

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes, and no, returned Fix; there is good and bad luck in such things.  But you must understand that I don't travel at my own expense.
children.prevalue: Yes and no returned Fix there is good and bad luck in such things But you must understand that I don t travel at my own expense

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh, I am quite sure of that! cried Passepartout, laughing heartily.
children.prevalue: Oh I am quite sure of that cried Passepartout laughing heartily

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Fix, fairly puzzled, descended to his cabin and gave himself up to his reflections.  He was evidently suspected; somehow or other the Frenchman had found out that he was a detective.  But had he told his master?  What part was he playing in all this: was he an accomplice or not?  Was the game, then, up?  Fix spent several hours turning these things over in his mind, sometimes thinking that all was lost, then persuading himself that Fogg was ignorant of his presence, and then undecided what course it was best to take.
children.prevalue: Fix fairly puzzled descended to his cabin and gave himself up to his reflections He was evidently suspected somehow or other the Frenchman had found out that he was a detective But had he told his master What part was he playing in all this was he an accomplice or not Was the game then up Fix spent several hours turning these things over in his mind sometimes thinking that all was lost then persuading himself that Fogg was ignorant of his presence and then undecided what course it was best to take

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Nevertheless, he preserved his coolness of mind, and at last resolved to deal plainly with Passepartout.  If he did not find it practicable to arrest Fogg at Hong Kong, and if Fogg made preparations to leave that last foothold of English territory, he, Fix, would tell Passepartout all.  Either the servant was the accomplice of his master, and in this case the master knew of his operations, and he should fail; or else the servant knew nothing about the robbery, and then his interest would be to abandon the robber.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless he preserved his coolness of mind and at last resolved to deal plainly with Passepartout If he did not find it practicable to arrest Fogg at Hong Kong and if Fogg made preparations to leave that last foothold of English territory he Fix would tell Passepartout all Either the servant was the accomplice of his master and in this case the master knew of his operations and he should fail or else the servant knew nothing about the robbery and then his interest would be to abandon the robber

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Such was the situation between Fix and Passepartout.  Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference.  He was passing methodically in his orbit around the world, regardless of the lesser stars which gravitated around him.  Yet there was near by what the astronomers would call a disturbing star, which might have produced an agitation in this gentleman's heart.  But no! the charms of Aouda failed to act, to Passepartout's great surprise; and the disturbances, if they existed, would have been more difficult to calculate than those of Uranus which led to the discovery of Neptune.
children.prevalue: Such was the situation between Fix and Passepartout Meanwhile Phileas Fogg moved about above them in the most majestic and unconscious indifference He was passing methodically in his orbit around the world regardless of the lesser stars which gravitated around him Yet there was near by what the astronomers would call a disturbing star which might have produced an agitation in this gentleman s heart But no the charms of Aouda failed to act to Passepartout s great surprise and the disturbances if they existed would have been more difficult to calculate than those of Uranus which led to the discovery of Neptune

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It was every day an increasing wonder to Passepartout, who read in Aouda's eyes the depths of her gratitude to his master.  Phileas Fogg, though brave and gallant, must be, he thought, quite heartless.  As to the sentiment which this journey might have awakened in him, there was clearly no trace of such a thing; while poor Passepartout existed in perpetual reveries.
children.prevalue: It was every day an increasing wonder to Passepartout who read in Aouda s eyes the depths of her gratitude to his master Phileas Fogg though brave and gallant must be he thought quite heartless As to the sentiment which this journey might have awakened in him there was clearly no trace of such a thing while poor Passepartout existed in perpetual reveries

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: One day he was leaning on the railing of the engine-room, and was observing the engine, when a sudden pitch of the steamer threw the screw out of the water.  The steam came hissing out of the valves; and this made Passepartout indignant.
children.prevalue: One day he was leaning on the railing of the engine room and was observing the engine when a sudden pitch of the steamer threw the screw out of the water The steam came hissing out of the valves and this made Passepartout indignant

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The valves are not sufficiently charged! he exclaimed.  We are not going.  Oh, these English!  If this was an American craft, we should blow up, perhaps, but we should at all events go faster!
children.prevalue: The valves are not sufficiently charged he exclaimed We are not going Oh these English If this was an American craft we should blow up perhaps but we should at all events go faster

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG, PASSEPARTOUT, AND FIX GO EACH ABOUT HIS BUSINESS
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG PASSEPARTOUT AND FIX GO EACH ABOUT HIS BUSINESS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage.  The wind, obstinately remaining in the north-west, blew a gale, and retarded the steamer.  The Rangoon rolled heavily and the passengers became impatient of the long, monstrous waves which the wind raised before their path.  A sort of tempest arose on the 3rd of November, the squall knocking the vessel about with fury, and the waves running high.  The Rangoon reefed all her sails, and even the rigging proved too much, whistling and shaking amid the squall.  The steamer was forced to proceed slowly, and the captain estimated that she would reach Hong Kong twenty hours behind time, and more if the storm lasted.
children.prevalue: The weather was bad during the latter days of the voyage The wind obstinately remaining in the north west blew a gale and retarded the steamer The Rangoon rolled heavily and the passengers became impatient of the long monstrous waves which the wind raised before their path A sort of tempest arose on the 3rd of November the squall knocking the vessel about with fury and the waves running high The Rangoon reefed all her sails and even the rigging proved too much whistling and shaking amid the squall The steamer was forced to proceed slowly and the captain estimated that she would reach Hong Kong twenty hours behind time and more if the storm lasted

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Phileas Fogg gazed at the tempestuous sea, which seemed to be struggling especially to delay him, with his habitual tranquillity.  He never changed countenance for an instant, though a delay of twenty hours, by making him too late for the Yokohama boat, would almost inevitably cause the loss of the wager.  But this man of nerve manifested neither impatience nor annoyance; it seemed as if the storm were a part of his programme, and had been foreseen.  Aouda was amazed to find him as calm as he had been from the first time she saw him.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg gazed at the tempestuous sea which seemed to be struggling especially to delay him with his habitual tranquillity He never changed countenance for an instant though a delay of twenty hours by making him too late for the Yokohama boat would almost inevitably cause the loss of the wager But this man of nerve manifested neither impatience nor annoyance it seemed as if the storm were a part of his programme and had been foreseen Aouda was amazed to find him as calm as he had been from the first time she saw him

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Fix did not look at the state of things in the same light.  The storm greatly pleased him.  His satisfaction would have been complete had the Rangoon been forced to retreat before the violence of wind and waves. Each delay filled him with hope, for it became more and more probable that Fogg would be obliged to remain some days at Hong Kong; and now the heavens themselves became his allies, with the gusts and squalls. It mattered not that they made him sea-sick--he made no account of this inconvenience; and, whilst his body was writhing under their effects, his spirit bounded with hopeful exultation.
children.prevalue: Fix did not look at the state of things in the same light The storm greatly pleased him His satisfaction would have been complete had the Rangoon been forced to retreat before the violence of wind and waves Each delay filled him with hope for it became more and more probable that Fogg would be obliged to remain some days at Hong Kong and now the heavens themselves became his allies with the gusts and squalls It mattered not that they made him sea sick he made no account of this inconvenience and whilst his body was writhing under their effects his spirit bounded with hopeful exultation

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Passepartout was enraged beyond expression by the unpropitious weather. Everything had gone so well till now!  Earth and sea had seemed to be at his master's service; steamers and railways obeyed him; wind and steam united to speed his journey.  Had the hour of adversity come? Passepartout was as much excited as if the twenty thousand pounds were to come from his own pocket.  The storm exasperated him, the gale made him furious, and he longed to lash the obstinate sea into obedience. Poor fellow!  Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction, for, had he betrayed it, Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was enraged beyond expression by the unpropitious weather Everything had gone so well till now Earth and sea had seemed to be at his master s service steamers and railways obeyed him wind and steam united to speed his journey Had the hour of adversity come Passepartout was as much excited as if the twenty thousand pounds were to come from his own pocket The storm exasperated him the gale made him furious and he longed to lash the obstinate sea into obedience Poor fellow Fix carefully concealed from him his own satisfaction for had he betrayed it Passepartout could scarcely have restrained himself from personal violence

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted, being unable to remain quiet below, and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew.  He overwhelmed the captain, officers, and sailors, who could not help laughing at his impatience, with all sorts of questions.  He wanted to know exactly how long the storm was going to last; whereupon he was referred to the barometer, which seemed to have no intention of rising.  Passepartout shook it, but with no perceptible effect; for neither shaking nor maledictions could prevail upon it to change its mind.
children.prevalue: Passepartout remained on deck as long as the tempest lasted being unable to remain quiet below and taking it into his head to aid the progress of the ship by lending a hand with the crew He overwhelmed the captain officers and sailors who could not help laughing at his impatience with all sorts of questions He wanted to know exactly how long the storm was going to last whereupon he was referred to the barometer which seemed to have no intention of rising Passepartout shook it but with no perceptible effect for neither shaking nor maledictions could prevail upon it to change its mind

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: On the 4th, however, the sea became more calm, and the storm lessened its violence; the wind veered southward, and was once more favourable. Passepartout cleared up with the weather.  Some of the sails were unfurled, and the Rangoon resumed its most rapid speed.  The time lost could not, however, be regained.  Land was not signalled until five o'clock on the morning of the 6th; the steamer was due on the 5th. Phileas Fogg was twenty-four hours behind-hand, and the Yokohama steamer would, of course, be missed.
children.prevalue: On the 4th however the sea became more calm and the storm lessened its violence the wind veered southward and was once more favourable Passepartout cleared up with the weather Some of the sails were unfurled and the Rangoon resumed its most rapid speed The time lost could not however be regained Land was not signalled until five o clock on the morning of the 6th the steamer was due on the 5th Phileas Fogg was twenty four hours behind hand and the Yokohama steamer would of course be missed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The pilot went on board at six, and took his place on the bridge, to guide the Rangoon through the channels to the port of Hong Kong. Passepartout longed to ask him if the steamer had left for Yokohama; but he dared not, for he wished to preserve the spark of hope, which still remained till the last moment.  He had confided his anxiety to Fix who--the sly rascal!--tried to console him by saying that Mr. Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat; but this only put Passepartout in a passion.
children.prevalue: The pilot went on board at six and took his place on the bridge to guide the Rangoon through the channels to the port of Hong Kong Passepartout longed to ask him if the steamer had left for Yokohama but he dared not for he wished to preserve the spark of hope which still remained till the last moment He had confided his anxiety to Fix who the sly rascal tried to console him by saying that Mr Fogg would be in time if he took the next boat but this only put Passepartout in a passion

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Mr. Fogg, bolder than his servant, did not hesitate to approach the pilot, and tranquilly ask him if he knew when a steamer would leave Hong Kong for Yokohama.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg bolder than his servant did not hesitate to approach the pilot and tranquilly ask him if he knew when a steamer would leave Hong Kong for Yokohama

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: At high tide to-morrow morning, answered the pilot.
children.prevalue: At high tide to morrow morning answered the pilot

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ah! said Mr. Fogg, without betraying any astonishment.
children.prevalue: Ah said Mr Fogg without betraying any astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Passepartout, who heard what passed, would willingly have embraced the pilot, while Fix would have been glad to twist his neck.
children.prevalue: Passepartout who heard what passed would willingly have embraced the pilot while Fix would have been glad to twist his neck

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What is the steamer's name? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: What is the steamer s name asked Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The Carnatic.
children.prevalue: The Carnatic

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Ought she not to have gone yesterday?
children.prevalue: Ought she not to have gone yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes, sir; but they had to repair one of her boilers, and so her departure was postponed till to-morrow.
children.prevalue: Yes sir but they had to repair one of her boilers and so her departure was postponed till to morrow

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Thank you, returned Mr. Fogg, descending mathematically to the saloon.
children.prevalue: Thank you returned Mr Fogg descending mathematically to the saloon

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Passepartout clasped the pilot's hand and shook it heartily in his delight, exclaiming, Pilot, you are the best of good fellows!
children.prevalue: Passepartout clasped the pilot s hand and shook it heartily in his delight exclaiming Pilot you are the best of good fellows

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The pilot probably does not know to this day why his responses won him this enthusiastic greeting.  He remounted the bridge, and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks, tankas, and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong.
children.prevalue: The pilot probably does not know to this day why his responses won him this enthusiastic greeting He remounted the bridge and guided the steamer through the flotilla of junks tankas and fishing boats which crowd the harbour of Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: At one o'clock the Rangoon was at the quay, and the passengers were going ashore.
children.prevalue: At one o clock the Rangoon was at the quay and the passengers were going ashore

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Chance had strangely favoured Phileas Fogg, for had not the Carnatic been forced to lie over for repairing her boilers, she would have left on the 6th of November, and the passengers for Japan would have been obliged to await for a week the sailing of the next steamer.  Mr. Fogg was, it is true, twenty-four hours behind his time; but this could not seriously imperil the remainder of his tour.
children.prevalue: Chance had strangely favoured Phileas Fogg for had not the Carnatic been forced to lie over for repairing her boilers she would have left on the 6th of November and the passengers for Japan would have been obliged to await for a week the sailing of the next steamer Mr Fogg was it is true twenty four hours behind his time but this could not seriously imperil the remainder of his tour

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The steamer which crossed the Pacific from Yokohama to San Francisco made a direct connection with that from Hong Kong, and it could not sail until the latter reached Yokohama; and if Mr. Fogg was twenty-four hours late on reaching Yokohama, this time would no doubt be easily regained in the voyage of twenty-two days across the Pacific.  He found himself, then, about twenty-four hours behind-hand, thirty-five days after leaving London.
children.prevalue: The steamer which crossed the Pacific from Yokohama to San Francisco made a direct connection with that from Hong Kong and it could not sail until the latter reached Yokohama and if Mr Fogg was twenty four hours late on reaching Yokohama this time would no doubt be easily regained in the voyage of twenty two days across the Pacific He found himself then about twenty four hours behind hand thirty five days after leaving London

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The Carnatic was announced to leave Hong Kong at five the next morning. Mr. Fogg had sixteen hours in which to attend to his business there, which was to deposit Aouda safely with her wealthy relative.
children.prevalue: The Carnatic was announced to leave Hong Kong at five the next morning Mr Fogg had sixteen hours in which to attend to his business there which was to deposit Aouda safely with her wealthy relative

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: On landing, he conducted her to a palanquin, in which they repaired to the Club Hotel.  A room was engaged for the young woman, and Mr. Fogg, after seeing that she wanted for nothing, set out in search of her cousin Jeejeeh.  He instructed Passepartout to remain at the hotel until his return, that Aouda might not be left entirely alone.
children.prevalue: On landing he conducted her to a palanquin in which they repaired to the Club Hotel A room was engaged for the young woman and Mr Fogg after seeing that she wanted for nothing set out in search of her cousin Jeejeeh He instructed Passepartout to remain at the hotel until his return that Aouda might not be left entirely alone

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Mr. Fogg repaired to the Exchange, where, he did not doubt, every one would know so wealthy and considerable a personage as the Parsee merchant.  Meeting a broker, he made the inquiry, to learn that Jeejeeh had left China two years before, and, retiring from business with an immense fortune, had taken up his residence in Europe--in Holland the broker thought, with the merchants of which country he had principally traded.  Phileas Fogg returned to the hotel, begged a moment's conversation with Aouda, and without more ado, apprised her that Jeejeeh was no longer at Hong Kong, but probably in Holland.

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Aouda at first said nothing.  She passed her hand across her forehead, and reflected a few moments.  Then, in her sweet, soft voice, she said: What ought I to do, Mr. Fogg?
children.prevalue: Aouda at first said nothing She passed her hand across her forehead and reflected a few moments Then in her sweet soft voice she said What ought I to do Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: It is very simple, responded the gentleman.  Go on to Europe.
children.prevalue: It is very simple responded the gentleman Go on to Europe

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: But I cannot intrude--
children.prevalue: But I cannot intrude

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: You do not intrude, nor do you in the least embarrass my project. Passepartout!
children.prevalue: You do not intrude nor do you in the least embarrass my project Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Monsieur.
children.prevalue: Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Go to the Carnatic, and engage three cabins.
children.prevalue: Go to the Carnatic and engage three cabins

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Passepartout, delighted that the young woman, who was very gracious to him, was going to continue the journey with them, went off at a brisk gait to obey his master's order.
children.prevalue: Passepartout delighted that the young woman who was very gracious to him was going to continue the journey with them went off at a brisk gait to obey his master s order

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TAKES A TOO GREAT INTEREST IN HIS MASTER, AND WHAT COMES OF IT
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT TAKES A TOO GREAT INTEREST IN HIS MASTER AND WHAT COMES OF IT

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin, after the war of 1842; and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port.  The island is situated at the mouth of the Canton River, and is separated by about sixty miles from the Portuguese town of Macao, on the opposite coast.  Hong Kong has beaten Macao in the struggle for the Chinese trade, and now the greater part of the transportation of Chinese goods finds its depot at the former place.  Docks, hospitals, wharves, a Gothic cathedral, a government house, macadamised streets, give to Hong Kong the appearance of a town in Kent or Surrey transferred by some strange magic to the antipodes.
children.prevalue: Hong Kong is an island which came into the possession of the English by the Treaty of Nankin after the war of 1842 and the colonising genius of the English has created upon it an important city and an excellent port The island is situated at the mouth of the Canton River and is separated by about sixty miles from the Portuguese town of Macao on the opposite coast Hong Kong has beaten Macao in the struggle for the Chinese trade and now the greater part of the transportation of Chinese goods finds its depot at the former place Docks hospitals wharves a Gothic cathedral a government house macadamised streets give to Hong Kong the appearance of a town in Kent or Surrey transferred by some strange magic to the antipodes

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Passepartout wandered, with his hands in his pockets, towards the Victoria port, gazing as he went at the curious palanquins and other modes of conveyance, and the groups of Chinese, Japanese, and Europeans who passed to and fro in the streets.  Hong Kong seemed to him not unlike Bombay, Calcutta, and Singapore, since, like them, it betrayed everywhere the evidence of English supremacy.  At the Victoria port he found a confused mass of ships of all nations: English, French, American, and Dutch, men-of-war and trading vessels, Japanese and Chinese junks, sempas, tankas, and flower-boats, which formed so many floating parterres.  Passepartout noticed in the crowd a number of the natives who seemed very old and were dressed in yellow.  On going into a barber's to get shaved he learned that these ancient men were all at least eighty years old, at which age they are permitted to wear yellow, which is the Imperial colour.  Passepartout, without exactly knowing why, thought this very funny.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: On reaching the quay where they were to embark on the Carnatic, he was not astonished to find Fix walking up and down.  The detective seemed very much disturbed and disappointed.
children.prevalue: On reaching the quay where they were to embark on the Carnatic he was not astonished to find Fix walking up and down The detective seemed very much disturbed and disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This is bad, muttered Passepartout, for the gentlemen of the Reform Club!  He accosted Fix with a merry smile, as if he had not perceived that gentleman's chagrin.  The detective had, indeed, good reasons to inveigh against the bad luck which pursued him.  The warrant had not come!  It was certainly on the way, but as certainly it could not now reach Hong Kong for several days; and, this being the last English territory on Mr. Fogg's route, the robber would escape, unless he could manage to detain him.
children.prevalue: This is bad muttered Passepartout for the gentlemen of the Reform Club He accosted Fix with a merry smile as if he had not perceived that gentleman s chagrin The detective had indeed good reasons to inveigh against the bad luck which pursued him The warrant had not come It was certainly on the way but as certainly it could not now reach Hong Kong for several days and this being the last English territory on Mr Fogg s route the robber would escape unless he could manage to detain him

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, Monsieur Fix, said Passepartout, have you decided to go with us so far as America?
children.prevalue: Well Monsieur Fix said Passepartout have you decided to go with us so far as America

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes, returned Fix, through his set teeth.
children.prevalue: Yes returned Fix through his set teeth

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Good! exclaimed Passepartout, laughing heartily.  I knew you could not persuade yourself to separate from us.  Come and engage your berth.
children.prevalue: Good exclaimed Passepartout laughing heartily I knew you could not persuade yourself to separate from us Come and engage your berth

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They entered the steamer office and secured cabins for four persons. The clerk, as he gave them the tickets, informed them that, the repairs on the Carnatic having been completed, the steamer would leave that very evening, and not next morning, as had been announced.
children.prevalue: They entered the steamer office and secured cabins for four persons The clerk as he gave them the tickets informed them that the repairs on the Carnatic having been completed the steamer would leave that very evening and not next morning as had been announced

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: That will suit my master all the better, said Passepartout.  I will go and let him know.
children.prevalue: That will suit my master all the better said Passepartout I will go and let him know

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Fix now decided to make a bold move; he resolved to tell Passepartout all.  It seemed to be the only possible means of keeping Phileas Fogg several days longer at Hong Kong.  He accordingly invited his companion into a tavern which caught his eye on the quay.  On entering, they found themselves in a large room handsomely decorated, at the end of which was a large camp-bed furnished with cushions.  Several persons lay upon this bed in a deep sleep.  At the small tables which were arranged about the room some thirty customers were drinking English beer, porter, gin, and brandy; smoking, the while, long red clay pipes stuffed with little balls of opium mingled with essence of rose.  From time to time one of the smokers, overcome with the narcotic, would slip under the table, whereupon the waiters, taking him by the head and feet, carried and laid him upon the bed.  The bed already supported twenty of these stupefied sots.
children.prevalue: Fix now decided to make a bold move he resolved to tell Passepartout all It seemed to be the only possible means of keeping Phileas Fogg several days longer at Hong Kong He accordingly invited his companion into a tavern which caught his eye on the quay On entering they found themselves in a large room handsomely decorated at the end of which was a large camp bed furnished with cushions Several persons lay upon this bed in a deep sleep At the small tables which were arranged about the room some thirty customers were drinking English beer porter gin and brandy smoking the while long red clay pipes stuffed with little balls of opium mingled with essence of rose From time to time one of the smokers overcome with the narcotic would slip under the table whereupon the waiters taking him by the head and feet carried and laid him upon the bed The bed already supported twenty of these stupefied sots

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Fix and Passepartout saw that they were in a smoking-house haunted by those wretched, cadaverous, idiotic creatures to whom the English merchants sell every year the miserable drug called opium, to the amount of one million four hundred thousand pounds--thousands devoted to one of the most despicable vices which afflict humanity!  The Chinese government has in vain attempted to deal with the evil by stringent laws.  It passed gradually from the rich, to whom it was at first exclusively reserved, to the lower classes, and then its ravages could not be arrested.  Opium is smoked everywhere, at all times, by men and women, in the Celestial Empire; and, once accustomed to it, the victims cannot dispense with it, except by suffering horrible bodily contortions and agonies.  A great smoker can smoke as many as eight pipes a day; but he dies in five years.  It was in one of these dens that Fix and Passepartout, in search of a friendly glass, found themselves.  Passepartout had no money, but willingly accepted Fix's invitation in the hope of returning the obligation at some future time.
children.prevalue: Fix and Passepartout saw that they were in a smoking house haunted by those wretched cadaverous idiotic creatures to whom the English merchants sell every year the miserable drug called opium to the amount of one million four hundred thousand pounds thousands devoted to one of the most despicable vices which afflict humanity The Chinese government has in vain attempted to deal with the evil by stringent laws It passed gradually from the rich to whom it was at first exclusively reserved to the lower classes and then its ravages could not be arrested Opium is smoked everywhere at all times by men and women in the Celestial Empire and once accustomed to it the victims cannot dispense with it except by suffering horrible bodily contortions and agonies A great smoker can smoke as many as eight pipes a day but he dies in five years It was in one of these dens that Fix and Passepartout in search of a friendly glass found themselves Passepartout had no money but willingly accepted Fix s invitation in the hope of returning the obligation at some future time

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: They ordered two bottles of port, to which the Frenchman did ample justice, whilst Fix observed him with close attention.  They chatted about the journey, and Passepartout was especially merry at the idea that Fix was going to continue it with them.  When the bottles were empty, however, he rose to go and tell his master of the change in the time of the sailing of the Carnatic.
children.prevalue: They ordered two bottles of port to which the Frenchman did ample justice whilst Fix observed him with close attention They chatted about the journey and Passepartout was especially merry at the idea that Fix was going to continue it with them When the bottles were empty however he rose to go and tell his master of the change in the time of the sailing of the Carnatic

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Fix caught him by the arm, and said, Wait a moment.
children.prevalue: Fix caught him by the arm and said Wait a moment

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: What for, Mr. Fix?
children.prevalue: What for Mr Fix

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I want to have a serious talk with you.
children.prevalue: I want to have a serious talk with you

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: A serious talk! cried Passepartout, drinking up the little wine that was left in the bottom of his glass.  Well, we'll talk about it to-morrow; I haven't time now.
children.prevalue: A serious talk cried Passepartout drinking up the little wine that was left in the bottom of his glass Well we ll talk about it to morrow I haven t time now

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Stay!  What I have to say concerns your master.
children.prevalue: Stay What I have to say concerns your master

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Passepartout, at this, looked attentively at his companion.  Fix's face seemed to have a singular expression.  He resumed his seat.
children.prevalue: Passepartout at this looked attentively at his companion Fix s face seemed to have a singular expression He resumed his seat

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What is it that you have to say?
children.prevalue: What is it that you have to say

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Fix placed his hand upon Passepartout's arm, and, lowering his voice, said, You have guessed who I am?
children.prevalue: Fix placed his hand upon Passepartout s arm and lowering his voice said You have guessed who I am

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Parbleu! said Passepartout, smiling.
children.prevalue: Parbleu said Passepartout smiling

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Then I'm going to tell you everything--
children.prevalue: Then I m going to tell you everything

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Now that I know everything, my friend!  Ah! that's very good.  But go on, go on.  First, though, let me tell you that those gentlemen have put themselves to a useless expense.
children.prevalue: Now that I know everything my friend Ah that s very good But go on go on First though let me tell you that those gentlemen have put themselves to a useless expense

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Useless! said Fix.  You speak confidently.  It's clear that you don't know how large the sum is.
children.prevalue: Useless said Fix You speak confidently It s clear that you don t know how large the sum is

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Of course I do, returned Passepartout.  Twenty thousand pounds.
children.prevalue: Of course I do returned Passepartout Twenty thousand pounds

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Fifty-five thousand! answered Fix, pressing his companion's hand.
children.prevalue: Fifty five thousand answered Fix pressing his companion s hand

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: What! cried the Frenchman.  Has Monsieur Fogg dared--fifty-five thousand pounds!  Well, there's all the more reason for not losing an instant, he continued, getting up hastily.
children.prevalue: What cried the Frenchman Has Monsieur Fogg dared fifty five thousand pounds Well there s all the more reason for not losing an instant he continued getting up hastily

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Fix pushed Passepartout back in his chair, and resumed: Fifty-five thousand pounds; and if I succeed, I get two thousand pounds.  If you'll help me, I'll let you have five hundred of them.
children.prevalue: Fix pushed Passepartout back in his chair and resumed Fifty five thousand pounds and if I succeed I get two thousand pounds If you ll help me I ll let you have five hundred of them

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Help you? cried Passepartout, whose eyes were standing wide open.
children.prevalue: Help you cried Passepartout whose eyes were standing wide open

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes; help me keep Mr. Fogg here for two or three days.
children.prevalue: Yes help me keep Mr Fogg here for two or three days

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why, what are you saying?  Those gentlemen are not satisfied with following my master and suspecting his honour, but they must try to put obstacles in his way!  I blush for them!
children.prevalue: Why what are you saying Those gentlemen are not satisfied with following my master and suspecting his honour but they must try to put obstacles in his way I blush for them

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I mean that it is a piece of shameful trickery.  They might as well waylay Mr. Fogg and put his money in their pockets!
children.prevalue: I mean that it is a piece of shameful trickery They might as well waylay Mr Fogg and put his money in their pockets

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That's just what we count on doing.
children.prevalue: That s just what we count on doing

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: It's a conspiracy, then, cried Passepartout, who became more and more excited as the liquor mounted in his head, for he drank without perceiving it.  A real conspiracy!  And gentlemen, too. Bah!
children.prevalue: It s a conspiracy then cried Passepartout who became more and more excited as the liquor mounted in his head for he drank without perceiving it A real conspiracy And gentlemen too Bah

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Fix began to be puzzled.
children.prevalue: Fix began to be puzzled

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Members of the Reform Club! continued Passepartout.  You must know, Monsieur Fix, that my master is an honest man, and that, when he makes a wager, he tries to win it fairly!
children.prevalue: Members of the Reform Club continued Passepartout You must know Monsieur Fix that my master is an honest man and that when he makes a wager he tries to win it fairly

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: But who do you think I am? asked Fix, looking at him intently.
children.prevalue: But who do you think I am asked Fix looking at him intently

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Parbleu!  An agent of the members of the Reform Club, sent out here to interrupt my master's journey.  But, though I found you out some time ago, I've taken good care to say nothing about it to Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Parbleu An agent of the members of the Reform Club sent out here to interrupt my master s journey But though I found you out some time ago I ve taken good care to say nothing about it to Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: He knows nothing, then?
children.prevalue: He knows nothing then

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Nothing, replied Passepartout, again emptying his glass.
children.prevalue: Nothing replied Passepartout again emptying his glass

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The detective passed his hand across his forehead, hesitating before he spoke again.  What should he do?  Passepartout's mistake seemed sincere, but it made his design more difficult.  It was evident that the servant was not the master's accomplice, as Fix had been inclined to suspect.
children.prevalue: The detective passed his hand across his forehead hesitating before he spoke again What should he do Passepartout s mistake seemed sincere but it made his design more difficult It was evident that the servant was not the master s accomplice as Fix had been inclined to suspect

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Well, said the detective to himself, as he is not an accomplice, he will help me.
children.prevalue: Well said the detective to himself as he is not an accomplice he will help me

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: He had no time to lose: Fogg must be detained at Hong Kong, so he resolved to make a clean breast of it.
children.prevalue: He had no time to lose Fogg must be detained at Hong Kong so he resolved to make a clean breast of it

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Listen to me, said Fix abruptly.  I am not, as you think, an agent of the members of the Reform Club--
children.prevalue: Listen to me said Fix abruptly I am not as you think an agent of the members of the Reform Club

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Bah! retorted Passepartout, with an air of raillery.
children.prevalue: Bah retorted Passepartout with an air of raillery

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I am a police detective, sent out here by the London office.
children.prevalue: I am a police detective sent out here by the London office

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You, a detective?
children.prevalue: You a detective

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I will prove it.  Here is my commission.
children.prevalue: I will prove it Here is my commission

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Passepartout was speechless with astonishment when Fix displayed this document, the genuineness of which could not be doubted.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was speechless with astonishment when Fix displayed this document the genuineness of which could not be doubted

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Mr. Fogg's wager, resumed Fix, is only a pretext, of which you and the gentlemen of the Reform are dupes.  He had a motive for securing your innocent complicity.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg s wager resumed Fix is only a pretext of which you and the gentlemen of the Reform are dupes He had a motive for securing your innocent complicity

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But why?
children.prevalue: But why

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Listen.  On the 28th of last September a robbery of fifty-five thousand pounds was committed at the Bank of England by a person whose description was fortunately secured.  Here is his description; it answers exactly to that of Mr. Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: Listen On the 28th of last September a robbery of fifty five thousand pounds was committed at the Bank of England by a person whose description was fortunately secured Here is his description it answers exactly to that of Mr Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What nonsense! cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. My master is the most honourable of men!
children.prevalue: What nonsense cried Passepartout striking the table with his fist My master is the most honourable of men

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: How can you tell?  You know scarcely anything about him.  You went into his service the day he came away; and he came away on a foolish pretext, without trunks, and carrying a large amount in banknotes.  And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man!
children.prevalue: How can you tell You know scarcely anything about him You went into his service the day he came away and he came away on a foolish pretext without trunks and carrying a large amount in banknotes And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Yes, yes, repeated the poor fellow, mechanically.
children.prevalue: Yes yes repeated the poor fellow mechanically

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Would you like to be arrested as his accomplice?
children.prevalue: Would you like to be arrested as his accomplice

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Passepartout, overcome by what he had heard, held his head between his hands, and did not dare to look at the detective.  Phileas Fogg, the saviour of Aouda, that brave and generous man, a robber!  And yet how many presumptions there were against him!  Passepartout essayed to reject the suspicions which forced themselves upon his mind; he did not wish to believe that his master was guilty.
children.prevalue: Passepartout overcome by what he had heard held his head between his hands and did not dare to look at the detective Phileas Fogg the saviour of Aouda that brave and generous man a robber And yet how many presumptions there were against him Passepartout essayed to reject the suspicions which forced themselves upon his mind he did not wish to believe that his master was guilty

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Well, what do you want of me? said he, at last, with an effort.
children.prevalue: Well what do you want of me said he at last with an effort

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: See here, replied Fix; I have tracked Mr. Fogg to this place, but as yet I have failed to receive the warrant of arrest for which I sent to London.  You must help me to keep him here in Hong Kong--
children.prevalue: See here replied Fix I have tracked Mr Fogg to this place but as yet I have failed to receive the warrant of arrest for which I sent to London You must help me to keep him here in Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I!  But I--
children.prevalue: I But I

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I will share with you the two thousand pounds reward offered by the Bank of England.
children.prevalue: I will share with you the two thousand pounds reward offered by the Bank of England

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Never! replied Passepartout, who tried to rise, but fell back, exhausted in mind and body.
children.prevalue: Never replied Passepartout who tried to rise but fell back exhausted in mind and body

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Mr. Fix, he stammered, even should what you say be true--if my master is really the robber you are seeking for--which I deny--I have been, am, in his service; I have seen his generosity and goodness; and I will never betray him--not for all the gold in the world.  I come from a village where they don't eat that kind of bread!
children.prevalue: Mr Fix he stammered even should what you say be true if my master is really the robber you are seeking for which I deny I have been am in his service I have seen his generosity and goodness and I will never betray him not for all the gold in the world I come from a village where they don t eat that kind of bread

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: You refuse?
children.prevalue: You refuse

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I refuse.
children.prevalue: I refuse

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Consider that I've said nothing, said Fix; and let us drink.
children.prevalue: Consider that I ve said nothing said Fix and let us drink

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Yes; let us drink!
children.prevalue: Yes let us drink

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Passepartout felt himself yielding more and more to the effects of the liquor.  Fix, seeing that he must, at all hazards, be separated from his master, wished to entirely overcome him.  Some pipes full of opium lay upon the table.  Fix slipped one into Passepartout's hand.  He took it, put it between his lips, lit it, drew several puffs, and his head, becoming heavy under the influence of the narcotic, fell upon the table.
children.prevalue: Passepartout felt himself yielding more and more to the effects of the liquor Fix seeing that he must at all hazards be separated from his master wished to entirely overcome him Some pipes full of opium lay upon the table Fix slipped one into Passepartout s hand He took it put it between his lips lit it drew several puffs and his head becoming heavy under the influence of the narcotic fell upon the table

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: At last! said Fix, seeing Passepartout unconscious.  Mr. Fogg will not be informed of the Carnatic's departure; and, if he is, he will have to go without this cursed Frenchman!
children.prevalue: At last said Fix seeing Passepartout unconscious Mr Fogg will not be informed of the Carnatic s departure and if he is he will have to go without this cursed Frenchman

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.
children.prevalue: And after paying his bill Fix left the tavern

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH FIX COMES FACE TO FACE WITH PHILEAS FOGG
children.prevalue: IN WHICH FIX COMES FACE TO FACE WITH PHILEAS FOGG

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them.  It was all very well for an Englishman like Mr. Fogg to make the tour of the world with a carpet-bag; a lady could not be expected to travel comfortably under such conditions.  He acquitted his task with characteristic serenity, and invariably replied to the remonstrances of his fair companion, who was confused by his patience and generosity:
children.prevalue: While these events were passing at the opium house Mr Fogg unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them It was all very well for an Englishman like Mr Fogg to make the tour of the world with a carpet bag a lady could not be expected to travel comfortably under such conditions He acquitted his task with characteristic serenity and invariably replied to the remonstrances of his fair companion who was confused by his patience and generosity

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is in the interest of my journey--a part of my programme.
children.prevalue: It is in the interest of my journey a part of my programme

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The purchases made, they returned to the hotel, where they dined at a sumptuously served table-d'hote; after which Aouda, shaking hands with her protector after the English fashion, retired to her room for rest. Mr. Fogg absorbed himself throughout the evening in the perusal of The Times and Illustrated London News.
children.prevalue: The purchases made they returned to the hotel where they dined at a sumptuously served table d hote after which Aouda shaking hands with her protector after the English fashion retired to her room for rest Mr Fogg absorbed himself throughout the evening in the perusal of The Times and Illustrated London News

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime.  But, knowing that the steamer was not to leave for Yokohama until the next morning, he did not disturb himself about the matter.  When Passepartout did not appear the next morning to answer his master's bell, Mr. Fogg, not betraying the least vexation, contented himself with taking his carpet-bag, calling Aouda, and sending for a palanquin.
children.prevalue: Had he been capable of being astonished at anything it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime But knowing that the steamer was not to leave for Yokohama until the next morning he did not disturb himself about the matter When Passepartout did not appear the next morning to answer his master s bell Mr Fogg not betraying the least vexation contented himself with taking his carpet bag calling Aouda and sending for a palanquin

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It was then eight o'clock; at half-past nine, it being then high tide, the Carnatic would leave the harbour.  Mr. Fogg and Aouda got into the palanquin, their luggage being brought after on a wheelbarrow, and half an hour later stepped upon the quay whence they were to embark.  Mr. Fogg then learned that the Carnatic had sailed the evening before.  He had expected to find not only the steamer, but his domestic, and was forced to give up both; but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face, and he merely remarked to Aouda, It is an accident, madam; nothing more.
children.prevalue: It was then eight o clock at half past nine it being then high tide the Carnatic would leave the harbour Mr Fogg and Aouda got into the palanquin their luggage being brought after on a wheelbarrow and half an hour later stepped upon the quay whence they were to embark Mr Fogg then learned that the Carnatic had sailed the evening before He had expected to find not only the steamer but his domestic and was forced to give up both but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face and he merely remarked to Aouda It is an accident madam nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. It was Fix, who, bowing, addressed Mr. Fogg:  Were you not, like me, sir, a passenger by the Rangoon, which arrived yesterday?
children.prevalue: At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached It was Fix who bowing addressed Mr Fogg Were you not like me sir a passenger by the Rangoon which arrived yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I was, sir, replied Mr. Fogg coldly.  But I have not the honour--
children.prevalue: I was sir replied Mr Fogg coldly But I have not the honour

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Pardon me; I thought I should find your servant here.
children.prevalue: Pardon me I thought I should find your servant here

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Do you know where he is, sir? asked Aouda anxiously.
children.prevalue: Do you know where he is sir asked Aouda anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: What! responded Fix, feigning surprise.  Is he not with you?
children.prevalue: What responded Fix feigning surprise Is he not with you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: No, said Aouda.  He has not made his appearance since yesterday. Could he have gone on board the Carnatic without us?
children.prevalue: No said Aouda He has not made his appearance since yesterday Could he have gone on board the Carnatic without us

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Without you, madam? answered the detective.  Excuse me, did you intend to sail in the Carnatic?
children.prevalue: Without you madam answered the detective Excuse me did you intend to sail in the Carnatic

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, sir.
children.prevalue: Yes sir

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: So did I, madam, and I am excessively disappointed.  The Carnatic, its repairs being completed, left Hong Kong twelve hours before the stated time, without any notice being given; and we must now wait a week for another steamer.
children.prevalue: So did I madam and I am excessively disappointed The Carnatic its repairs being completed left Hong Kong twelve hours before the stated time without any notice being given and we must now wait a week for another steamer

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: As he said a week Fix felt his heart leap for joy.  Fogg detained at Hong Kong for a week!  There would be time for the warrant to arrive, and fortune at last favoured the representative of the law.  His horror may be imagined when he heard Mr. Fogg say, in his placid voice, But there are other vessels besides the Carnatic, it seems to me, in the harbour of Hong Kong.
children.prevalue: As he said a week Fix felt his heart leap for joy Fogg detained at Hong Kong for a week There would be time for the warrant to arrive and fortune at last favoured the representative of the law His horror may be imagined when he heard Mr Fogg say in his placid voice But there are other vessels besides the Carnatic it seems to me in the harbour of Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start.  Fix, stupefied, followed; it seemed as if he were attached to Mr. Fogg by an invisible thread. Chance, however, appeared really to have abandoned the man it had hitherto served so well.  For three hours Phileas Fogg wandered about the docks, with the determination, if necessary, to charter a vessel to carry him to Yokohama; but he could only find vessels which were loading or unloading, and which could not therefore set sail.  Fix began to hope again.
children.prevalue: And offering his arm to Aouda he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start Fix stupefied followed it seemed as if he were attached to Mr Fogg by an invisible thread Chance however appeared really to have abandoned the man it had hitherto served so well For three hours Phileas Fogg wandered about the docks with the determination if necessary to charter a vessel to carry him to Yokohama but he could only find vessels which were loading or unloading and which could not therefore set sail Fix began to hope again

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves.
children.prevalue: But Mr Fogg far from being discouraged was continuing his search resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Is your honour looking for a boat?
children.prevalue: Is your honour looking for a boat

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Have you a boat ready to sail?
children.prevalue: Have you a boat ready to sail

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, your honour; a pilot-boat--No. 43--the best in the harbour.
children.prevalue: Yes your honour a pilot boat No 43 the best in the harbour

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Does she go fast?
children.prevalue: Does she go fast

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Between eight and nine knots the hour.  Will you look at her?
children.prevalue: Between eight and nine knots the hour Will you look at her

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Your honour will be satisfied with her.  Is it for a sea excursion?
children.prevalue: Your honour will be satisfied with her Is it for a sea excursion

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No; for a voyage.
children.prevalue: No for a voyage

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A voyage?
children.prevalue: A voyage

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes, will you agree to take me to Yokohama?
children.prevalue: Yes will you agree to take me to Yokohama

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The sailor leaned on the railing, opened his eyes wide, and said, Is your honour joking?
children.prevalue: The sailor leaned on the railing opened his eyes wide and said Is your honour joking

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: No.  I have missed the Carnatic, and I must get to Yokohama by the 14th at the latest, to take the boat for San Francisco.
children.prevalue: No I have missed the Carnatic and I must get to Yokohama by the 14th at the latest to take the boat for San Francisco

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I am sorry, said the sailor; but it is impossible.
children.prevalue: I am sorry said the sailor but it is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I offer you a hundred pounds per day, and an additional reward of two hundred pounds if I reach Yokohama in time.
children.prevalue: I offer you a hundred pounds per day and an additional reward of two hundred pounds if I reach Yokohama in time

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Are you in earnest?
children.prevalue: Are you in earnest

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Very much so.
children.prevalue: Very much so

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The pilot walked away a little distance, and gazed out to sea, evidently struggling between the anxiety to gain a large sum and the fear of venturing so far.  Fix was in mortal suspense.
children.prevalue: The pilot walked away a little distance and gazed out to sea evidently struggling between the anxiety to gain a large sum and the fear of venturing so far Fix was in mortal suspense

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Mr. Fogg turned to Aouda and asked her, You would not be afraid, would you, madam?
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg turned to Aouda and asked her You would not be afraid would you madam

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Not with you, Mr. Fogg, was her answer.
children.prevalue: Not with you Mr Fogg was her answer

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The pilot now returned, shuffling his hat in his hands.
children.prevalue: The pilot now returned shuffling his hat in his hands

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Well, pilot? said Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Well pilot said Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, your honour, replied he, I could not risk myself, my men, or my little boat of scarcely twenty tons on so long a voyage at this time of year.  Besides, we could not reach Yokohama in time, for it is sixteen hundred and sixty miles from Hong Kong.
children.prevalue: Well your honour replied he I could not risk myself my men or my little boat of scarcely twenty tons on so long a voyage at this time of year Besides we could not reach Yokohama in time for it is sixteen hundred and sixty miles from Hong Kong

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Only sixteen hundred, said Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Only sixteen hundred said Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: It's the same thing.
children.prevalue: It s the same thing

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Fix breathed more freely.
children.prevalue: Fix breathed more freely

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But, added the pilot, it might be arranged another way.
children.prevalue: But added the pilot it might be arranged another way

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Fix ceased to breathe at all.
children.prevalue: Fix ceased to breathe at all

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: How? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: How asked Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: By going to Nagasaki, at the extreme south of Japan, or even to Shanghai, which is only eight hundred miles from here.  In going to Shanghai we should not be forced to sail wide of the Chinese coast, which would be a great advantage, as the currents run northward, and would aid us.
children.prevalue: By going to Nagasaki at the extreme south of Japan or even to Shanghai which is only eight hundred miles from here In going to Shanghai we should not be forced to sail wide of the Chinese coast which would be a great advantage as the currents run northward and would aid us

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Pilot, said Mr. Fogg, I must take the American steamer at Yokohama, and not at Shanghai or Nagasaki.
children.prevalue: Pilot said Mr Fogg I must take the American steamer at Yokohama and not at Shanghai or Nagasaki

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Why not? returned the pilot.  The San Francisco steamer does not start from Yokohama.  It puts in at Yokohama and Nagasaki, but it starts from Shanghai.
children.prevalue: Why not returned the pilot The San Francisco steamer does not start from Yokohama It puts in at Yokohama and Nagasaki but it starts from Shanghai

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You are sure of that?
children.prevalue: You are sure of that

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Perfectly.
children.prevalue: Perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And when does the boat leave Shanghai?
children.prevalue: And when does the boat leave Shanghai

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: On the 11th, at seven in the evening.  We have, therefore, four days before us, that is ninety-six hours; and in that time, if we had good luck and a south-west wind, and the sea was calm, we could make those eight hundred miles to Shanghai.
children.prevalue: On the 11th at seven in the evening We have therefore four days before us that is ninety six hours and in that time if we had good luck and a south west wind and the sea was calm we could make those eight hundred miles to Shanghai

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And you could go--
children.prevalue: And you could go

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: In an hour; as soon as provisions could be got aboard and the sails put up.
children.prevalue: In an hour as soon as provisions could be got aboard and the sails put up

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is a bargain.  Are you the master of the boat?
children.prevalue: It is a bargain Are you the master of the boat

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Yes; John Bunsby, master of the Tankadere.
children.prevalue: Yes John Bunsby master of the Tankadere

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Would you like some earnest-money?
children.prevalue: Would you like some earnest money

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: If it would not put your honour out--
children.prevalue: If it would not put your honour out

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Here are two hundred pounds on account sir, added Phileas Fogg, turning to Fix, if you would like to take advantage--
children.prevalue: Here are two hundred pounds on account sir added Phileas Fogg turning to Fix if you would like to take advantage

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Thanks, sir; I was about to ask the favour.
children.prevalue: Thanks sir I was about to ask the favour

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Very well.  In half an hour we shall go on board.
children.prevalue: Very well In half an hour we shall go on board

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But poor Passepartout? urged Aouda, who was much disturbed by the servant's disappearance.
children.prevalue: But poor Passepartout urged Aouda who was much disturbed by the servant s disappearance

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I shall do all I can to find him, replied Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: I shall do all I can to find him replied Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: While Fix, in a feverish, nervous state, repaired to the pilot-boat, the others directed their course to the police-station at Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg there gave Passepartout's description, and left a sum of money to be spent in the search for him.  The same formalities having been gone through at the French consulate, and the palanquin having stopped at the hotel for the luggage, which had been sent back there, they returned to the wharf.
children.prevalue: While Fix in a feverish nervous state repaired to the pilot boat the others directed their course to the police station at Hong Kong Phileas Fogg there gave Passepartout s description and left a sum of money to be spent in the search for him The same formalities having been gone through at the French consulate and the palanquin having stopped at the hotel for the luggage which had been sent back there they returned to the wharf

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It was now three o'clock; and pilot-boat No. 43, with its crew on board, and its provisions stored away, was ready for departure.
children.prevalue: It was now three o clock and pilot boat No 43 with its crew on board and its provisions stored away was ready for departure

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The Tankadere was a neat little craft of twenty tons, as gracefully built as if she were a racing yacht.  Her shining copper sheathing, her galvanised iron-work, her deck, white as ivory, betrayed the pride taken by John Bunsby in making her presentable.  Her two masts leaned a trifle backward; she carried brigantine, foresail, storm-jib, and standing-jib, and was well rigged for running before the wind; and she seemed capable of brisk speed, which, indeed, she had already proved by gaining several prizes in pilot-boat races.  The crew of the Tankadere was composed of John Bunsby, the master, and four hardy mariners, who were familiar with the Chinese seas.  John Bunsby, himself, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, vigorous, sunburnt, with a sprightly expression of the eye, and energetic and self-reliant countenance, would have inspired confidence in the most timid.
children.prevalue: The Tankadere was a neat little craft of twenty tons as gracefully built as if she were a racing yacht Her shining copper sheathing her galvanised iron work her deck white as ivory betrayed the pride taken by John Bunsby in making her presentable Her two masts leaned a trifle backward she carried brigantine foresail storm jib and standing jib and was well rigged for running before the wind and she seemed capable of brisk speed which indeed she had already proved by gaining several prizes in pilot boat races The crew of the Tankadere was composed of John Bunsby the master and four hardy mariners who were familiar with the Chinese seas John Bunsby himself a man of forty five or thereabouts vigorous sunburnt with a sprightly expression of the eye and energetic and self reliant countenance would have inspired confidence in the most timid

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Phileas Fogg and Aouda went on board, where they found Fix already installed.  Below deck was a square cabin, of which the walls bulged out in the form of cots, above a circular divan; in the centre was a table provided with a swinging lamp.  The accommodation was confined, but neat.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg and Aouda went on board where they found Fix already installed Below deck was a square cabin of which the walls bulged out in the form of cots above a circular divan in the centre was a table provided with a swinging lamp The accommodation was confined but neat

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I am sorry to have nothing better to offer you, said Mr. Fogg to Fix, who bowed without responding.
children.prevalue: I am sorry to have nothing better to offer you said Mr Fogg to Fix who bowed without responding

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The detective had a feeling akin to humiliation in profiting by the kindness of Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: The detective had a feeling akin to humiliation in profiting by the kindness of Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It's certain, thought he, though rascal as he is, he is a polite one!
children.prevalue: It s certain thought he though rascal as he is he is a polite one

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The sails and the English flag were hoisted at ten minutes past three. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, who were seated on deck, cast a last glance at the quay, in the hope of espying Passepartout.  Fix was not without his fears lest chance should direct the steps of the unfortunate servant, whom he had so badly treated, in this direction; in which case an explanation the reverse of satisfactory to the detective must have ensued.  But the Frenchman did not appear, and, without doubt, was still lying under the stupefying influence of the opium.
children.prevalue: The sails and the English flag were hoisted at ten minutes past three Mr Fogg and Aouda who were seated on deck cast a last glance at the quay in the hope of espying Passepartout Fix was not without his fears lest chance should direct the steps of the unfortunate servant whom he had so badly treated in this direction in which case an explanation the reverse of satisfactory to the detective must have ensued But the Frenchman did not appear and without doubt was still lying under the stupefying influence of the opium

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: John Bunsby, master, at length gave the order to start, and the Tankadere, taking the wind under her brigantine, foresail, and standing-jib, bounded briskly forward over the waves.
children.prevalue: John Bunsby master at length gave the order to start and the Tankadere taking the wind under her brigantine foresail and standing jib bounded briskly forward over the waves

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH THE MASTER OF THE TANKADERE RUNS GREAT RISK OF LOSING A REWARD OF TWO HUNDRED POUNDS
children.prevalue: IN WHICH THE MASTER OF THE TANKADERE RUNS GREAT RISK OF LOSING A REWARD OF TWO HUNDRED POUNDS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year.  The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.
children.prevalue: This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons and at that season of the year The Chinese seas are usually boisterous subject to terrible gales of wind and especially during the equinoxes and it was now early November

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It would clearly have been to the master's advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai.  But John Bunsby believed in the Tankadere, which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.
children.prevalue: It would clearly have been to the master s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama since he was paid a certain sum per day but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai But John Bunsby believed in the Tankadere which rode on the waves like a seagull and perhaps he was not wrong

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the Tankadere, impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.
children.prevalue: Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong and the Tankadere impelled by favourable winds conducted herself admirably

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I do not need, pilot, said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, to advise you to use all possible speed.
children.prevalue: I do not need pilot said Phileas Fogg when they got into the open sea to advise you to use all possible speed

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Trust me, your honour.  We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us.  The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.
children.prevalue: Trust me your honour We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us The poles would add nothing and are only used when we are going into port

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It's your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.
children.prevalue: It s your trade not mine pilot and I confide in you

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters.  The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel.  Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings.  The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg with body erect and legs wide apart standing like a sailor gazed without staggering at the swelling waters The young woman who was seated aft was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean darkening now with the twilight on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel Above her head rustled the white sails which seemed like great white wings The boat carried forward by the wind seemed to be flying in the air

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Night came.  The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.
