children.prevalue: After a comfortable breakfast served in the car Mr Fogg and his partners had just resumed whist when a violent whistling was heard and the train stopped Passepartout put his head out of the door but saw nothing to cause the delay no station was in view

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Aouda and Fix feared that Mr. Fogg might take it into his head to get out; but that gentleman contented himself with saying to his servant, See what is the matter.
children.prevalue: Aouda and Fix feared that Mr Fogg might take it into his head to get out but that gentleman contented himself with saying to his servant See what is the matter

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Passepartout rushed out of the car.  Thirty or forty passengers had already descended, amongst them Colonel Stamp Proctor.
children.prevalue: Passepartout rushed out of the car Thirty or forty passengers had already descended amongst them Colonel Stamp Proctor

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the way.  The engineer and conductor were talking excitedly with a signal-man, whom the station-master at Medicine Bow, the next stopping place, had sent on before.  The passengers drew around and took part in the discussion, in which Colonel Proctor, with his insolent manner, was conspicuous.
children.prevalue: The train had stopped before a red signal which blocked the way The engineer and conductor were talking excitedly with a signal man whom the station master at Medicine Bow the next stopping place had sent on before The passengers drew around and took part in the discussion in which Colonel Proctor with his insolent manner was conspicuous

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Passepartout, joining the group, heard the signal-man say, No! you can't pass.  The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky, and would not bear the weight of the train.
children.prevalue: Passepartout joining the group heard the signal man say No you can t pass The bridge at Medicine Bow is shaky and would not bear the weight of the train

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were.  According to the signal-man, it was in a ruinous condition, several of the iron wires being broken; and it was impossible to risk the passage.  He did not in any way exaggerate the condition of the bridge.  It may be taken for granted that, rash as the Americans usually are, when they are prudent there is good reason for it.
children.prevalue: This was a suspension bridge thrown over some rapids about a mile from the place where they now were According to the signal man it was in a ruinous condition several of the iron wires being broken and it was impossible to risk the passage He did not in any way exaggerate the condition of the bridge It may be taken for granted that rash as the Americans usually are when they are prudent there is good reason for it

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Passepartout, not daring to apprise his master of what he heard, listened with set teeth, immovable as a statue.
children.prevalue: Passepartout not daring to apprise his master of what he heard listened with set teeth immovable as a statue

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Hum! cried Colonel Proctor; but we are not going to stay here, I imagine, and take root in the snow?
children.prevalue: Hum cried Colonel Proctor but we are not going to stay here I imagine and take root in the snow

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Colonel, replied the conductor, we have telegraphed to Omaha for a train, but it is not likely that it will reach Medicine Bow in less than six hours.
children.prevalue: Colonel replied the conductor we have telegraphed to Omaha for a train but it is not likely that it will reach Medicine Bow in less than six hours

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Six hours! cried Passepartout.
children.prevalue: Six hours cried Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Certainly, returned the conductor, besides, it will take us as long as that to reach Medicine Bow on foot.
children.prevalue: Certainly returned the conductor besides it will take us as long as that to reach Medicine Bow on foot

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: But it is only a mile from here, said one of the passengers.
children.prevalue: But it is only a mile from here said one of the passengers

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, but it's on the other side of the river.
children.prevalue: Yes but it s on the other side of the river

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And can't we cross that in a boat? asked the colonel.
children.prevalue: And can t we cross that in a boat asked the colonel

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: That's impossible.  The creek is swelled by the rains.  It is a rapid, and we shall have to make a circuit of ten miles to the north to find a ford.
children.prevalue: That s impossible The creek is swelled by the rains It is a rapid and we shall have to make a circuit of ten miles to the north to find a ford

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The colonel launched a volley of oaths, denouncing the railway company and the conductor; and Passepartout, who was furious, was not disinclined to make common cause with him.  Here was an obstacle, indeed, which all his master's banknotes could not remove.
children.prevalue: The colonel launched a volley of oaths denouncing the railway company and the conductor and Passepartout who was furious was not disinclined to make common cause with him Here was an obstacle indeed which all his master s banknotes could not remove

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: There was a general disappointment among the passengers, who, without reckoning the delay, saw themselves compelled to trudge fifteen miles over a plain covered with snow.  They grumbled and protested, and would certainly have thus attracted Phileas Fogg's attention if he had not been completely absorbed in his game.
children.prevalue: There was a general disappointment among the passengers who without reckoning the delay saw themselves compelled to trudge fifteen miles over a plain covered with snow They grumbled and protested and would certainly have thus attracted Phileas Fogg s attention if he had not been completely absorbed in his game

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Passepartout found that he could not avoid telling his master what had occurred, and, with hanging head, he was turning towards the car, when the engineer, a true Yankee, named Forster called out, Gentlemen, perhaps there is a way, after all, to get over.
children.prevalue: Passepartout found that he could not avoid telling his master what had occurred and with hanging head he was turning towards the car when the engineer a true Yankee named Forster called out Gentlemen perhaps there is a way after all to get over

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: On the bridge? asked a passenger.
children.prevalue: On the bridge asked a passenger

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: On the bridge.
children.prevalue: On the bridge

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: With our train?
children.prevalue: With our train

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: With our train.
children.prevalue: With our train

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer.
children.prevalue: Passepartout stopped short and eagerly listened to the engineer

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But the bridge is unsafe, urged the conductor.
children.prevalue: But the bridge is unsafe urged the conductor

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: No matter, replied Forster; I think that by putting on the very highest speed we might have a chance of getting over.
children.prevalue: No matter replied Forster I think that by putting on the very highest speed we might have a chance of getting over

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The devil! muttered Passepartout.
children.prevalue: The devil muttered Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But a number of the passengers were at once attracted by the engineer's proposal, and Colonel Proctor was especially delighted, and found the plan a very feasible one.  He told stories about engineers leaping their trains over rivers without bridges, by putting on full steam; and many of those present avowed themselves of the engineer's mind.
children.prevalue: But a number of the passengers were at once attracted by the engineer s proposal and Colonel Proctor was especially delighted and found the plan a very feasible one He told stories about engineers leaping their trains over rivers without bridges by putting on full steam and many of those present avowed themselves of the engineer s mind

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: We have fifty chances out of a hundred of getting over, said one.
children.prevalue: We have fifty chances out of a hundred of getting over said one

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Eighty! ninety!
children.prevalue: Eighty ninety

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Passepartout was astounded, and, though ready to attempt anything to get over Medicine Creek, thought the experiment proposed a little too American.  Besides, thought he, there's a still more simple way, and it does not even occur to any of these people!  Sir, said he aloud to one of the passengers, the engineer's plan seems to me a little dangerous, but--
children.prevalue: Passepartout was astounded and though ready to attempt anything to get over Medicine Creek thought the experiment proposed a little too American Besides thought he there s a still more simple way and it does not even occur to any of these people Sir said he aloud to one of the passengers the engineer s plan seems to me a little dangerous but

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Eighty chances! replied the passenger, turning his back on him.
children.prevalue: Eighty chances replied the passenger turning his back on him

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I know it, said Passepartout, turning to another passenger, but a simple idea--
children.prevalue: I know it said Passepartout turning to another passenger but a simple idea

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Ideas are no use, returned the American, shrugging his shoulders, as the engineer assures us that we can pass.
children.prevalue: Ideas are no use returned the American shrugging his shoulders as the engineer assures us that we can pass

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Doubtless, urged Passepartout, we can pass, but perhaps it would be more prudent--
children.prevalue: Doubtless urged Passepartout we can pass but perhaps it would be more prudent

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: What!  Prudent! cried Colonel Proctor, whom this word seemed to excite prodigiously.  At full speed, don't you see, at full speed!
children.prevalue: What Prudent cried Colonel Proctor whom this word seemed to excite prodigiously At full speed don t you see at full speed

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I know--I see, repeated Passepartout; but it would be, if not more prudent, since that word displeases you, at least more natural--
children.prevalue: I know I see repeated Passepartout but it would be if not more prudent since that word displeases you at least more natural

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Who!  What!  What's the matter with this fellow? cried several.
children.prevalue: Who What What s the matter with this fellow cried several

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The poor fellow did not know to whom to address himself.
children.prevalue: The poor fellow did not know to whom to address himself

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Are you afraid? asked Colonel Proctor.
children.prevalue: Are you afraid asked Colonel Proctor

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I afraid?  Very well; I will show these people that a Frenchman can be as American as they!
children.prevalue: I afraid Very well I will show these people that a Frenchman can be as American as they

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: All aboard! cried the conductor.
children.prevalue: All aboard cried the conductor

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes, all aboard! repeated Passepartout, and immediately.  But they can't prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot, and let the train come after!
children.prevalue: Yes all aboard repeated Passepartout and immediately But they can t prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot and let the train come after

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice.  The passengers resumed their places in the cars.  Passepartout took his seat without telling what had passed.  The whist-players were quite absorbed in their game.
children.prevalue: But no one heard this sage reflection nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice The passengers resumed their places in the cars Passepartout took his seat without telling what had passed The whist players were quite absorbed in their game

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The locomotive whistled vigorously; the engineer, reversing the steam, backed the train for nearly a mile--retiring, like a jumper, in order to take a longer leap.  Then, with another whistle, he began to move forward; the train increased its speed, and soon its rapidity became frightful; a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive; the piston worked up and down twenty strokes to the second.  They perceived that the whole train, rushing on at the rate of a hundred miles an hour, hardly bore upon the rails at all.
children.prevalue: The locomotive whistled vigorously the engineer reversing the steam backed the train for nearly a mile retiring like a jumper in order to take a longer leap Then with another whistle he began to move forward the train increased its speed and soon its rapidity became frightful a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive the piston worked up and down twenty strokes to the second They perceived that the whole train rushing on at the rate of a hundred miles an hour hardly bore upon the rails at all

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: And they passed over!  It was like a flash.  No one saw the bridge. The train leaped, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station.  But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.
children.prevalue: And they passed over It was like a flash No one saw the bridge The train leaped so to speak from one bank to the other and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station But scarcely had the train passed the river when the bridge completely ruined fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH CERTAIN INCIDENTS ARE NARRATED WHICH ARE ONLY TO BE MET WITH ON AMERICAN RAILROADS
children.prevalue: IN WHICH CERTAIN INCIDENTS ARE NARRATED WHICH ARE ONLY TO BE MET WITH ON AMERICAN RAILROADS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass. The road here attained the highest elevation of the journey, eight thousand and ninety-two feet above the level of the sea.  The travellers had now only to descend to the Atlantic by limitless plains, levelled by nature.  A branch of the grand trunk led off southward to Denver, the capital of Colorado.  The country round about is rich in gold and silver, and more than fifty thousand inhabitants are already settled there.
children.prevalue: The train pursued its course that evening without interruption passing Fort Saunders crossing Cheyne Pass and reaching Evans Pass The road here attained the highest elevation of the journey eight thousand and ninety two feet above the level of the sea The travellers had now only to descend to the Atlantic by limitless plains levelled by nature A branch of the grand trunk led off southward to Denver the capital of Colorado The country round about is rich in gold and silver and more than fifty thousand inhabitants are already settled there

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Thirteen hundred and eighty-two miles had been passed over from San Francisco, in three days and three nights; four days and nights more would probably bring them to New York.  Phileas Fogg was not as yet behind-hand.
children.prevalue: Thirteen hundred and eighty two miles had been passed over from San Francisco in three days and three nights four days and nights more would probably bring them to New York Phileas Fogg was not as yet behind hand

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: During the night Camp Walbach was passed on the left; Lodge Pole Creek ran parallel with the road, marking the boundary between the territories of Wyoming and Colorado.  They entered Nebraska at eleven, passed near Sedgwick, and touched at Julesburg, on the southern branch of the Platte River.
children.prevalue: During the night Camp Walbach was passed on the left Lodge Pole Creek ran parallel with the road marking the boundary between the territories of Wyoming and Colorado They entered Nebraska at eleven passed near Sedgwick and touched at Julesburg on the southern branch of the Platte River

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was here that the Union Pacific Railroad was inaugurated on the 23rd of October, 1867, by the chief engineer, General Dodge.  Two powerful locomotives, carrying nine cars of invited guests, amongst whom was Thomas C. Durant, vice-president of the road, stopped at this point; cheers were given, the Sioux and Pawnees performed an imitation Indian battle, fireworks were let off, and the first number of the Railway Pioneer was printed by a press brought on the train.  Thus was celebrated the inauguration of this great railroad, a mighty instrument of progress and civilisation, thrown across the desert, and destined to link together cities and towns which do not yet exist.  The whistle of the locomotive, more powerful than Amphion's lyre, was about to bid them rise from American soil.
children.prevalue: It was here that the Union Pacific Railroad was inaugurated on the 23rd of October 1867 by the chief engineer General Dodge Two powerful locomotives carrying nine cars of invited guests amongst whom was Thomas C Durant vice president of the road stopped at this point cheers were given the Sioux and Pawnees performed an imitation Indian battle fireworks were let off and the first number of the Railway Pioneer was printed by a press brought on the train Thus was celebrated the inauguration of this great railroad a mighty instrument of progress and civilisation thrown across the desert and destined to link together cities and towns which do not yet exist The whistle of the locomotive more powerful than Amphion s lyre was about to bid them rise from American soil

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Fort McPherson was left behind at eight in the morning, and three hundred and fifty-seven miles had yet to be traversed before reaching Omaha.  The road followed the capricious windings of the southern branch of the Platte River, on its left bank.  At nine the train stopped at the important town of North Platte, built between the two arms of the river, which rejoin each other around it and form a single artery, a large tributary, whose waters empty into the Missouri a little above Omaha.
children.prevalue: Fort McPherson was left behind at eight in the morning and three hundred and fifty seven miles had yet to be traversed before reaching Omaha The road followed the capricious windings of the southern branch of the Platte River on its left bank At nine the train stopped at the important town of North Platte built between the two arms of the river which rejoin each other around it and form a single artery a large tributary whose waters empty into the Missouri a little above Omaha

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The one hundred and first meridian was passed.
children.prevalue: The one hundred and first meridian was passed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one--not even the dummy--complained of the length of the trip.  Fix had begun by winning several guineas, which he seemed likely to lose; but he showed himself a not less eager whist-player than Mr. Fogg.  During the morning, chance distinctly favoured that gentleman.  Trumps and honours were showered upon his hands.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg and his partners had resumed their game no one not even the dummy complained of the length of the trip Fix had begun by winning several guineas which he seemed likely to lose but he showed himself a not less eager whist player than Mr Fogg During the morning chance distinctly favoured that gentleman Trumps and honours were showered upon his hands

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Once, having resolved on a bold stroke, he was on the point of playing a spade, when a voice behind him said, I should play a diamond.
children.prevalue: Once having resolved on a bold stroke he was on the point of playing a spade when a voice behind him said I should play a diamond

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix raised their heads, and beheld Colonel Proctor.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg Aouda and Fix raised their heads and beheld Colonel Proctor

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Stamp Proctor and Phileas Fogg recognised each other at once.
children.prevalue: Stamp Proctor and Phileas Fogg recognised each other at once

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Ah! it's you, is it, Englishman? cried the colonel; it's you who are going to play a spade!
children.prevalue: Ah it s you is it Englishman cried the colonel it s you who are going to play a spade

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And who plays it, replied Phileas Fogg coolly, throwing down the ten of spades.
children.prevalue: And who plays it replied Phileas Fogg coolly throwing down the ten of spades

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Well, it pleases me to have it diamonds, replied Colonel Proctor, in an insolent tone.
children.prevalue: Well it pleases me to have it diamonds replied Colonel Proctor in an insolent tone

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He made a movement as if to seize the card which had just been played, adding, You don't understand anything about whist.
children.prevalue: He made a movement as if to seize the card which had just been played adding You don t understand anything about whist

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Perhaps I do, as well as another, said Phileas Fogg, rising.
children.prevalue: Perhaps I do as well as another said Phileas Fogg rising

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You have only to try, son of John Bull, replied the colonel.
children.prevalue: You have only to try son of John Bull replied the colonel

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Aouda turned pale, and her blood ran cold.  She seized Mr. Fogg's arm and gently pulled him back.  Passepartout was ready to pounce upon the American, who was staring insolently at his opponent.  But Fix got up, and, going to Colonel Proctor said, You forget that it is I with whom you have to deal, sir; for it was I whom you not only insulted, but struck!
children.prevalue: Aouda turned pale and her blood ran cold She seized Mr Fogg s arm and gently pulled him back Passepartout was ready to pounce upon the American who was staring insolently at his opponent But Fix got up and going to Colonel Proctor said You forget that it is I with whom you have to deal sir for it was I whom you not only insulted but struck

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Mr. Fix, said Mr. Fogg, pardon me, but this affair is mine, and mine only.  The colonel has again insulted me, by insisting that I should not play a spade, and he shall give me satisfaction for it.
children.prevalue: Mr Fix said Mr Fogg pardon me but this affair is mine and mine only The colonel has again insulted me by insisting that I should not play a spade and he shall give me satisfaction for it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: When and where you will, replied the American, and with whatever weapon you choose.
children.prevalue: When and where you will replied the American and with whatever weapon you choose

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Aouda in vain attempted to retain Mr. Fogg; as vainly did the detective endeavour to make the quarrel his.  Passepartout wished to throw the colonel out of the window, but a sign from his master checked him. Phileas Fogg left the car, and the American followed him upon the platform.  Sir, said Mr. Fogg to his adversary, I am in a great hurry to get back to Europe, and any delay whatever will be greatly to my disadvantage.
children.prevalue: Aouda in vain attempted to retain Mr Fogg as vainly did the detective endeavour to make the quarrel his Passepartout wished to throw the colonel out of the window but a sign from his master checked him Phileas Fogg left the car and the American followed him upon the platform Sir said Mr Fogg to his adversary I am in a great hurry to get back to Europe and any delay whatever will be greatly to my disadvantage

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well, what's that to me? replied Colonel Proctor.
children.prevalue: Well what s that to me replied Colonel Proctor

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Sir, said Mr. Fogg, very politely, after our meeting at San Francisco, I determined to return to America and find you as soon as I had completed the business which called me to England.
children.prevalue: Sir said Mr Fogg very politely after our meeting at San Francisco I determined to return to America and find you as soon as I had completed the business which called me to England

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Really!
children.prevalue: Really

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Will you appoint a meeting for six months hence?
children.prevalue: Will you appoint a meeting for six months hence

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Why not ten years hence?
children.prevalue: Why not ten years hence

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I say six months, returned Phileas Fogg; and I shall be at the place of meeting promptly.
children.prevalue: I say six months returned Phileas Fogg and I shall be at the place of meeting promptly

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: All this is an evasion, cried Stamp Proctor.  Now or never!
children.prevalue: All this is an evasion cried Stamp Proctor Now or never

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Very good.  You are going to New York?
children.prevalue: Very good You are going to New York

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: To Chicago?
children.prevalue: To Chicago

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: To Omaha?
children.prevalue: To Omaha

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What difference is it to you?  Do you know Plum Creek?
children.prevalue: What difference is it to you Do you know Plum Creek

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: No, replied Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: No replied Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: It's the next station.  The train will be there in an hour, and will stop there ten minutes.  In ten minutes several revolver-shots could be exchanged.
children.prevalue: It s the next station The train will be there in an hour and will stop there ten minutes In ten minutes several revolver shots could be exchanged

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Very well, said Mr. Fogg.  I will stop at Plum Creek.
children.prevalue: Very well said Mr Fogg I will stop at Plum Creek

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And I guess you'll stay there too, added the American insolently.
children.prevalue: And I guess you ll stay there too added the American insolently

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Who knows? replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. He began to reassure Aouda, telling her that blusterers were never to be feared, and begged Fix to be his second at the approaching duel, a request which the detective could not refuse.  Mr. Fogg resumed the interrupted game with perfect calmness.
children.prevalue: Who knows replied Mr Fogg returning to the car as coolly as usual He began to reassure Aouda telling her that blusterers were never to be feared and begged Fix to be his second at the approaching duel a request which the detective could not refuse Mr Fogg resumed the interrupted game with perfect calmness

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: At eleven o'clock the locomotive's whistle announced that they were approaching Plum Creek station.  Mr. Fogg rose, and, followed by Fix, went out upon the platform.  Passepartout accompanied him, carrying a pair of revolvers.  Aouda remained in the car, as pale as death.
children.prevalue: At eleven o clock the locomotive s whistle announced that they were approaching Plum Creek station Mr Fogg rose and followed by Fix went out upon the platform Passepartout accompanied him carrying a pair of revolvers Aouda remained in the car as pale as death

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The door of the next car opened, and Colonel Proctor appeared on the platform, attended by a Yankee of his own stamp as his second.  But just as the combatants were about to step from the train, the conductor hurried up, and shouted, You can't get off, gentlemen!
children.prevalue: The door of the next car opened and Colonel Proctor appeared on the platform attended by a Yankee of his own stamp as his second But just as the combatants were about to step from the train the conductor hurried up and shouted You can t get off gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Why not? asked the colonel.
children.prevalue: Why not asked the colonel

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: We are twenty minutes late, and we shall not stop.
children.prevalue: We are twenty minutes late and we shall not stop

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But I am going to fight a duel with this gentleman.
children.prevalue: But I am going to fight a duel with this gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I am sorry, said the conductor; but we shall be off at once. There's the bell ringing now.
children.prevalue: I am sorry said the conductor but we shall be off at once There s the bell ringing now

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The train started.
children.prevalue: The train started

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I'm really very sorry, gentlemen, said the conductor.  Under any other circumstances I should have been happy to oblige you.  But, after all, as you have not had time to fight here, why not fight as we go along?
children.prevalue: I m really very sorry gentlemen said the conductor Under any other circumstances I should have been happy to oblige you But after all as you have not had time to fight here why not fight as we go along

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: That wouldn't be convenient, perhaps, for this gentleman, said the colonel, in a jeering tone.
children.prevalue: That wouldn t be convenient perhaps for this gentleman said the colonel in a jeering tone

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It would be perfectly so, replied Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: It would be perfectly so replied Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Well, we are really in America, thought Passepartout, and the conductor is a gentleman of the first order!
children.prevalue: Well we are really in America thought Passepartout and the conductor is a gentleman of the first order

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: So muttering, he followed his master.
children.prevalue: So muttering he followed his master

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train.  The last car was only occupied by a dozen passengers, whom the conductor politely asked if they would not be so kind as to leave it vacant for a few moments, as two gentlemen had an affair of honour to settle.  The passengers granted the request with alacrity, and straightway disappeared on the platform.
children.prevalue: The two combatants their seconds and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train The last car was only occupied by a dozen passengers whom the conductor politely asked if they would not be so kind as to leave it vacant for a few moments as two gentlemen had an affair of honour to settle The passengers granted the request with alacrity and straightway disappeared on the platform

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The car, which was some fifty feet long, was very convenient for their purpose.  The adversaries might march on each other in the aisle, and fire at their ease.  Never was duel more easily arranged.  Mr. Fogg and Colonel Proctor, each provided with two six-barrelled revolvers, entered the car.  The seconds, remaining outside, shut them in.  They were to begin firing at the first whistle of the locomotive.  After an interval of two minutes, what remained of the two gentlemen would be taken from the car.
children.prevalue: The car which was some fifty feet long was very convenient for their purpose The adversaries might march on each other in the aisle and fire at their ease Never was duel more easily arranged Mr Fogg and Colonel Proctor each provided with two six barrelled revolvers entered the car The seconds remaining outside shut them in They were to begin firing at the first whistle of the locomotive After an interval of two minutes what remained of the two gentlemen would be taken from the car

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Nothing could be more simple.  Indeed, it was all so simple that Fix and Passepartout felt their hearts beating as if they would crack. They were listening for the whistle agreed upon, when suddenly savage cries resounded in the air, accompanied by reports which certainly did not issue from the car where the duellists were.  The reports continued in front and the whole length of the train.  Cries of terror proceeded from the interior of the cars.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be more simple Indeed it was all so simple that Fix and Passepartout felt their hearts beating as if they would crack They were listening for the whistle agreed upon when suddenly savage cries resounded in the air accompanied by reports which certainly did not issue from the car where the duellists were The reports continued in front and the whole length of the train Cries of terror proceeded from the interior of the cars

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg, revolvers in hand, hastily quitted their prison, and rushed forward where the noise was most clamorous.  They then perceived that the train was attacked by a band of Sioux.
children.prevalue: Colonel Proctor and Mr Fogg revolvers in hand hastily quitted their prison and rushed forward where the noise was most clamorous They then perceived that the train was attacked by a band of Sioux

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: This was not the first attempt of these daring Indians, for more than once they had waylaid trains on the road.  A hundred of them had, according to their habit, jumped upon the steps without stopping the train, with the ease of a clown mounting a horse at full gallop.
children.prevalue: This was not the first attempt of these daring Indians for more than once they had waylaid trains on the road A hundred of them had according to their habit jumped upon the steps without stopping the train with the ease of a clown mounting a horse at full gallop

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
children.prevalue: The Sioux were armed with guns from which came the reports to which the passengers who were almost all armed responded by revolver shots

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: The Indians had first mounted the engine, and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets.  A Sioux chief, wishing to stop the train, but not knowing how to work the regulator, had opened wide instead of closing the steam-valve, and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity.
children.prevalue: The Indians had first mounted the engine and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets A Sioux chief wishing to stop the train but not knowing how to work the regulator had opened wide instead of closing the steam valve and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The Sioux had at the same time invaded the cars, skipping like enraged monkeys over the roofs, thrusting open the doors, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers.  Penetrating the baggage-car, they pillaged it, throwing the trunks out of the train.  The cries and shots were constant.  The travellers defended themselves bravely; some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a siege, like moving forts, carried along at a speed of a hundred miles an hour.
children.prevalue: The Sioux had at the same time invaded the cars skipping like enraged monkeys over the roofs thrusting open the doors and fighting hand to hand with the passengers Penetrating the baggage car they pillaged it throwing the trunks out of the train The cries and shots were constant The travellers defended themselves bravely some of the cars were barricaded and sustained a siege like moving forts carried along at a speed of a hundred miles an hour

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Aouda behaved courageously from the first.  She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she shot through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance.  Twenty Sioux had fallen mortally wounded to the ground, and the wheels crushed those who fell upon the rails as if they had been worms.  Several passengers, shot or stunned, lay on the seats.
children.prevalue: Aouda behaved courageously from the first She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver which she shot through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance Twenty Sioux had fallen mortally wounded to the ground and the wheels crushed those who fell upon the rails as if they had been worms Several passengers shot or stunned lay on the seats

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: It was necessary to put an end to the struggle, which had lasted for ten minutes, and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped.  Fort Kearney station, where there was a garrison, was only two miles distant; but, that once passed, the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the station beyond.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to put an end to the struggle which had lasted for ten minutes and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped Fort Kearney station where there was a garrison was only two miles distant but that once passed the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the station beyond

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The conductor was fighting beside Mr. Fogg, when he was shot and fell. At the same moment he cried, Unless the train is stopped in five minutes, we are lost!
children.prevalue: The conductor was fighting beside Mr Fogg when he was shot and fell At the same moment he cried Unless the train is stopped in five minutes we are lost

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: It shall be stopped, said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car.
children.prevalue: It shall be stopped said Phileas Fogg preparing to rush from the car

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Stay, monsieur, cried Passepartout; I will go.
children.prevalue: Stay monsieur cried Passepartout I will go

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Mr. Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow, who, opening a door unperceived by the Indians, succeeded in slipping under the car; and while the struggle continued and the balls whizzed across each other over his head, he made use of his old acrobatic experience, and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars, holding on to the chains, aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes, creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill, and thus gaining the forward end of the train.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow who opening a door unperceived by the Indians succeeded in slipping under the car and while the struggle continued and the balls whizzed across each other over his head he made use of his old acrobatic experience and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars holding on to the chains aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill and thus gaining the forward end of the train

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.  The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
children.prevalue: There suspended by one hand between the baggage car and the tender with the other he loosened the safety chains but owing to the traction he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking bar had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out The train now detached from the engine remained a little behind whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Carried on by the force already acquired, the train still moved for several minutes; but the brakes were worked and at last they stopped, less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
children.prevalue: Carried on by the force already acquired the train still moved for several minutes but the brakes were worked and at last they stopped less than a hundred feet from Kearney station

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The soldiers of the fort, attracted by the shots, hurried up; the Sioux had not expected them, and decamped in a body before the train entirely stopped.
children.prevalue: The soldiers of the fort attracted by the shots hurried up the Sioux had not expected them and decamped in a body before the train entirely stopped

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.
children.prevalue: But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing among others the courageous Frenchman whose devotion had just saved them

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SIMPLY DOES HIS DUTY
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SIMPLY DOES HIS DUTY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared.  Had they been killed in the struggle?  Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux?  It was impossible to tell.
children.prevalue: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared Had they been killed in the struggle Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux It was impossible to tell

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: There were many wounded, but none mortally.  Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt; he had fought bravely, and a ball had entered his groin.  He was carried into the station with the other wounded passengers, to receive such attention as could be of avail.
children.prevalue: There were many wounded but none mortally Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt he had fought bravely and a ball had entered his groin He was carried into the station with the other wounded passengers to receive such attention as could be of avail

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Aouda was safe; and Phileas Fogg, who had been in the thickest of the fight, had not received a scratch.  Fix was slightly wounded in the arm.  But Passepartout was not to be found, and tears coursed down Aouda's cheeks.
children.prevalue: Aouda was safe and Phileas Fogg who had been in the thickest of the fight had not received a scratch Fix was slightly wounded in the arm But Passepartout was not to be found and tears coursed down Aouda s cheeks

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: All the passengers had got out of the train, the wheels of which were stained with blood.  From the tyres and spokes hung ragged pieces of flesh.  As far as the eye could reach on the white plain behind, red trails were visible.  The last Sioux were disappearing in the south, along the banks of Republican River.
children.prevalue: All the passengers had got out of the train the wheels of which were stained with blood From the tyres and spokes hung ragged pieces of flesh As far as the eye could reach on the white plain behind red trails were visible The last Sioux were disappearing in the south along the banks of Republican River

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Mr. Fogg, with folded arms, remained motionless.  He had a serious decision to make.  Aouda, standing near him, looked at him without speaking, and he understood her look.  If his servant was a prisoner, ought he not to risk everything to rescue him from the Indians?  I will find him, living or dead, said he quietly to Aouda.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg with folded arms remained motionless He had a serious decision to make Aouda standing near him looked at him without speaking and he understood her look If his servant was a prisoner ought he not to risk everything to rescue him from the Indians I will find him living or dead said he quietly to Aouda

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Ah, Mr.--Mr. Fogg! cried she, clasping his hands and covering them with tears.
children.prevalue: Ah Mr Mr Fogg cried she clasping his hands and covering them with tears

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Living, added Mr. Fogg, if we do not lose a moment.
children.prevalue: Living added Mr Fogg if we do not lose a moment

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom.  The delay of a single day would make him lose the steamer at New York, and his bet would be certainly lost.  But as he thought, It is my duty, he did not hesitate.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg by this resolution inevitably sacrificed himself he pronounced his own doom The delay of a single day would make him lose the steamer at New York and his bet would be certainly lost But as he thought It is my duty he did not hesitate

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there.  A hundred of his soldiers had placed themselves in a position to defend the station, should the Sioux attack it.
children.prevalue: The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there A hundred of his soldiers had placed themselves in a position to defend the station should the Sioux attack it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Sir, said Mr. Fogg to the captain, three passengers have disappeared.
children.prevalue: Sir said Mr Fogg to the captain three passengers have disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Dead? asked the captain.
children.prevalue: Dead asked the captain

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Dead or prisoners; that is the uncertainty which must be solved.  Do you propose to pursue the Sioux?
children.prevalue: Dead or prisoners that is the uncertainty which must be solved Do you propose to pursue the Sioux

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: That's a serious thing to do, sir, returned the captain.  These Indians may retreat beyond the Arkansas, and I cannot leave the fort unprotected.
children.prevalue: That s a serious thing to do sir returned the captain These Indians may retreat beyond the Arkansas and I cannot leave the fort unprotected

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The lives of three men are in question, sir, said Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: The lives of three men are in question sir said Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Doubtless; but can I risk the lives of fifty men to save three?
children.prevalue: Doubtless but can I risk the lives of fifty men to save three

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I don't know whether you can, sir; but you ought to do so.
children.prevalue: I don t know whether you can sir but you ought to do so

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Nobody here, returned the other, has a right to teach me my duty.
children.prevalue: Nobody here returned the other has a right to teach me my duty

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Very well, said Mr. Fogg, coldly.  I will go alone.
children.prevalue: Very well said Mr Fogg coldly I will go alone

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You, sir! cried Fix, coming up; you go alone in pursuit of the Indians?
children.prevalue: You sir cried Fix coming up you go alone in pursuit of the Indians

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Would you have me leave this poor fellow to perish--him to whom every one present owes his life?  I shall go.
children.prevalue: Would you have me leave this poor fellow to perish him to whom every one present owes his life I shall go

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No, sir, you shall not go alone, cried the captain, touched in spite of himself.  No! you are a brave man.  Thirty volunteers! he added, turning to the soldiers.
children.prevalue: No sir you shall not go alone cried the captain touched in spite of himself No you are a brave man Thirty volunteers he added turning to the soldiers

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The whole company started forward at once.  The captain had only to pick his men.  Thirty were chosen, and an old sergeant placed at their head.
children.prevalue: The whole company started forward at once The captain had only to pick his men Thirty were chosen and an old sergeant placed at their head

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Thanks, captain, said Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Thanks captain said Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Will you let me go with you? asked Fix.
children.prevalue: Will you let me go with you asked Fix

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Do as you please, sir.  But if you wish to do me a favour, you will remain with Aouda.  In case anything should happen to me--
children.prevalue: Do as you please sir But if you wish to do me a favour you will remain with Aouda In case anything should happen to me

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A sudden pallor overspread the detective's face.  Separate himself from the man whom he had so persistently followed step by step!  Leave him to wander about in this desert!  Fix gazed attentively at Mr. Fogg, and, despite his suspicions and of the struggle which was going on within him, he lowered his eyes before that calm and frank look.
children.prevalue: A sudden pallor overspread the detective s face Separate himself from the man whom he had so persistently followed step by step Leave him to wander about in this desert Fix gazed attentively at Mr Fogg and despite his suspicions and of the struggle which was going on within him he lowered his eyes before that calm and frank look

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I will stay, said he.
children.prevalue: I will stay said he

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: A few moments after, Mr. Fogg pressed the young woman's hand, and, having confided to her his precious carpet-bag, went off with the sergeant and his little squad.  But, before going, he had said to the soldiers, My friends, I will divide five thousand dollars among you, if we save the prisoners.
children.prevalue: A few moments after Mr Fogg pressed the young woman s hand and having confided to her his precious carpet bag went off with the sergeant and his little squad But before going he had said to the soldiers My friends I will divide five thousand dollars among you if we save the prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It was then a little past noon.
children.prevalue: It was then a little past noon

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg.  He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, from duty, in silence.
children.prevalue: Aouda retired to a waiting room and there she waited alone thinking of the simple and noble generosity the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg He had sacrificed his fortune and was now risking his life all without hesitation from duty in silence

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Fix did not have the same thoughts, and could scarcely conceal his agitation.  He walked feverishly up and down the platform, but soon resumed his outward composure.  He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone.  What!  This man, whom he had just followed around the world, was permitted now to separate himself from him!  He began to accuse and abuse himself, and, as if he were director of police, administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness.
children.prevalue: Fix did not have the same thoughts and could scarcely conceal his agitation He walked feverishly up and down the platform but soon resumed his outward composure He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone What This man whom he had just followed around the world was permitted now to separate himself from him He began to accuse and abuse himself and as if he were director of police administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have been an idiot! he thought, and this man will see it.  He has gone, and won't come back!  But how is it that I, Fix, who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest, have been so fascinated by him? Decidedly, I am nothing but an ass!
children.prevalue: I have been an idiot he thought and this man will see it He has gone and won t come back But how is it that I Fix who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest have been so fascinated by him Decidedly I am nothing but an ass

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: So reasoned the detective, while the hours crept by all too slowly.  He did not know what to do.  Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all; but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences.  What course should he take?  He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains; it did not seem impossible that he might overtake him.  Footsteps were easily printed on the snow!  But soon, under a new sheet, every imprint would be effaced.
children.prevalue: So reasoned the detective while the hours crept by all too slowly He did not know what to do Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences What course should he take He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains it did not seem impossible that he might overtake him Footsteps were easily printed on the snow But soon under a new sheet every imprint would be effaced

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Fix became discouraged.  He felt a sort of insurmountable longing to abandon the game altogether.  He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.
children.prevalue: Fix became discouraged He felt a sort of insurmountable longing to abandon the game altogether He could now leave Fort Kearney station and pursue his journey homeward in peace

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Towards two o'clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east.  A great shadow, preceded by a wild light, slowly advanced, appearing still larger through the mist, which gave it a fantastic aspect.  No train was expected from the east, neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive; the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day.  The mystery was soon explained.
children.prevalue: Towards two o clock in the afternoon while it was snowing hard long whistles were heard approaching from the east A great shadow preceded by a wild light slowly advanced appearing still larger through the mist which gave it a fantastic aspect No train was expected from the east neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day The mystery was soon explained

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The locomotive, which was slowly approaching with deafening whistles, was that which, having been detached from the train, had continued its route with such terrific rapidity, carrying off the unconscious engineer and stoker.  It had run several miles, when, the fire becoming low for want of fuel, the steam had slackened; and it had finally stopped an hour after, some twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney.  Neither the engineer nor the stoker was dead, and, after remaining for some time in their swoon, had come to themselves.  The train had then stopped.  The engineer, when he found himself in the desert, and the locomotive without cars, understood what had happened.  He could not imagine how the locomotive had become separated from the train; but he did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress.
children.prevalue: The locomotive which was slowly approaching with deafening whistles was that which having been detached from the train had continued its route with such terrific rapidity carrying off the unconscious engineer and stoker It had run several miles when the fire becoming low for want of fuel the steam had slackened and it had finally stopped an hour after some twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney Neither the engineer nor the stoker was dead and after remaining for some time in their swoon had come to themselves The train had then stopped The engineer when he found himself in the desert and the locomotive without cars understood what had happened He could not imagine how the locomotive had become separated from the train but he did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: He did not hesitate what to do.  It would be prudent to continue on to Omaha, for it would be dangerous to return to the train, which the Indians might still be engaged in pillaging.  Nevertheless, he began to rebuild the fire in the furnace; the pressure again mounted, and the locomotive returned, running backwards to Fort Kearney.  This it was which was whistling in the mist.
children.prevalue: He did not hesitate what to do It would be prudent to continue on to Omaha for it would be dangerous to return to the train which the Indians might still be engaged in pillaging Nevertheless he began to rebuild the fire in the furnace the pressure again mounted and the locomotive returned running backwards to Fort Kearney This it was which was whistling in the mist

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train.  They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted.
children.prevalue: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Aouda, on seeing the locomotive come up, hurried out of the station, and asked the conductor, Are you going to start?
children.prevalue: Aouda on seeing the locomotive come up hurried out of the station and asked the conductor Are you going to start

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At once, madam.
children.prevalue: At once madam

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: But the prisoners, our unfortunate fellow-travellers--
children.prevalue: But the prisoners our unfortunate fellow travellers

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I cannot interrupt the trip, replied the conductor.  We are already three hours behind time.
children.prevalue: I cannot interrupt the trip replied the conductor We are already three hours behind time

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And when will another train pass here from San Francisco?
children.prevalue: And when will another train pass here from San Francisco

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: To-morrow evening, madam.
children.prevalue: To morrow evening madam

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: To-morrow evening!  But then it will be too late!  We must wait--
children.prevalue: To morrow evening But then it will be too late We must wait

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is impossible, responded the conductor.  If you wish to go, please get in.
children.prevalue: It is impossible responded the conductor If you wish to go please get in

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I will not go, said Aouda.
children.prevalue: I will not go said Aouda

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Fix had heard this conversation.  A little while before, when there was no prospect of proceeding on the journey, he had made up his mind to leave Fort Kearney; but now that the train was there, ready to start, and he had only to take his seat in the car, an irresistible influence held him back.  The station platform burned his feet, and he could not stir.  The conflict in his mind again began; anger and failure stifled him.  He wished to struggle on to the end.
children.prevalue: Fix had heard this conversation A little while before when there was no prospect of proceeding on the journey he had made up his mind to leave Fort Kearney but now that the train was there ready to start and he had only to take his seat in the car an irresistible influence held him back The station platform burned his feet and he could not stir The conflict in his mind again began anger and failure stifled him He wished to struggle on to the end

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Meanwhile the passengers and some of the wounded, among them Colonel Proctor, whose injuries were serious, had taken their places in the train.  The buzzing of the over-heated boiler was heard, and the steam was escaping from the valves.  The engineer whistled, the train started, and soon disappeared, mingling its white smoke with the eddies of the densely falling snow.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile the passengers and some of the wounded among them Colonel Proctor whose injuries were serious had taken their places in the train The buzzing of the over heated boiler was heard and the steam was escaping from the valves The engineer whistled the train started and soon disappeared mingling its white smoke with the eddies of the densely falling snow

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The detective had remained behind.
children.prevalue: The detective had remained behind

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Several hours passed.  The weather was dismal, and it was very cold. Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station; he might have been thought asleep.  Aouda, despite the storm, kept coming out of the waiting-room, going to the end of the platform, and peering through the tempest of snow, as if to pierce the mist which narrowed the horizon around her, and to hear, if possible, some welcome sound.  She heard and saw nothing.  Then she would return, chilled through, to issue out again after the lapse of a few moments, but always in vain.
children.prevalue: Several hours passed The weather was dismal and it was very cold Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station he might have been thought asleep Aouda despite the storm kept coming out of the waiting room going to the end of the platform and peering through the tempest of snow as if to pierce the mist which narrowed the horizon around her and to hear if possible some welcome sound She heard and saw nothing Then she would return chilled through to issue out again after the lapse of a few moments but always in vain

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Evening came, and the little band had not returned.  Where could they be?  Had they found the Indians, and were they having a conflict with them, or were they still wandering amid the mist?  The commander of the fort was anxious, though he tried to conceal his apprehensions.  As night approached, the snow fell less plentifully, but it became intensely cold.  Absolute silence rested on the plains.  Neither flight of bird nor passing of beast troubled the perfect calm.
children.prevalue: Evening came and the little band had not returned Where could they be Had they found the Indians and were they having a conflict with them or were they still wandering amid the mist The commander of the fort was anxious though he tried to conceal his apprehensions As night approached the snow fell less plentifully but it became intensely cold Absolute silence rested on the plains Neither flight of bird nor passing of beast troubled the perfect calm

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Throughout the night Aouda, full of sad forebodings, her heart stifled with anguish, wandered about on the verge of the plains.  Her imagination carried her far off, and showed her innumerable dangers. What she suffered through the long hours it would be impossible to describe.
children.prevalue: Throughout the night Aouda full of sad forebodings her heart stifled with anguish wandered about on the verge of the plains Her imagination carried her far off and showed her innumerable dangers What she suffered through the long hours it would be impossible to describe

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Fix remained stationary in the same place, but did not sleep.  Once a man approached and spoke to him, and the detective merely replied by shaking his head.
children.prevalue: Fix remained stationary in the same place but did not sleep Once a man approached and spoke to him and the detective merely replied by shaking his head

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Thus the night passed.  At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off.  Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward; in the south all was still vacancy.  It was then seven o'clock.
children.prevalue: Thus the night passed At dawn the half extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward in the south all was still vacancy It was then seven o clock

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take.
children.prevalue: The captain who was really alarmed did not know what course to take

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first?  Should he sacrifice more men, with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed?  His hesitation did not last long, however.  Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard.  Was it a signal?  The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order.
children.prevalue: Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first Should he sacrifice more men with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed His hesitation did not last long however Calling one of his lieutenants he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance when gunshots were heard Was it a signal The soldiers rushed out of the fort and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, rescued from the Sioux.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg was marching at their head and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers rescued from the Sioux

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney. Shortly before the detachment arrived, Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, three of whom the Frenchman had felled with his fists, when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief.
children.prevalue: They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney Shortly before the detachment arrived Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors three of whom the Frenchman had felled with his fists when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: All were welcomed with joyful cries.  Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, not without reason, muttered to himself, It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear!
children.prevalue: All were welcomed with joyful cries Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers while Passepartout not without reason muttered to himself It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Fix, without saying a word, looked at Mr. Fogg, and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him.  As for Aouda, she took her protector's hand and pressed it in her own, too much moved to speak.
children.prevalue: Fix without saying a word looked at Mr Fogg and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him As for Aouda she took her protector s hand and pressed it in her own too much moved to speak

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought he should find it there, ready to start for Omaha, and he hoped that the time lost might be regained.
children.prevalue: Meanwhile Passepartout was looking about for the train he thought he should find it there ready to start for Omaha and he hoped that the time lost might be regained

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The train! the train! cried he.
children.prevalue: The train the train cried he

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Gone, replied Fix.
children.prevalue: Gone replied Fix

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And when does the next train pass here? said Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: And when does the next train pass here said Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Not till this evening.
children.prevalue: Not till this evening

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Ah! returned the impassible gentleman quietly.
children.prevalue: Ah returned the impassible gentleman quietly

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, CONSIDERABLY FURTHERS THE INTERESTS OF PHILEAS FOGG
children.prevalue: IN WHICH FIX THE DETECTIVE CONSIDERABLY FURTHERS THE INTERESTS OF PHILEAS FOGG

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time.  Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was desperate.  He had ruined his master!
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time Passepartout the involuntary cause of this delay was desperate He had ruined his master

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At this moment the detective approached Mr. Fogg, and, looking him intently in the face, said:
children.prevalue: At this moment the detective approached Mr Fogg and looking him intently in the face said

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Seriously, sir, are you in great haste?
children.prevalue: Seriously sir are you in great haste

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Quite seriously.
children.prevalue: Quite seriously

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I have a purpose in asking, resumed Fix.  Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th, before nine o'clock in the evening, the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool?
children.prevalue: I have a purpose in asking resumed Fix Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th before nine o clock in the evening the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It is absolutely necessary.
children.prevalue: It is absolutely necessary

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And, if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians, you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th?
children.prevalue: And if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes; with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left.
children.prevalue: Yes with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Good! you are therefore twenty hours behind.  Twelve from twenty leaves eight.  You must regain eight hours.  Do you wish to try to do so?
children.prevalue: Good you are therefore twenty hours behind Twelve from twenty leaves eight You must regain eight hours Do you wish to try to do so

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: On foot? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: On foot asked Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: No; on a sledge, replied Fix.  On a sledge with sails.  A man has proposed such a method to me.
children.prevalue: No on a sledge replied Fix On a sledge with sails A man has proposed such a method to me

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.
children.prevalue: It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night and whose offer he had refused

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him.  An instant after, Mr. Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, entered a hut built just below the fort.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once but Fix having pointed out the man who was walking up and down in front of the station Mr Fogg went up to him An instant after Mr Fogg and the American whose name was Mudge entered a hut built just below the fort

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: There Mr. Fogg examined a curious vehicle, a kind of frame on two long beams, a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge, and upon which there was room for five or six persons.  A high mast was fixed on the frame, held firmly by metallic lashings, to which was attached a large brigantine sail.  This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib-sail.  Behind, a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle.  It was, in short, a sledge rigged like a sloop.  During the winter, when the trains are blocked up by the snow, these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another. Provided with more sails than a cutter, and with the wind behind them, they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains.
children.prevalue: There Mr Fogg examined a curious vehicle a kind of frame on two long beams a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge and upon which there was room for five or six persons A high mast was fixed on the frame held firmly by metallic lashings to which was attached a large brigantine sail This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib sail Behind a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle It was in short a sledge rigged like a sloop During the winter when the trains are blocked up by the snow these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another Provided with more sails than a cutter and with the wind behind them they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Mr. Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land-craft.  The wind was favourable, being fresh, and blowing from the west.  The snow had hardened, and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr. Fogg in a few hours to Omaha.  Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York.  It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land craft The wind was favourable being fresh and blowing from the west The snow had hardened and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr Fogg in a few hours to Omaha Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered and such an opportunity was not to be rejected

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions.  But Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision; for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him.
children.prevalue: Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air Mr Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions But Aouda refused to separate from Mr Fogg and Passepartout was delighted with her decision for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It would be difficult to guess the detective's thoughts.  Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg's return, or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal, who, his journey round the world completed, would think himself absolutely safe in England?  Perhaps Fix's opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.
