children.prevalue: It would be difficult to guess the detective s thoughts Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg s return or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal who his journey round the world completed would think himself absolutely safe in England Perhaps Fix s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: At eight o'clock the sledge was ready to start.  The passengers took their places on it, and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling-cloaks.  The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour.
children.prevalue: At eight o clock the sledge was ready to start The passengers took their places on it and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling cloaks The two great sails were hoisted and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha, as the birds fly, is at most two hundred miles.  If the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours; if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o'clock.
children.prevalue: The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha as the birds fly is at most two hundred miles If the wind held good the distance might be traversed in five hours if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o clock

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What a journey!  The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going.  The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves.  When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails.  Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make.  All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine.  A top-mast was hoisted, and another jib, held out to the wind, added its force to the other sails.  Although the speed could not be exactly estimated, the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour.
children.prevalue: What a journey The travellers huddled close together could not speak for the cold intensified by the rapidity at which they were going The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails Mudge who was at the rudder kept in a straight line and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make All the sails were up and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine A top mast was hoisted and another jib held out to the wind added its force to the other sails Although the speed could not be exactly estimated the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: If nothing breaks, said Mudge, we shall get there!
children.prevalue: If nothing breaks said Mudge we shall get there

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge's interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg had made it for Mudge s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on by the offer of a handsome reward

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea.  It seemed like a vast frozen lake.  The railroad which ran through this section ascended from the south-west to the north-west by Great Island, Columbus, an important Nebraska town, Schuyler, and Fremont, to Omaha.  It followed throughout the right bank of the Platte River.  The sledge, shortening this route, took a chord of the arc described by the railway.  Mudge was not afraid of being stopped by the Platte River, because it was frozen.  The road, then, was quite clear of obstacles, and Phileas Fogg had but two things to fear--an accident to the sledge, and a change or calm in the wind.
children.prevalue: The prairie across which the sledge was moving in a straight line was as flat as a sea It seemed like a vast frozen lake The railroad which ran through this section ascended from the south west to the north west by Great Island Columbus an important Nebraska town Schuyler and Fremont to Omaha It followed throughout the right bank of the Platte River The sledge shortening this route took a chord of the arc described by the railway Mudge was not afraid of being stopped by the Platte River because it was frozen The road then was quite clear of obstacles and Phileas Fogg had but two things to fear an accident to the sledge and a change or calm in the wind

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But the breeze, far from lessening its force, blew as if to bend the mast, which, however, the metallic lashings held firmly.  These lashings, like the chords of a stringed instrument, resounded as if vibrated by a violin bow.  The sledge slid along in the midst of a plaintively intense melody.
children.prevalue: But the breeze far from lessening its force blew as if to bend the mast which however the metallic lashings held firmly These lashings like the chords of a stringed instrument resounded as if vibrated by a violin bow The sledge slid along in the midst of a plaintively intense melody

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Those chords give the fifth and the octave, said Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Those chords give the fifth and the octave said Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: These were the only words he uttered during the journey.  Aouda, cosily packed in furs and cloaks, was sheltered as much as possible from the attacks of the freezing wind.  As for Passepartout, his face was as red as the sun's disc when it sets in the mist, and he laboriously inhaled the biting air.  With his natural buoyancy of spirits, he began to hope again.  They would reach New York on the evening, if not on the morning, of the 11th, and there was still some chances that it would be before the steamer sailed for Liverpool.
children.prevalue: These were the only words he uttered during the journey Aouda cosily packed in furs and cloaks was sheltered as much as possible from the attacks of the freezing wind As for Passepartout his face was as red as the sun s disc when it sets in the mist and he laboriously inhaled the biting air With his natural buoyancy of spirits he began to hope again They would reach New York on the evening if not on the morning of the 11th and there was still some chances that it would be before the steamer sailed for Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Passepartout even felt a strong desire to grasp his ally, Fix, by the hand.  He remembered that it was the detective who procured the sledge, the only means of reaching Omaha in time; but, checked by some presentiment, he kept his usual reserve.  One thing, however, Passepartout would never forget, and that was the sacrifice which Mr. Fogg had made, without hesitation, to rescue him from the Sioux.  Mr. Fogg had risked his fortune and his life. No!  His servant would never forget that!
children.prevalue: Passepartout even felt a strong desire to grasp his ally Fix by the hand He remembered that it was the detective who procured the sledge the only means of reaching Omaha in time but checked by some presentiment he kept his usual reserve One thing however Passepartout would never forget and that was the sacrifice which Mr Fogg had made without hesitation to rescue him from the Sioux Mr Fogg had risked his fortune and his life No His servant would never forget that

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: While each of the party was absorbed in reflections so different, the sledge flew past over the vast carpet of snow.  The creeks it passed over were not perceived.  Fields and streams disappeared under the uniform whiteness.  The plain was absolutely deserted.  Between the Union Pacific road and the branch which unites Kearney with Saint Joseph it formed a great uninhabited island.  Neither village, station, nor fort appeared.  From time to time they sped by some phantom-like tree, whose white skeleton twisted and rattled in the wind.  Sometimes flocks of wild birds rose, or bands of gaunt, famished, ferocious prairie-wolves ran howling after the sledge.  Passepartout, revolver in hand, held himself ready to fire on those which came too near.  Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.
children.prevalue: While each of the party was absorbed in reflections so different the sledge flew past over the vast carpet of snow The creeks it passed over were not perceived Fields and streams disappeared under the uniform whiteness The plain was absolutely deserted Between the Union Pacific road and the branch which unites Kearney with Saint Joseph it formed a great uninhabited island Neither village station nor fort appeared From time to time they sped by some phantom like tree whose white skeleton twisted and rattled in the wind Sometimes flocks of wild birds rose or bands of gaunt famished ferocious prairie wolves ran howling after the sledge Passepartout revolver in hand held himself ready to fire on those which came too near Had an accident then happened to the sledge the travellers attacked by these beasts would have been in the most terrible danger but it held on its even course soon gained on the wolves and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River.  He said nothing, but he felt certain that he was now within twenty miles of Omaha.  In less than an hour he left the rudder and furled his sails, whilst the sledge, carried forward by the great impetus the wind had given it, went on half a mile further with its sails unspread.
children.prevalue: About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River He said nothing but he felt certain that he was now within twenty miles of Omaha In less than an hour he left the rudder and furled his sails whilst the sledge carried forward by the great impetus the wind had given it went on half a mile further with its sails unspread

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It stopped at last, and Mudge, pointing to a mass of roofs white with snow, said: We have got there!
children.prevalue: It stopped at last and Mudge pointing to a mass of roofs white with snow said We have got there

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Arrived!  Arrived at the station which is in daily communication, by numerous trains, with the Atlantic seaboard!
children.prevalue: Arrived Arrived at the station which is in daily communication by numerous trains with the Atlantic seaboard

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Passepartout and Fix jumped off, stretched their stiffened limbs, and aided Mr. Fogg and the young woman to descend from the sledge.  Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.
children.prevalue: Passepartout and Fix jumped off stretched their stiffened limbs and aided Mr Fogg and the young woman to descend from the sledge Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town.  Omaha is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, which runs directly east, and passes fifty stations.
children.prevalue: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town Omaha is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad which runs directly east and passes fifty stations

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: A train was ready to start when Mr. Fogg and his party reached the station, and they only had time to get into the cars.  They had seen nothing of Omaha; but Passepartout confessed to himself that this was not to be regretted, as they were not travelling to see the sights.
children.prevalue: A train was ready to start when Mr Fogg and his party reached the station and they only had time to get into the cars They had seen nothing of Omaha but Passepartout confessed to himself that this was not to be regretted as they were not travelling to see the sights

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The train passed rapidly across the State of Iowa, by Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City.  During the night it crossed the Mississippi at Davenport, and by Rock Island entered Illinois.  The next day, which was the 10th, at four o'clock in the evening, it reached Chicago, already risen from its ruins, and more proudly seated than ever on the borders of its beautiful Lake Michigan.
children.prevalue: The train passed rapidly across the State of Iowa by Council Bluffs Des Moines and Iowa City During the night it crossed the Mississippi at Davenport and by Rock Island entered Illinois The next day which was the 10th at four o clock in the evening it reached Chicago already risen from its ruins and more proudly seated than ever on the borders of its beautiful Lake Michigan

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Nine hundred miles separated Chicago from New York; but trains are not wanting at Chicago.  Mr. Fogg passed at once from one to the other, and the locomotive of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway left at full speed, as if it fully comprehended that that gentleman had no time to lose.  It traversed Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey like a flash, rushing through towns with antique names, some of which had streets and car-tracks, but as yet no houses.  At last the Hudson came into view; and, at a quarter-past eleven in the evening of the 11th, the train stopped in the station on the right bank of the river, before the very pier of the Cunard line.
children.prevalue: Nine hundred miles separated Chicago from New York but trains are not wanting at Chicago Mr Fogg passed at once from one to the other and the locomotive of the Pittsburgh Fort Wayne and Chicago Railway left at full speed as if it fully comprehended that that gentleman had no time to lose It traversed Indiana Ohio Pennsylvania and New Jersey like a flash rushing through towns with antique names some of which had streets and car tracks but as yet no houses At last the Hudson came into view and at a quarter past eleven in the evening of the 11th the train stopped in the station on the right bank of the river before the very pier of the Cunard line

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The China, for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!
children.prevalue: The China for Liverpool had started three quarters of an hour before

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ENGAGES IN A DIRECT STRUGGLE WITH BAD FORTUNE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ENGAGES IN A DIRECT STRUGGLE WITH BAD FORTUNE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The China, in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg's last hope.  None of the other steamers were able to serve his projects.  The Pereire, of the French Transatlantic Company, whose admirable steamers are equal to any in speed and comfort, did not leave until the 14th; the Hamburg boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London, but to Havre; and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Phileas Fogg's last efforts of no avail.  The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day, and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager.
children.prevalue: The China in leaving seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg s last hope None of the other steamers were able to serve his projects The Pereire of the French Transatlantic Company whose admirable steamers are equal to any in speed and comfort did not leave until the 14th the Hamburg boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London but to Havre and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Phileas Fogg s last efforts of no avail The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Mr. Fogg learned all this in consulting his Bradshaw, which gave him the daily movements of the trans-Atlantic steamers.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg learned all this in consulting his Bradshaw which gave him the daily movements of the trans Atlantic steamers

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Passepartout was crushed; it overwhelmed him to lose the boat by three-quarters of an hour.  It was his fault, for, instead of helping his master, he had not ceased putting obstacles in his path!  And when he recalled all the incidents of the tour, when he counted up the sums expended in pure loss and on his own account, when he thought that the immense stake, added to the heavy charges of this useless journey, would completely ruin Mr. Fogg, he overwhelmed himself with bitter self-accusations.  Mr. Fogg, however, did not reproach him; and, on leaving the Cunard pier, only said: We will consult about what is best to-morrow.  Come.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was crushed it overwhelmed him to lose the boat by three quarters of an hour It was his fault for instead of helping his master he had not ceased putting obstacles in his path And when he recalled all the incidents of the tour when he counted up the sums expended in pure loss and on his own account when he thought that the immense stake added to the heavy charges of this useless journey would completely ruin Mr Fogg he overwhelmed himself with bitter self accusations Mr Fogg however did not reproach him and on leaving the Cunard pier only said We will consult about what is best to morrow Come

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway.  Rooms were engaged, and the night passed, briefly to Phileas Fogg, who slept profoundly, but very long to Aouda and the others, whose agitation did not permit them to rest.
children.prevalue: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat and drove in a carriage to the St Nicholas Hotel on Broadway Rooms were engaged and the night passed briefly to Phileas Fogg who slept profoundly but very long to Aouda and the others whose agitation did not permit them to rest

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The next day was the 12th of December.  From seven in the morning of the 12th to a quarter before nine in the evening of the 21st there were nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes.  If Phileas Fogg had left in the China, one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.
children.prevalue: The next day was the 12th of December From seven in the morning of the 12th to a quarter before nine in the evening of the 21st there were nine days thirteen hours and forty five minutes If Phileas Fogg had left in the China one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic he would have reached Liverpool and then London within the period agreed upon

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant's notice.  He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson, and looked about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river, for any that were about to depart.  Several had departure signals, and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide; for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe.  But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg left the hotel alone after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant s notice He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson and looked about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river for any that were about to depart Several had departure signals and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe But they were mostly sailing vessels of which of course Phileas Fogg could make no use

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable's length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
children.prevalue: He seemed about to give up all hope when he espied anchored at the Battery a cable s length off at most a trading vessel with a screw well shaped whose funnel puffing a cloud of smoke indicated that she was getting ready for departure

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Phileas Fogg hailed a boat, got into it, and soon found himself on board the Henrietta, iron-hulled, wood-built above.  He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.  He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg hailed a boat got into it and soon found himself on board the Henrietta iron hulled wood built above He ascended to the deck and asked for the captain who forthwith presented himself He was a man of fifty a sort of sea wolf with big eyes a complexion of oxidised copper red hair and thick neck and a growling voice

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The captain? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: The captain asked Mr Fogg

children.value: I am the captain.
children.prevalue: I am the captain

children.prevalue: I am Phileas Fogg of London

children.name: Paragraph_13

children.prevalue: And I am Andrew Speedy of Cardiff

children.value: You are going to put to sea?
children.prevalue: You are going to put to sea

children.name: Paragraph_15

children.prevalue: In an hour

children.prevalue: You are bound for

children.name: Paragraph_17

children.prevalue: Bordeaux

children.prevalue: And your cargo

children.prevalue: Have you any passengers

children.value: No passengers.  Never have passengers.  Too much in the way.

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Is your vessel a swift one?
children.prevalue: Is your vessel a swift one

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Between eleven and twelve knots.  The Henrietta, well known.
children.prevalue: Between eleven and twelve knots The Henrietta well known

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Will you carry me and three other persons to Liverpool?
children.prevalue: Will you carry me and three other persons to Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: To Liverpool?  Why not to China?
children.prevalue: To Liverpool Why not to China

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I said Liverpool.
children.prevalue: I said Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: No!
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: No?
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: No.  I am setting out for Bordeaux, and shall go to Bordeaux.
children.prevalue: No I am setting out for Bordeaux and shall go to Bordeaux

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Money is no object?
children.prevalue: Money is no object

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: None.
children.prevalue: None

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The captain spoke in a tone which did not admit of a reply.
children.prevalue: The captain spoke in a tone which did not admit of a reply

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But the owners of the Henrietta-- resumed Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: But the owners of the Henrietta resumed Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The owners are myself, replied the captain.  The vessel belongs to me.
children.prevalue: The owners are myself replied the captain The vessel belongs to me

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I will freight it for you.
children.prevalue: I will freight it for you

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I will buy it of you.
children.prevalue: I will buy it of you

children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Phileas Fogg did not betray the least disappointment; but the situation was a grave one.  It was not at New York as at Hong Kong, nor with the captain of the Henrietta as with the captain of the Tankadere.  Up to this time money had smoothed away every obstacle.  Now money failed.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg did not betray the least disappointment but the situation was a grave one It was not at New York as at Hong Kong nor with the captain of the Henrietta as with the captain of the Tankadere Up to this time money had smoothed away every obstacle Now money failed

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon--which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice.  It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea, for he said to the captain, Well, will you carry me to Bordeaux?
children.prevalue: Still some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat unless by balloon which would have been venturesome besides not being capable of being put in practice It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea for he said to the captain Well will you carry me to Bordeaux

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: No, not if you paid me two hundred dollars.
children.prevalue: No not if you paid me two hundred dollars

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I offer you two thousand.
children.prevalue: I offer you two thousand

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Apiece?
children.prevalue: Apiece

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Apiece.
children.prevalue: Apiece

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And there are four of you?
children.prevalue: And there are four of you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Four.
children.prevalue: Four

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Captain Speedy began to scratch his head.  There were eight thousand dollars to gain, without changing his route; for which it was well worth conquering the repugnance he had for all kinds of passengers. Besides, passengers at two thousand dollars are no longer passengers, but valuable merchandise.  I start at nine o'clock, said Captain Speedy, simply.  Are you and your party ready?
children.prevalue: Captain Speedy began to scratch his head There were eight thousand dollars to gain without changing his route for which it was well worth conquering the repugnance he had for all kinds of passengers Besides passengers at two thousand dollars are no longer passengers but valuable merchandise I start at nine o clock said Captain Speedy simply Are you and your party ready

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: We will be on board at nine o'clock, replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: We will be on board at nine o clock replied no less simply Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It was half-past eight.  To disembark from the Henrietta, jump into a hack, hurry to the St. Nicholas, and return with Aouda, Passepartout, and even the inseparable Fix was the work of a brief time, and was performed by Mr. Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him. They were on board when the Henrietta made ready to weigh anchor.
children.prevalue: It was half past eight To disembark from the Henrietta jump into a hack hurry to the St Nicholas and return with Aouda Passepartout and even the inseparable Fix was the work of a brief time and was performed by Mr Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him They were on board when the Henrietta made ready to weigh anchor

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: When Passepartout heard what this last voyage was going to cost, he uttered a prolonged Oh! which extended throughout his vocal gamut.
children.prevalue: When Passepartout heard what this last voyage was going to cost he uttered a prolonged Oh which extended throughout his vocal gamut

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: As for Fix, he said to himself that the Bank of England would certainly not come out of this affair well indemnified.  When they reached England, even if Mr. Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank-bills into the sea, more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent!
children.prevalue: As for Fix he said to himself that the Bank of England would certainly not come out of this affair well indemnified When they reached England even if Mr Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank bills into the sea more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SHOWS HIMSELF EQUAL TO THE OCCASION
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SHOWS HIMSELF EQUAL TO THE OCCASION

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: An hour after, the Henrietta passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day she skirted Long Island, passed Fire Island, and directed her course rapidly eastward.
children.prevalue: An hour after the Henrietta passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson turned the point of Sandy Hook and put to sea During the day she skirted Long Island passed Fire Island and directed her course rapidly eastward

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At noon the next day, a man mounted the bridge to ascertain the vessel's position.  It might be thought that this was Captain Speedy. Not the least in the world.  It was Phileas Fogg, Esquire.  As for Captain Speedy, he was shut up in his cabin under lock and key, and was uttering loud cries, which signified an anger at once pardonable and excessive.
children.prevalue: At noon the next day a man mounted the bridge to ascertain the vessel s position It might be thought that this was Captain Speedy Not the least in the world It was Phileas Fogg Esquire As for Captain Speedy he was shut up in his cabin under lock and key and was uttering loud cries which signified an anger at once pardonable and excessive

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What had happened was very simple.  Phileas Fogg wished to go to Liverpool, but the captain would not carry him there.  Then Phileas Fogg had taken passage for Bordeaux, and, during the thirty hours he had been on board, had so shrewdly managed with his banknotes that the sailors and stokers, who were only an occasional crew, and were not on the best terms with the captain, went over to him in a body.  This was why Phileas Fogg was in command instead of Captain Speedy; why the captain was a prisoner in his cabin; and why, in short, the Henrietta was directing her course towards Liverpool.  It was very clear, to see Mr. Fogg manage the craft, that he had been a sailor.
children.prevalue: What had happened was very simple Phileas Fogg wished to go to Liverpool but the captain would not carry him there Then Phileas Fogg had taken passage for Bordeaux and during the thirty hours he had been on board had so shrewdly managed with his banknotes that the sailors and stokers who were only an occasional crew and were not on the best terms with the captain went over to him in a body This was why Phileas Fogg was in command instead of Captain Speedy why the captain was a prisoner in his cabin and why in short the Henrietta was directing her course towards Liverpool It was very clear to see Mr Fogg manage the craft that he had been a sailor

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: How the adventure ended will be seen anon.  Aouda was anxious, though she said nothing.  As for Passepartout, he thought Mr. Fogg's manoeuvre simply glorious.  The captain had said between eleven and twelve knots, and the Henrietta confirmed his prediction.
children.prevalue: How the adventure ended will be seen anon Aouda was anxious though she said nothing As for Passepartout he thought Mr Fogg s manoeuvre simply glorious The captain had said between eleven and twelve knots and the Henrietta confirmed his prediction

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: If, then--for there were ifs still--the sea did not become too boisterous, if the wind did not veer round to the east, if no accident happened to the boat or its machinery, the Henrietta might cross the three thousand miles from New York to Liverpool in the nine days, between the 12th and the 21st of December.  It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the Henrietta, added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.
children.prevalue: If then for there were ifs still the sea did not become too boisterous if the wind did not veer round to the east if no accident happened to the boat or its machinery the Henrietta might cross the three thousand miles from New York to Liverpool in the nine days between the 12th and the 21st of December It is true that once arrived the affair on board the Henrietta added to that of the Bank of England might create more difficulties for Mr Fogg than he imagined or could desire

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough.  The sea was not very unpropitious, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, the sails were hoisted, and the Henrietta ploughed across the waves like a real trans-Atlantic steamer.
children.prevalue: During the first days they went along smoothly enough The sea was not very unpropitious the wind seemed stationary in the north east the sails were hoisted and the Henrietta ploughed across the waves like a real trans Atlantic steamer

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Passepartout was delighted.  His master's last exploit, the consequences of which he ignored, enchanted him.  Never had the crew seen so jolly and dexterous a fellow.  He formed warm friendships with the sailors, and amazed them with his acrobatic feats.  He thought they managed the vessel like gentlemen, and that the stokers fired up like heroes.  His loquacious good-humour infected everyone.  He had forgotten the past, its vexations and delays.  He only thought of the end, so nearly accomplished; and sometimes he boiled over with impatience, as if heated by the furnaces of the Henrietta.  Often, also, the worthy fellow revolved around Fix, looking at him with a keen, distrustful eye; but he did not speak to him, for their old intimacy no longer existed.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was delighted His master s last exploit the consequences of which he ignored enchanted him Never had the crew seen so jolly and dexterous a fellow He formed warm friendships with the sailors and amazed them with his acrobatic feats He thought they managed the vessel like gentlemen and that the stokers fired up like heroes His loquacious good humour infected everyone He had forgotten the past its vexations and delays He only thought of the end so nearly accomplished and sometimes he boiled over with impatience as if heated by the furnaces of the Henrietta Often also the worthy fellow revolved around Fix looking at him with a keen distrustful eye but he did not speak to him for their old intimacy no longer existed

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Fix, it must be confessed, understood nothing of what was going on. The conquest of the Henrietta, the bribery of the crew, Fogg managing the boat like a skilled seaman, amazed and confused him.  He did not know what to think.  For, after all, a man who began by stealing fifty-five thousand pounds might end by stealing a vessel; and Fix was not unnaturally inclined to conclude that the Henrietta under Fogg's command, was not going to Liverpool at all, but to some part of the world where the robber, turned into a pirate, would quietly put himself in safety.  The conjecture was at least a plausible one, and the detective began to seriously regret that he had embarked on the affair.
children.prevalue: Fix it must be confessed understood nothing of what was going on The conquest of the Henrietta the bribery of the crew Fogg managing the boat like a skilled seaman amazed and confused him He did not know what to think For after all a man who began by stealing fifty five thousand pounds might end by stealing a vessel and Fix was not unnaturally inclined to conclude that the Henrietta under Fogg s command was not going to Liverpool at all but to some part of the world where the robber turned into a pirate would quietly put himself in safety The conjecture was at least a plausible one and the detective began to seriously regret that he had embarked on the affair

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: As for Captain Speedy, he continued to howl and growl in his cabin; and Passepartout, whose duty it was to carry him his meals, courageous as he was, took the greatest precautions.  Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.
children.prevalue: As for Captain Speedy he continued to howl and growl in his cabin and Passepartout whose duty it was to carry him his meals courageous as he was took the greatest precautions Mr Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind.  Ever since the evening before the barometer, suddenly falling, had indicated an approaching change in the atmosphere; and during the night the temperature varied, the cold became sharper, and the wind veered to the south-east.
children.prevalue: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland a dangerous locality during the winter especially there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind Ever since the evening before the barometer suddenly falling had indicated an approaching change in the atmosphere and during the night the temperature varied the cold became sharper and the wind veered to the south east

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: This was a misfortune.  Mr. Fogg, in order not to deviate from his course, furled his sails and increased the force of the steam; but the vessel's speed slackened, owing to the state of the sea, the long waves of which broke against the stern.  She pitched violently, and this retarded her progress.  The breeze little by little swelled into a tempest, and it was to be feared that the Henrietta might not be able to maintain herself upright on the waves.
children.prevalue: This was a misfortune Mr Fogg in order not to deviate from his course furled his sails and increased the force of the steam but the vessel s speed slackened owing to the state of the sea the long waves of which broke against the stern She pitched violently and this retarded her progress The breeze little by little swelled into a tempest and it was to be feared that the Henrietta might not be able to maintain herself upright on the waves

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Passepartout's visage darkened with the skies, and for two days the poor fellow experienced constant fright.  But Phileas Fogg was a bold mariner, and knew how to maintain headway against the sea; and he kept on his course, without even decreasing his steam.  The Henrietta, when she could not rise upon the waves, crossed them, swamping her deck, but passing safely.  Sometimes the screw rose out of the water, beating its protruding end, when a mountain of water raised the stern above the waves; but the craft always kept straight ahead.
children.prevalue: Passepartout s visage darkened with the skies and for two days the poor fellow experienced constant fright But Phileas Fogg was a bold mariner and knew how to maintain headway against the sea and he kept on his course without even decreasing his steam The Henrietta when she could not rise upon the waves crossed them swamping her deck but passing safely Sometimes the screw rose out of the water beating its protruding end when a mountain of water raised the stern above the waves but the craft always kept straight ahead

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The wind, however, did not grow as boisterous as might have been feared; it was not one of those tempests which burst, and rush on with a speed of ninety miles an hour.  It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.
children.prevalue: The wind however did not grow as boisterous as might have been feared it was not one of those tempests which burst and rush on with a speed of ninety miles an hour It continued fresh but unhappily it remained obstinately in the south east rendering the sails useless

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg's departure from London, and the Henrietta had not yet been seriously delayed.  Half of the voyage was almost accomplished, and the worst localities had been passed.  In summer, success would have been well-nigh certain.  In winter, they were at the mercy of the bad season.  Passepartout said nothing; but he cherished hope in secret, and comforted himself with the reflection that, if the wind failed them, they might still count on the steam.
children.prevalue: The 16th of December was the seventy fifth day since Phileas Fogg s departure from London and the Henrietta had not yet been seriously delayed Half of the voyage was almost accomplished and the worst localities had been passed In summer success would have been well nigh certain In winter they were at the mercy of the bad season Passepartout said nothing but he cherished hope in secret and comforted himself with the reflection that if the wind failed them they might still count on the steam

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: On this day the engineer came on deck, went up to Mr. Fogg, and began to speak earnestly with him.  Without knowing why it was a presentiment, perhaps Passepartout became vaguely uneasy.  He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying.  He finally managed to catch a few words, and was sure he heard his master say, You are certain of what you tell me?
children.prevalue: On this day the engineer came on deck went up to Mr Fogg and began to speak earnestly with him Without knowing why it was a presentiment perhaps Passepartout became vaguely uneasy He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying He finally managed to catch a few words and was sure he heard his master say You are certain of what you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Certain, sir, replied the engineer.  You must remember that, since we started, we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces, and, though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux, we haven't enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool. I will consider, replied Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Certain sir replied the engineer You must remember that since we started we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces and though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux we haven t enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool I will consider replied Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Passepartout understood it all; he was seized with mortal anxiety.  The coal was giving out!  Ah, if my master can get over that, muttered he, he'll be a famous man!  He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard.
children.prevalue: Passepartout understood it all he was seized with mortal anxiety The coal was giving out Ah if my master can get over that muttered he he ll be a famous man He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then you believe that we really are going to Liverpool?
children.prevalue: Then you believe that we really are going to Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Of course.
children.prevalue: Of course

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ass! replied the detective, shrugging his shoulders and turning on his heel.
children.prevalue: Ass replied the detective shrugging his shoulders and turning on his heel

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self esteem after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world and refrained

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt?  It was difficult to imagine.  Nevertheless he seemed to have decided upon one, for that evening he sent for the engineer, and said to him, Feed all the fires until the coal is exhausted.
children.prevalue: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt It was difficult to imagine Nevertheless he seemed to have decided upon one for that evening he sent for the engineer and said to him Feed all the fires until the coal is exhausted

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: A few moments after, the funnel of the Henrietta vomited forth torrents of smoke.  The vessel continued to proceed with all steam on; but on the 18th, the engineer, as he had predicted, announced that the coal would give out in the course of the day.
children.prevalue: A few moments after the funnel of the Henrietta vomited forth torrents of smoke The vessel continued to proceed with all steam on but on the 18th the engineer as he had predicted announced that the coal would give out in the course of the day

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Do not let the fires go down, replied Mr. Fogg.  Keep them up to the last.  Let the valves be filled.
children.prevalue: Do not let the fires go down replied Mr Fogg Keep them up to the last Let the valves be filled

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Towards noon Phileas Fogg, having ascertained their position, called Passepartout, and ordered him to go for Captain Speedy.  It was as if the honest fellow had been commanded to unchain a tiger.  He went to the poop, saying to himself, He will be like a madman!
children.prevalue: Towards noon Phileas Fogg having ascertained their position called Passepartout and ordered him to go for Captain Speedy It was as if the honest fellow had been commanded to unchain a tiger He went to the poop saying to himself He will be like a madman

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In a few moments, with cries and oaths, a bomb appeared on the poop-deck.  The bomb was Captain Speedy.  It was clear that he was on the point of bursting.  Where are we?  were the first words his anger permitted him to utter.  Had the poor man been an apoplectic, he could never have recovered from his paroxysm of wrath.
children.prevalue: In a few moments with cries and oaths a bomb appeared on the poop deck The bomb was Captain Speedy It was clear that he was on the point of bursting Where are we were the first words his anger permitted him to utter Had the poor man been an apoplectic he could never have recovered from his paroxysm of wrath

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Where are we? he repeated, with purple face.
children.prevalue: Where are we he repeated with purple face

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Seven hundred and seven miles from Liverpool, replied Mr. Fogg, with imperturbable calmness.
children.prevalue: Seven hundred and seven miles from Liverpool replied Mr Fogg with imperturbable calmness

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Pirate! cried Captain Speedy.
children.prevalue: Pirate cried Captain Speedy

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I have sent for you, sir--
children.prevalue: I have sent for you sir

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Pickaroon!
children.prevalue: Pickaroon

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: --sir, continued Mr. Fogg, to ask you to sell me your vessel.
children.prevalue: sir continued Mr Fogg to ask you to sell me your vessel

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No!  By all the devils, no!
children.prevalue: No By all the devils no

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But I shall be obliged to burn her.
children.prevalue: But I shall be obliged to burn her

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Burn the Henrietta!
children.prevalue: Burn the Henrietta

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes; at least the upper part of her.  The coal has given out.
children.prevalue: Yes at least the upper part of her The coal has given out

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Burn my vessel! cried Captain Speedy, who could scarcely pronounce the words.  A vessel worth fifty thousand dollars!
children.prevalue: Burn my vessel cried Captain Speedy who could scarcely pronounce the words A vessel worth fifty thousand dollars

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Here are sixty thousand, replied Phileas Fogg, handing the captain a roll of bank-bills.  This had a prodigious effect on Andrew Speedy.  An American can scarcely remain unmoved at the sight of sixty thousand dollars.  The captain forgot in an instant his anger, his imprisonment, and all his grudges against his passenger.  The Henrietta was twenty years old; it was a great bargain.  The bomb would not go off after all.  Mr. Fogg had taken away the match.
children.prevalue: Here are sixty thousand replied Phileas Fogg handing the captain a roll of bank bills This had a prodigious effect on Andrew Speedy An American can scarcely remain unmoved at the sight of sixty thousand dollars The captain forgot in an instant his anger his imprisonment and all his grudges against his passenger The Henrietta was twenty years old it was a great bargain The bomb would not go off after all Mr Fogg had taken away the match

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And I shall still have the iron hull, said the captain in a softer tone.
children.prevalue: And I shall still have the iron hull said the captain in a softer tone

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The iron hull and the engine.  Is it agreed?
children.prevalue: The iron hull and the engine Is it agreed

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Agreed.
children.prevalue: Agreed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And Andrew Speedy, seizing the banknotes, counted them and consigned them to his pocket.
children.prevalue: And Andrew Speedy seizing the banknotes counted them and consigned them to his pocket

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: During this colloquy, Passepartout was as white as a sheet, and Fix seemed on the point of having an apoplectic fit.  Nearly twenty thousand pounds had been expended, and Fogg left the hull and engine to the captain, that is, near the whole value of the craft!  It was true, however, that fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank.
children.prevalue: During this colloquy Passepartout was as white as a sheet and Fix seemed on the point of having an apoplectic fit Nearly twenty thousand pounds had been expended and Fogg left the hull and engine to the captain that is near the whole value of the craft It was true however that fifty five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, Don't let this astonish you, sir.  You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds, unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December.  I missed the steamer at New York, and as you refused to take me to Liverpool--
children.prevalue: When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money Mr Fogg said to him Don t let this astonish you sir You must know that I shall lose twenty thousand pounds unless I arrive in London by a quarter before nine on the evening of the 21st of December I missed the steamer at New York and as you refused to take me to Liverpool

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And I did well! cried Andrew Speedy; for I have gained at least forty thousand dollars by it!  He added, more sedately, Do you know one thing, Captain--
children.prevalue: And I did well cried Andrew Speedy for I have gained at least forty thousand dollars by it He added more sedately Do you know one thing Captain

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Fogg.
children.prevalue: Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Captain Fogg, you've got something of the Yankee about you.
children.prevalue: Captain Fogg you ve got something of the Yankee about you

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And, having paid his passenger what he considered a high compliment, he was going away, when Mr. Fogg said, The vessel now belongs to me?
children.prevalue: And having paid his passenger what he considered a high compliment he was going away when Mr Fogg said The vessel now belongs to me

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Certainly, from the keel to the truck of the masts--all the wood, that is.
children.prevalue: Certainly from the keel to the truck of the masts all the wood that is

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Very well.  Have the interior seats, bunks, and frames pulled down, and burn them.
children.prevalue: Very well Have the interior seats bunks and frames pulled down and burn them

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It was necessary to have dry wood to keep the steam up to the adequate pressure, and on that day the poop, cabins, bunks, and the spare deck were sacrificed.  On the next day, the 19th of December, the masts, rafts, and spars were burned; the crew worked lustily, keeping up the fires.  Passepartout hewed, cut, and sawed away with all his might. There was a perfect rage for demolition.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to have dry wood to keep the steam up to the adequate pressure and on that day the poop cabins bunks and the spare deck were sacrificed On the next day the 19th of December the masts rafts and spars were burned the crew worked lustily keeping up the fires Passepartout hewed cut and sawed away with all his might There was a perfect rage for demolition

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The railings, fittings, the greater part of the deck, and top sides disappeared on the 20th, and the Henrietta was now only a flat hulk. But on this day they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light.  By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown.  Phileas Fogg had only twenty-four hours more in which to get to London; that length of time was necessary to reach Liverpool, with all steam on.  And the steam was about to give out altogether!
children.prevalue: The railings fittings the greater part of the deck and top sides disappeared on the 20th and the Henrietta was now only a flat hulk But on this day they sighted the Irish coast and Fastnet Light By ten in the evening they were passing Queenstown Phileas Fogg had only twenty four hours more in which to get to London that length of time was necessary to reach Liverpool with all steam on And the steam was about to give out altogether

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Sir, said Captain Speedy, who was now deeply interested in Mr. Fogg's project, I really commiserate you.  Everything is against you.  We are only opposite Queenstown.
children.prevalue: Sir said Captain Speedy who was now deeply interested in Mr Fogg s project I really commiserate you Everything is against you We are only opposite Queenstown

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Ah, said Mr. Fogg, is that place where we see the lights Queenstown?
children.prevalue: Ah said Mr Fogg is that place where we see the lights Queenstown

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Can we enter the harbour?
children.prevalue: Can we enter the harbour

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Not under three hours.  Only at high tide.
children.prevalue: Not under three hours Only at high tide

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Stay, replied Mr. Fogg calmly, without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill-fortune.
children.prevalue: Stay replied Mr Fogg calmly without betraying in his features that by a supreme inspiration he was about to attempt once more to conquer ill fortune

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Queenstown is the Irish port at which the trans-Atlantic steamers stop to put off the mails.  These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness to start; from Dublin they are sent on to Liverpool by the most rapid boats, and thus gain twelve hours on the Atlantic steamers.
children.prevalue: Queenstown is the Irish port at which the trans Atlantic steamers stop to put off the mails These mails are carried to Dublin by express trains always held in readiness to start from Dublin they are sent on to Liverpool by the most rapid boats and thus gain twelve hours on the Atlantic steamers

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way.  Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the Henrietta, he would be there by noon, and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg counted on gaining twelve hours in the same way Instead of arriving at Liverpool the next evening by the Henrietta he would be there by noon and would therefore have time to reach London before a quarter before nine in the evening

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: The Henrietta entered Queenstown Harbour at one o'clock in the morning, it then being high tide; and Phileas Fogg, after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy, left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft, which was still worth half what he had sold it for.
children.prevalue: The Henrietta entered Queenstown Harbour at one o clock in the morning it then being high tide and Phileas Fogg after being grasped heartily by the hand by Captain Speedy left that gentleman on the levelled hulk of his craft which was still worth half what he had sold it for

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The party went on shore at once.  Fix was greatly tempted to arrest Mr. Fogg on the spot; but he did not.  Why?  What struggle was going on within him?  Had he changed his mind about his man?  Did he understand that he had made a grave mistake?  He did not, however, abandon Mr. Fogg.  They all got upon the train, which was just ready to start, at half-past one; at dawn of day they were in Dublin; and they lost no time in embarking on a steamer which, disdaining to rise upon the waves, invariably cut through them.
children.prevalue: The party went on shore at once Fix was greatly tempted to arrest Mr Fogg on the spot but he did not Why What struggle was going on within him Had he changed his mind about his man Did he understand that he had made a grave mistake He did not however abandon Mr Fogg They all got upon the train which was just ready to start at half past one at dawn of day they were in Dublin and they lost no time in embarking on a steamer which disdaining to rise upon the waves invariably cut through them

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Phileas Fogg at last disembarked on the Liverpool quay, at twenty minutes before twelve, 21st December.  He was only six hours distant from London.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg at last disembarked on the Liverpool quay at twenty minutes before twelve 21st December He was only six hours distant from London

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: But at this moment Fix came up, put his hand upon Mr. Fogg's shoulder, and, showing his warrant, said, You are really Phileas Fogg?
children.prevalue: But at this moment Fix came up put his hand upon Mr Fogg s shoulder and showing his warrant said You are really Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: I am.
children.prevalue: I am

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I arrest you in the Queen's name!
children.prevalue: I arrest you in the Queen s name

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AT LAST REACHES LONDON
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AT LAST REACHES LONDON

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Phileas Fogg was in prison.  He had been shut up in the Custom House, and he was to be transferred to London the next day.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg was in prison He had been shut up in the Custom House and he was to be transferred to London the next day

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Passepartout, when he saw his master arrested, would have fallen upon Fix had he not been held back by some policemen.  Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand.  Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a robber.  The young woman's heart revolted against so heinous a charge, and when she saw that she could attempt to do nothing to save her protector, she wept bitterly.
children.prevalue: Passepartout when he saw his master arrested would have fallen upon Fix had he not been held back by some policemen Aouda was thunderstruck at the suddenness of an event which she could not understand Passepartout explained to her how it was that the honest and courageous Fogg was arrested as a robber The young woman s heart revolted against so heinous a charge and when she saw that she could attempt to do nothing to save her protector she wept bitterly

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As for Fix, he had arrested Mr. Fogg because it was his duty, whether Mr. Fogg were guilty or not.
children.prevalue: As for Fix he had arrested Mr Fogg because it was his duty whether Mr Fogg were guilty or not

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The thought then struck Passepartout, that he was the cause of this new misfortune!  Had he not concealed Fix's errand from his master?  When Fix revealed his true character and purpose, why had he not told Mr. Fogg?  If the latter had been warned, he would no doubt have given Fix proof of his innocence, and satisfied him of his mistake; at least, Fix would not have continued his journey at the expense and on the heels of his master, only to arrest him the moment he set foot on English soil. Passepartout wept till he was blind, and felt like blowing his brains out.
children.prevalue: The thought then struck Passepartout that he was the cause of this new misfortune Had he not concealed Fix s errand from his master When Fix revealed his true character and purpose why had he not told Mr Fogg If the latter had been warned he would no doubt have given Fix proof of his innocence and satisfied him of his mistake at least Fix would not have continued his journey at the expense and on the heels of his master only to arrest him the moment he set foot on English soil Passepartout wept till he was blind and felt like blowing his brains out

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Aouda and he had remained, despite the cold, under the portico of the Custom House.  Neither wished to leave the place; both were anxious to see Mr. Fogg again.
children.prevalue: Aouda and he had remained despite the cold under the portico of the Custom House Neither wished to leave the place both were anxious to see Mr Fogg again

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: That gentleman was really ruined, and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end.  This arrest was fatal.  Having arrived at Liverpool at twenty minutes before twelve on the 21st of December, he had till a quarter before nine that evening to reach the Reform Club, that is, nine hours and a quarter; the journey from Liverpool to London was six hours.
children.prevalue: That gentleman was really ruined and that at the moment when he was about to attain his end This arrest was fatal Having arrived at Liverpool at twenty minutes before twelve on the 21st of December he had till a quarter before nine that evening to reach the Reform Club that is nine hours and a quarter the journey from Liverpool to London was six hours

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: If anyone, at this moment, had entered the Custom House, he would have found Mr. Fogg seated, motionless, calm, and without apparent anger, upon a wooden bench.  He was not, it is true, resigned; but this last blow failed to force him into an outward betrayal of any emotion.  Was he being devoured by one of those secret rages, all the more terrible because contained, and which only burst forth, with an irresistible force, at the last moment?  No one could tell.  There he sat, calmly waiting--for what?  Did he still cherish hope?  Did he still believe, now that the door of this prison was closed upon him, that he would succeed?
children.prevalue: If anyone at this moment had entered the Custom House he would have found Mr Fogg seated motionless calm and without apparent anger upon a wooden bench He was not it is true resigned but this last blow failed to force him into an outward betrayal of any emotion Was he being devoured by one of those secret rages all the more terrible because contained and which only burst forth with an irresistible force at the last moment No one could tell There he sat calmly waiting for what Did he still cherish hope Did he still believe now that the door of this prison was closed upon him that he would succeed

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: However that may have been, Mr. Fogg carefully put his watch upon the table, and observed its advancing hands.  Not a word escaped his lips, but his look was singularly set and stern.  The situation, in any event, was a terrible one, and might be thus stated: if Phileas Fogg was honest he was ruined; if he was a knave, he was caught.
children.prevalue: However that may have been Mr Fogg carefully put his watch upon the table and observed its advancing hands Not a word escaped his lips but his look was singularly set and stern The situation in any event was a terrible one and might be thus stated if Phileas Fogg was honest he was ruined if he was a knave he was caught

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Did escape occur to him?  Did he examine to see if there were any practicable outlet from his prison?  Did he think of escaping from it? Possibly; for once he walked slowly around the room.  But the door was locked, and the window heavily barred with iron rods.  He sat down again, and drew his journal from his pocket.  On the line where these words were written, 21st December, Saturday, Liverpool, he added, 80th day, 11.40 a.m., and waited.
children.prevalue: Did escape occur to him Did he examine to see if there were any practicable outlet from his prison Did he think of escaping from it Possibly for once he walked slowly around the room But the door was locked and the window heavily barred with iron rods He sat down again and drew his journal from his pocket On the line where these words were written 21st December Saturday Liverpool he added 80th day 11 40 a m and waited

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The Custom House clock struck one.  Mr. Fogg observed that his watch was two hours too fast.
children.prevalue: The Custom House clock struck one Mr Fogg observed that his watch was two hours too fast

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Two hours!  Admitting that he was at this moment taking an express train, he could reach London and the Reform Club by a quarter before nine, p.m.  His forehead slightly wrinkled.
children.prevalue: Two hours Admitting that he was at this moment taking an express train he could reach London and the Reform Club by a quarter before nine p m His forehead slightly wrinkled

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: At thirty-three minutes past two he heard a singular noise outside, then a hasty opening of doors.  Passepartout's voice was audible, and immediately after that of Fix.  Phileas Fogg's eyes brightened for an instant.
children.prevalue: At thirty three minutes past two he heard a singular noise outside then a hasty opening of doors Passepartout s voice was audible and immediately after that of Fix Phileas Fogg s eyes brightened for an instant

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The door swung open, and he saw Passepartout, Aouda, and Fix, who hurried towards him.
children.prevalue: The door swung open and he saw Passepartout Aouda and Fix who hurried towards him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Fix was out of breath, and his hair was in disorder.  He could not speak.  Sir, he stammered, sir--forgive me--most--unfortunate resemblance--robber arrested three days ago--you are free!
children.prevalue: Fix was out of breath and his hair was in disorder He could not speak Sir he stammered sir forgive me most unfortunate resemblance robber arrested three days ago you are free

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Phileas Fogg was free!  He walked to the detective, looked him steadily in the face, and with the only rapid motion he had ever made in his life, or which he ever would make, drew back his arms, and with the precision of a machine knocked Fix down.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg was free He walked to the detective looked him steadily in the face and with the only rapid motion he had ever made in his life or which he ever would make drew back his arms and with the precision of a machine knocked Fix down

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Well hit! cried Passepartout, Parbleu! that's what you might call a good application of English fists!
children.prevalue: Well hit cried Passepartout Parbleu that s what you might call a good application of English fists

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Fix, who found himself on the floor, did not utter a word.  He had only received his deserts.  Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay, got into a cab, and in a few moments descended at the station.
children.prevalue: Fix who found himself on the floor did not utter a word He had only received his deserts Mr Fogg Aouda and Passepartout left the Custom House without delay got into a cab and in a few moments descended at the station

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Phileas Fogg asked if there was an express train about to leave for London.  It was forty minutes past two.  The express train had left thirty-five minutes before.  Phileas Fogg then ordered a special train.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg asked if there was an express train about to leave for London It was forty minutes past two The express train had left thirty five minutes before Phileas Fogg then ordered a special train

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: There were several rapid locomotives on hand; but the railway arrangements did not permit the special train to leave until three o'clock.
children.prevalue: There were several rapid locomotives on hand but the railway arrangements did not permit the special train to leave until three o clock

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At that hour Phileas Fogg, having stimulated the engineer by the offer of a generous reward, at last set out towards London with Aouda and his faithful servant.
children.prevalue: At that hour Phileas Fogg having stimulated the engineer by the offer of a generous reward at last set out towards London with Aouda and his faithful servant

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It was necessary to make the journey in five hours and a half; and this would have been easy on a clear road throughout.  But there were forced delays, and when Mr. Fogg stepped from the train at the terminus, all the clocks in London were striking ten minutes before nine.
children.prevalue: It was necessary to make the journey in five hours and a half and this would have been easy on a clear road throughout But there were forced delays and when Mr Fogg stepped from the train at the terminus all the clocks in London were striking ten minutes before nine

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Having made the tour of the world, he was behind-hand five minutes.  He had lost the wager!
children.prevalue: Having made the tour of the world he was behind hand five minutes He had lost the wager

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DOES NOT HAVE TO REPEAT HIS ORDERS TO PASSEPARTOUT TWICE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DOES NOT HAVE TO REPEAT HIS ORDERS TO PASSEPARTOUT TWICE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day, if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home.  His doors and windows were still closed, no appearance of change was visible.
children.prevalue: The dwellers in Saville Row would have been surprised the next day if they had been told that Phileas Fogg had returned home His doors and windows were still closed no appearance of change was visible

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: After leaving the station, Mr. Fogg gave Passepartout instructions to purchase some provisions, and quietly went to his domicile.
children.prevalue: After leaving the station Mr Fogg gave Passepartout instructions to purchase some provisions and quietly went to his domicile

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He bore his misfortune with his habitual tranquillity.  Ruined!  And by the blundering of the detective!  After having steadily traversed that long journey, overcome a hundred obstacles, braved many dangers, and still found time to do some good on his way, to fail near the goal by a sudden event which he could not have foreseen, and against which he was unarmed; it was terrible!  But a few pounds were left of the large sum he had carried with him.  There only remained of his fortune the twenty thousand pounds deposited at Barings, and this amount he owed to his friends of the Reform Club.  So great had been the expense of his tour that, even had he won, it would not have enriched him; and it is probable that he had not sought to enrich himself, being a man who rather laid wagers for honour's sake than for the stake proposed.  But this wager totally ruined him.
children.prevalue: He bore his misfortune with his habitual tranquillity Ruined And by the blundering of the detective After having steadily traversed that long journey overcome a hundred obstacles braved many dangers and still found time to do some good on his way to fail near the goal by a sudden event which he could not have foreseen and against which he was unarmed it was terrible But a few pounds were left of the large sum he had carried with him There only remained of his fortune the twenty thousand pounds deposited at Barings and this amount he owed to his friends of the Reform Club So great had been the expense of his tour that even had he won it would not have enriched him and it is probable that he had not sought to enrich himself being a man who rather laid wagers for honour s sake than for the stake proposed But this wager totally ruined him

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Mr. Fogg's course, however, was fully decided upon; he knew what remained for him to do.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg s course however was fully decided upon he knew what remained for him to do

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda, who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector's misfortune.  From the words which Mr. Fogg dropped, she saw that he was meditating some serious project.
children.prevalue: A room in the house in Saville Row was set apart for Aouda who was overwhelmed with grief at her protector s misfortune From the words which Mr Fogg dropped she saw that he was meditating some serious project

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Knowing that Englishmen governed by a fixed idea sometimes resort to the desperate expedient of suicide, Passepartout kept a narrow watch upon his master, though he carefully concealed the appearance of so doing.
children.prevalue: Knowing that Englishmen governed by a fixed idea sometimes resort to the desperate expedient of suicide Passepartout kept a narrow watch upon his master though he carefully concealed the appearance of so doing

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: First of all, the worthy fellow had gone up to his room, and had extinguished the gas burner, which had been burning for eighty days. He had found in the letter-box a bill from the gas company, and he thought it more than time to put a stop to this expense, which he had been doomed to bear.
children.prevalue: First of all the worthy fellow had gone up to his room and had extinguished the gas burner which had been burning for eighty days He had found in the letter box a bill from the gas company and he thought it more than time to put a stop to this expense which he had been doomed to bear

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The night passed.  Mr. Fogg went to bed, but did he sleep?  Aouda did not once close her eyes.  Passepartout watched all night, like a faithful dog, at his master's door.
children.prevalue: The night passed Mr Fogg went to bed but did he sleep Aouda did not once close her eyes Passepartout watched all night like a faithful dog at his master s door

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Mr. Fogg called him in the morning, and told him to get Aouda's breakfast, and a cup of tea and a chop for himself.  He desired Aouda to excuse him from breakfast and dinner, as his time would be absorbed all day in putting his affairs to rights.  In the evening he would ask permission to have a few moment's conversation with the young lady.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg called him in the morning and told him to get Aouda s breakfast and a cup of tea and a chop for himself He desired Aouda to excuse him from breakfast and dinner as his time would be absorbed all day in putting his affairs to rights In the evening he would ask permission to have a few moment s conversation with the young lady

children.name: Paragraph_11
