children.value: Passepartout, having received his orders, had nothing to do but obey them.  He looked at his imperturbable master, and could scarcely bring his mind to leave him.  His heart was full, and his conscience tortured by remorse; for he accused himself more bitterly than ever of being the cause of the irretrievable disaster.  Yes! if he had warned Mr. Fogg, and had betrayed Fix's projects to him, his master would certainly not have given the detective passage to Liverpool, and then--
children.prevalue: Passepartout having received his orders had nothing to do but obey them He looked at his imperturbable master and could scarcely bring his mind to leave him His heart was full and his conscience tortured by remorse for he accused himself more bitterly than ever of being the cause of the irretrievable disaster Yes if he had warned Mr Fogg and had betrayed Fix s projects to him his master would certainly not have given the detective passage to Liverpool and then

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Passepartout could hold in no longer.
children.prevalue: Passepartout could hold in no longer

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My master!  Mr. Fogg! he cried, why do you not curse me?  It was my fault that--
children.prevalue: My master Mr Fogg he cried why do you not curse me It was my fault that

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I blame no one, returned Phileas Fogg, with perfect calmness.  Go!
children.prevalue: I blame no one returned Phileas Fogg with perfect calmness Go

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master's message.
children.prevalue: Passepartout left the room and went to find Aouda to whom he delivered his master s message

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Madam, he added, I can do nothing myself--nothing!  I have no influence over my master; but you, perhaps--
children.prevalue: Madam he added I can do nothing myself nothing I have no influence over my master but you perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What influence could I have? replied Aouda.  Mr. Fogg is influenced by no one.  Has he ever understood that my gratitude to him is overflowing?  Has he ever read my heart?  My friend, he must not be left alone an instant!  You say he is going to speak with me this evening?
children.prevalue: What influence could I have replied Aouda Mr Fogg is influenced by no one Has he ever understood that my gratitude to him is overflowing Has he ever read my heart My friend he must not be left alone an instant You say he is going to speak with me this evening

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, madam; probably to arrange for your protection and comfort in England.
children.prevalue: Yes madam probably to arrange for your protection and comfort in England

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: We shall see, replied Aouda, becoming suddenly pensive.
children.prevalue: We shall see replied Aouda becoming suddenly pensive

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Throughout this day (Sunday) the house in Saville Row was as if uninhabited, and Phileas Fogg, for the first time since he had lived in that house, did not set out for his club when Westminster clock struck half-past eleven.
children.prevalue: Throughout this day Sunday the house in Saville Row was as if uninhabited and Phileas Fogg for the first time since he had lived in that house did not set out for his club when Westminster clock struck half past eleven

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Why should he present himself at the Reform?  His friends no longer expected him there.  As Phileas Fogg had not appeared in the saloon on the evening before (Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine), he had lost his wager.  It was not even necessary that he should go to his bankers for the twenty thousand pounds; for his antagonists already had his cheque in their hands, and they had only to fill it out and send it to the Barings to have the amount transferred to their credit.
children.prevalue: Why should he present himself at the Reform His friends no longer expected him there As Phileas Fogg had not appeared in the saloon on the evening before Saturday the 21st of December at a quarter before nine he had lost his wager It was not even necessary that he should go to his bankers for the twenty thousand pounds for his antagonists already had his cheque in their hands and they had only to fill it out and send it to the Barings to have the amount transferred to their credit

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Mr. Fogg, therefore, had no reason for going out, and so he remained at home.  He shut himself up in his room, and busied himself putting his affairs in order.  Passepartout continually ascended and descended the stairs.  The hours were long for him. He listened at his master's door, and looked through the keyhole, as if he had a perfect right so to do, and as if he feared that something terrible might happen at any moment. Sometimes he thought of Fix, but no longer in anger.  Fix, like all the world, had been mistaken in Phileas Fogg, and had only done his duty in tracking and arresting him; while he, Passepartout. . . .  This thought haunted him, and he never ceased cursing his miserable folly.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg therefore had no reason for going out and so he remained at home He shut himself up in his room and busied himself putting his affairs in order Passepartout continually ascended and descended the stairs The hours were long for him He listened at his master s door and looked through the keyhole as if he had a perfect right so to do and as if he feared that something terrible might happen at any moment Sometimes he thought of Fix but no longer in anger Fix like all the world had been mistaken in Phileas Fogg and had only done his duty in tracking and arresting him while he Passepartout This thought haunted him and he never ceased cursing his miserable folly

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Finding himself too wretched to remain alone, he knocked at Aouda's door, went into her room, seated himself, without speaking, in a corner, and looked ruefully at the young woman. Aouda was still pensive.
children.prevalue: Finding himself too wretched to remain alone he knocked at Aouda s door went into her room seated himself without speaking in a corner and looked ruefully at the young woman Aouda was still pensive

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
children.prevalue: About half past seven in the evening Mr Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him and in a few moments he found himself alone with her

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Phileas Fogg took a chair, and sat down near the fireplace, opposite Aouda.  No emotion was visible on his face.  Fogg returned was exactly the Fogg who had gone away; there was the same calm, the same impassibility.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg took a chair and sat down near the fireplace opposite Aouda No emotion was visible on his face Fogg returned was exactly the Fogg who had gone away there was the same calm the same impassibility

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: He sat several minutes without speaking; then, bending his eyes on Aouda, Madam, said he, will you pardon me for bringing you to England?
children.prevalue: He sat several minutes without speaking then bending his eyes on Aouda Madam said he will you pardon me for bringing you to England

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I, Mr. Fogg! replied Aouda, checking the pulsations of her heart.
children.prevalue: I Mr Fogg replied Aouda checking the pulsations of her heart

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Please let me finish, returned Mr. Fogg.  When I decided to bring you far away from the country which was so unsafe for you, I was rich, and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal; then your existence would have been free and happy.  But now I am ruined.
children.prevalue: Please let me finish returned Mr Fogg When I decided to bring you far away from the country which was so unsafe for you I was rich and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal then your existence would have been free and happy But now I am ruined

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I know it, Mr. Fogg, replied Aouda; and I ask you in my turn, will you forgive me for having followed you, and--who knows?--for having, perhaps, delayed you, and thus contributed to your ruin?
children.prevalue: I know it Mr Fogg replied Aouda and I ask you in my turn will you forgive me for having followed you and who knows for having perhaps delayed you and thus contributed to your ruin

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Madam, you could not remain in India, and your safety could only be assured by bringing you to such a distance that your persecutors could not take you.
children.prevalue: Madam you could not remain in India and your safety could only be assured by bringing you to such a distance that your persecutors could not take you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: So, Mr. Fogg, resumed Aouda, not content with rescuing me from a terrible death, you thought yourself bound to secure my comfort in a foreign land?
children.prevalue: So Mr Fogg resumed Aouda not content with rescuing me from a terrible death you thought yourself bound to secure my comfort in a foreign land

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, madam; but circumstances have been against me.  Still, I beg to place the little I have left at your service.
children.prevalue: Yes madam but circumstances have been against me Still I beg to place the little I have left at your service

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But what will become of you, Mr. Fogg?
children.prevalue: But what will become of you Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: As for me, madam, replied the gentleman, coldly, I have need of nothing.
children.prevalue: As for me madam replied the gentleman coldly I have need of nothing

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But how do you look upon the fate, sir, which awaits you?
children.prevalue: But how do you look upon the fate sir which awaits you

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: As I am in the habit of doing.
children.prevalue: As I am in the habit of doing

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: At least, said Aouda, want should not overtake a man like you.  Your friends--
children.prevalue: At least said Aouda want should not overtake a man like you Your friends

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I have no friends, madam.
children.prevalue: I have no friends madam

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Your relatives--
children.prevalue: Your relatives

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I have no longer any relatives.
children.prevalue: I have no longer any relatives

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I pity you, then, Mr. Fogg, for solitude is a sad thing, with no heart to which to confide your griefs.  They say, though, that misery itself, shared by two sympathetic souls, may be borne with patience.
children.prevalue: I pity you then Mr Fogg for solitude is a sad thing with no heart to which to confide your griefs They say though that misery itself shared by two sympathetic souls may be borne with patience

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: They say so, madam.
children.prevalue: They say so madam

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Mr. Fogg, said Aouda, rising and seizing his hand, do you wish at once a kinswoman and friend?  Will you have me for your wife?
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg said Aouda rising and seizing his hand do you wish at once a kinswoman and friend Will you have me for your wife

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Mr. Fogg, at this, rose in his turn.  There was an unwonted light in his eyes, and a slight trembling of his lips.  Aouda looked into his face.  The sincerity, rectitude, firmness, and sweetness of this soft glance of a noble woman, who could dare all to save him to whom she owed all, at first astonished, then penetrated him.  He shut his eyes for an instant, as if to avoid her look.  When he opened them again, I love you! he said, simply.  Yes, by all that is holiest, I love you, and I am entirely yours!
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg at this rose in his turn There was an unwonted light in his eyes and a slight trembling of his lips Aouda looked into his face The sincerity rectitude firmness and sweetness of this soft glance of a noble woman who could dare all to save him to whom she owed all at first astonished then penetrated him He shut his eyes for an instant as if to avoid her look When he opened them again I love you he said simply Yes by all that is holiest I love you and I am entirely yours

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Ah! cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.
children.prevalue: Ah cried Aouda pressing his hand to her heart

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately.  Mr. Fogg still held Aouda's hand in his own; Passepartout understood, and his big, round face became as radiant as the tropical sun at its zenith.
children.prevalue: Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately Mr Fogg still held Aouda s hand in his own Passepartout understood and his big round face became as radiant as the tropical sun at its zenith

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Mr. Fogg asked him if it was not too late to notify the Reverend Samuel Wilson, of Marylebone parish, that evening.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg asked him if it was not too late to notify the Reverend Samuel Wilson of Marylebone parish that evening

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Passepartout smiled his most genial smile, and said, Never too late.
children.prevalue: Passepartout smiled his most genial smile and said Never too late

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It was five minutes past eight.
children.prevalue: It was five minutes past eight

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Will it be for to-morrow, Monday?
children.prevalue: Will it be for to morrow Monday

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: For to-morrow, Monday, said Mr. Fogg, turning to Aouda.
children.prevalue: For to morrow Monday said Mr Fogg turning to Aouda

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes; for to-morrow, Monday, she replied.
children.prevalue: Yes for to morrow Monday she replied

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.
children.prevalue: Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG'S NAME IS ONCE MORE AT A PREMIUM ON 'CHANGE
children.prevalue: IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG S NAME IS ONCE MORE AT A PREMIUM ON CHANGE

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh.  Three days before, Phileas Fogg had been a criminal, who was being desperately followed up by the police; now he was an honourable gentleman, mathematically pursuing his eccentric journey round the world.
children.prevalue: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber a certain James Strand had been arrested on the 17th day of December at Edinburgh Three days before Phileas Fogg had been a criminal who was being desperately followed up by the police now he was an honourable gentleman mathematically pursuing his eccentric journey round the world

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The papers resumed their discussion about the wager; all those who had laid bets, for or against him, revived their interest, as if by magic; the Phileas Fogg bonds again became negotiable, and many new wagers were made.  Phileas Fogg's name was once more at a premium on 'Change.
children.prevalue: The papers resumed their discussion about the wager all those who had laid bets for or against him revived their interest as if by magic the Phileas Fogg bonds again became negotiable and many new wagers were made Phileas Fogg s name was once more at a premium on Change

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense.  Would Phileas Fogg, whom they had forgotten, reappear before their eyes!  Where was he at this moment?  The 17th of December, the day of James Strand's arrest, was the seventy-sixth since Phileas Fogg's departure, and no news of him had been received.  Was he dead?  Had he abandoned the effort, or was he continuing his journey along the route agreed upon?  And would he appear on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine in the evening, on the threshold of the Reform Club saloon?
children.prevalue: His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense Would Phileas Fogg whom they had forgotten reappear before their eyes Where was he at this moment The 17th of December the day of James Strand s arrest was the seventy sixth since Phileas Fogg s departure and no news of him had been received Was he dead Had he abandoned the effort or was he continuing his journey along the route agreed upon And would he appear on Saturday the 21st of December at a quarter before nine in the evening on the threshold of the Reform Club saloon

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The anxiety in which, for three days, London society existed, cannot be described.  Telegrams were sent to America and Asia for news of Phileas Fogg.  Messengers were dispatched to the house in Saville Row morning and evening.  No news.  The police were ignorant what had become of the detective, Fix, who had so unfortunately followed up a false scent. Bets increased, nevertheless, in number and value.  Phileas Fogg, like a racehorse, was drawing near his last turning-point.  The bonds were quoted, no longer at a hundred below par, but at twenty, at ten, and at five; and paralytic old Lord Albemarle bet even in his favour.
children.prevalue: The anxiety in which for three days London society existed cannot be described Telegrams were sent to America and Asia for news of Phileas Fogg Messengers were dispatched to the house in Saville Row morning and evening No news The police were ignorant what had become of the detective Fix who had so unfortunately followed up a false scent Bets increased nevertheless in number and value Phileas Fogg like a racehorse was drawing near his last turning point The bonds were quoted no longer at a hundred below par but at twenty at ten and at five and paralytic old Lord Albemarle bet even in his favour

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: A great crowd was collected in Pall Mall and the neighbouring streets on Saturday evening; it seemed like a multitude of brokers permanently established around the Reform Club.  Circulation was impeded, and everywhere disputes, discussions, and financial transactions were going on.  The police had great difficulty in keeping back the crowd, and as the hour when Phileas Fogg was due approached, the excitement rose to its highest pitch.
children.prevalue: A great crowd was collected in Pall Mall and the neighbouring streets on Saturday evening it seemed like a multitude of brokers permanently established around the Reform Club Circulation was impeded and everywhere disputes discussions and financial transactions were going on The police had great difficulty in keeping back the crowd and as the hour when Phileas Fogg was due approached the excitement rose to its highest pitch

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The five antagonists of Phileas Fogg had met in the great saloon of the club.  John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, the bankers, Andrew Stuart, the engineer, Gauthier Ralph, the director of the Bank of England, and Thomas Flanagan, the brewer, one and all waited anxiously.
children.prevalue: The five antagonists of Phileas Fogg had met in the great saloon of the club John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin the bankers Andrew Stuart the engineer Gauthier Ralph the director of the Bank of England and Thomas Flanagan the brewer one and all waited anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.
children.prevalue: When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight Andrew Stuart got up saying Gentlemen in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr Fogg and ourselves will have expired

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What time did the last train arrive from Liverpool?  asked Thomas Flanagan.
children.prevalue: What time did the last train arrive from Liverpool asked Thomas Flanagan

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: At twenty-three minutes past seven, replied Gauthier Ralph; and the next does not arrive till ten minutes after twelve.
children.prevalue: At twenty three minutes past seven replied Gauthier Ralph and the next does not arrive till ten minutes after twelve

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Well, gentlemen, resumed Andrew Stuart, if Phileas Fogg had come in the 7:23 train, he would have got here by this time.  We can, therefore, regard the bet as won.
children.prevalue: Well gentlemen resumed Andrew Stuart if Phileas Fogg had come in the 7 23 train he would have got here by this time We can therefore regard the bet as won

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Wait; don't let us be too hasty, replied Samuel Fallentin.  You know that Mr. Fogg is very eccentric.  His punctuality is well known; he never arrives too soon, or too late; and I should not be surprised if he appeared before us at the last minute.
children.prevalue: Wait don t let us be too hasty replied Samuel Fallentin You know that Mr Fogg is very eccentric His punctuality is well known he never arrives too soon or too late and I should not be surprised if he appeared before us at the last minute

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Why, said Andrew Stuart nervously, if I should see him, I should not believe it was he.
children.prevalue: Why said Andrew Stuart nervously if I should see him I should not believe it was he

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The fact is, resumed Thomas Flanagan, Mr. Fogg's project was absurdly foolish.  Whatever his punctuality, he could not prevent the delays which were certain to occur; and a delay of only two or three days would be fatal to his tour.
children.prevalue: The fact is resumed Thomas Flanagan Mr Fogg s project was absurdly foolish Whatever his punctuality he could not prevent the delays which were certain to occur and a delay of only two or three days would be fatal to his tour

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Observe, too, added John Sullivan, that we have received no intelligence from him, though there are telegraphic lines all along his route.
children.prevalue: Observe too added John Sullivan that we have received no intelligence from him though there are telegraphic lines all along his route

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: He has lost, gentleman, said Andrew Stuart, he has a hundred times lost!  You know, besides, that the China the only steamer he could have taken from New York to get here in time arrived yesterday.  I have seen a list of the passengers, and the name of Phileas Fogg is not among them.  Even if we admit that fortune has favoured him, he can scarcely have reached America.  I think he will be at least twenty days behind-hand, and that Lord Albemarle will lose a cool five thousand.
children.prevalue: He has lost gentleman said Andrew Stuart he has a hundred times lost You know besides that the China the only steamer he could have taken from New York to get here in time arrived yesterday I have seen a list of the passengers and the name of Phileas Fogg is not among them Even if we admit that fortune has favoured him he can scarcely have reached America I think he will be at least twenty days behind hand and that Lord Albemarle will lose a cool five thousand

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It is clear, replied Gauthier Ralph; and we have nothing to do but to present Mr. Fogg's cheque at Barings to-morrow.
children.prevalue: It is clear replied Gauthier Ralph and we have nothing to do but to present Mr Fogg s cheque at Barings to morrow

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: At this moment, the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine.
children.prevalue: At this moment the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Five minutes more, said Andrew Stuart.
children.prevalue: Five minutes more said Andrew Stuart

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The five gentlemen looked at each other.  Their anxiety was becoming intense; but, not wishing to betray it, they readily assented to Mr. Fallentin's proposal of a rubber.
children.prevalue: The five gentlemen looked at each other Their anxiety was becoming intense but not wishing to betray it they readily assented to Mr Fallentin s proposal of a rubber

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I wouldn't give up my four thousand of the bet, said Andrew Stuart, as he took his seat, for three thousand nine hundred and ninety-nine.
children.prevalue: I wouldn t give up my four thousand of the bet said Andrew Stuart as he took his seat for three thousand nine hundred and ninety nine

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The clock indicated eighteen minutes to nine.
children.prevalue: The clock indicated eighteen minutes to nine

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The players took up their cards, but could not keep their eyes off the clock.  Certainly, however secure they felt, minutes had never seemed so long to them!
children.prevalue: The players took up their cards but could not keep their eyes off the clock Certainly however secure they felt minutes had never seemed so long to them

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Seventeen minutes to nine, said Thomas Flanagan, as he cut the cards which Ralph handed to him.
children.prevalue: Seventeen minutes to nine said Thomas Flanagan as he cut the cards which Ralph handed to him

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Then there was a moment of silence.  The great saloon was perfectly quiet; but the murmurs of the crowd outside were heard, with now and then a shrill cry.  The pendulum beat the seconds, which each player eagerly counted, as he listened, with mathematical regularity.
children.prevalue: Then there was a moment of silence The great saloon was perfectly quiet but the murmurs of the crowd outside were heard with now and then a shrill cry The pendulum beat the seconds which each player eagerly counted as he listened with mathematical regularity

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Sixteen minutes to nine! said John Sullivan, in a voice which betrayed his emotion.
children.prevalue: Sixteen minutes to nine said John Sullivan in a voice which betrayed his emotion

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: One minute more, and the wager would be won.  Andrew Stuart and his partners suspended their game.  They left their cards, and counted the seconds.
children.prevalue: One minute more and the wager would be won Andrew Stuart and his partners suspended their game They left their cards and counted the seconds

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: At the fortieth second, nothing.  At the fiftieth, still nothing.
children.prevalue: At the fortieth second nothing At the fiftieth still nothing

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: At the fifty-fifth, a loud cry was heard in the street, followed by applause, hurrahs, and some fierce growls.
children.prevalue: At the fifty fifth a loud cry was heard in the street followed by applause hurrahs and some fierce growls

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The players rose from their seats.
children.prevalue: The players rose from their seats

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: At the fifty-seventh second the door of the saloon opened; and the pendulum had not beat the sixtieth second when Phileas Fogg appeared, followed by an excited crowd who had forced their way through the club doors, and in his calm voice, said, Here I am, gentlemen!
children.prevalue: At the fifty seventh second the door of the saloon opened and the pendulum had not beat the sixtieth second when Phileas Fogg appeared followed by an excited crowd who had forced their way through the club doors and in his calm voice said Here I am gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: IN WHICH IT IS SHOWN THAT PHILEAS FOGG GAINED NOTHING BY HIS TOUR AROUND THE WORLD, UNLESS IT WERE HAPPINESS
children.prevalue: IN WHICH IT IS SHOWN THAT PHILEAS FOGG GAINED NOTHING BY HIS TOUR AROUND THE WORLD UNLESS IT WERE HAPPINESS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes; Phileas Fogg in person.
children.prevalue: Yes Phileas Fogg in person

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The reader will remember that at five minutes past eight in the evening--about five and twenty hours after the arrival of the travellers in London--Passepartout had been sent by his master to engage the services of the Reverend Samuel Wilson in a certain marriage ceremony, which was to take place the next day.
children.prevalue: The reader will remember that at five minutes past eight in the evening about five and twenty hours after the arrival of the travellers in London Passepartout had been sent by his master to engage the services of the Reverend Samuel Wilson in a certain marriage ceremony which was to take place the next day

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Passepartout went on his errand enchanted.  He soon reached the clergyman's house, but found him not at home.  Passepartout waited a good twenty minutes, and when he left the reverend gentleman, it was thirty-five minutes past eight.  But in what a state he was!  With his hair in disorder, and without his hat, he ran along the street as never man was seen to run before, overturning passers-by, rushing over the sidewalk like a waterspout.
children.prevalue: Passepartout went on his errand enchanted He soon reached the clergyman s house but found him not at home Passepartout waited a good twenty minutes and when he left the reverend gentleman it was thirty five minutes past eight But in what a state he was With his hair in disorder and without his hat he ran along the street as never man was seen to run before overturning passers by rushing over the sidewalk like a waterspout

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: In three minutes he was in Saville Row again, and staggered back into Mr. Fogg's room.
children.prevalue: In three minutes he was in Saville Row again and staggered back into Mr Fogg s room

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He could not speak.
children.prevalue: He could not speak

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What is the matter? asked Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: What is the matter asked Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: My master! gasped Passepartout--marriage--impossible--
children.prevalue: My master gasped Passepartout marriage impossible

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Impossible?
children.prevalue: Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Impossible--for to-morrow.
children.prevalue: Impossible for to morrow

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Because to-morrow--is Sunday!
children.prevalue: Because to morrow is Sunday

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Monday, replied Mr. Fogg.
children.prevalue: Monday replied Mr Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No--to-day is Saturday.
children.prevalue: No to day is Saturday

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Saturday?  Impossible!
children.prevalue: Saturday Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes, yes, yes, yes! cried Passepartout.  You have made a mistake of one day!  We arrived twenty-four hours ahead of time; but there are only ten minutes left!
children.prevalue: Yes yes yes yes cried Passepartout You have made a mistake of one day We arrived twenty four hours ahead of time but there are only ten minutes left

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Passepartout had seized his master by the collar, and was dragging him along with irresistible force.
children.prevalue: Passepartout had seized his master by the collar and was dragging him along with irresistible force

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Phileas Fogg, thus kidnapped, without having time to think, left his house, jumped into a cab, promised a hundred pounds to the cabman, and, having run over two dogs and overturned five carriages, reached the Reform Club.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg thus kidnapped without having time to think left his house jumped into a cab promised a hundred pounds to the cabman and having run over two dogs and overturned five carriages reached the Reform Club

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The clock indicated a quarter before nine when he appeared in the great saloon.
children.prevalue: The clock indicated a quarter before nine when he appeared in the great saloon

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Phileas Fogg had accomplished the journey round the world in eighty days!
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg had accomplished the journey round the world in eighty days

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Phileas Fogg had won his wager of twenty thousand pounds!
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg had won his wager of twenty thousand pounds

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day?  How came he to think that he had arrived in London on Saturday, the twenty-first day of December, when it was really Friday, the twentieth, the seventy-ninth day only from his departure?
children.prevalue: How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day How came he to think that he had arrived in London on Saturday the twenty first day of December when it was really Friday the twentieth the seventy ninth day only from his departure

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The cause of the error is very simple.
children.prevalue: The cause of the error is very simple

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Phileas Fogg had, without suspecting it, gained one day on his journey, and this merely because he had travelled constantly eastward; he would, on the contrary, have lost a day had he gone in the opposite direction, that is, westward.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg had without suspecting it gained one day on his journey and this merely because he had travelled constantly eastward he would on the contrary have lost a day had he gone in the opposite direction that is westward

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: In journeying eastward he had gone towards the sun, and the days therefore diminished for him as many times four minutes as he crossed degrees in this direction.  There are three hundred and sixty degrees on the circumference of the earth; and these three hundred and sixty degrees, multiplied by four minutes, gives precisely twenty-four hours--that is, the day unconsciously gained.  In other words, while Phileas Fogg, going eastward, saw the sun pass the meridian eighty times, his friends in London only saw it pass the meridian seventy-nine times.  This is why they awaited him at the Reform Club on Saturday, and not Sunday, as Mr. Fogg thought.
children.prevalue: In journeying eastward he had gone towards the sun and the days therefore diminished for him as many times four minutes as he crossed degrees in this direction There are three hundred and sixty degrees on the circumference of the earth and these three hundred and sixty degrees multiplied by four minutes gives precisely twenty four hours that is the day unconsciously gained In other words while Phileas Fogg going eastward saw the sun pass the meridian eighty times his friends in London only saw it pass the meridian seventy nine times This is why they awaited him at the Reform Club on Saturday and not Sunday as Mr Fogg thought

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And Passepartout's famous family watch, which had always kept London time, would have betrayed this fact, if it had marked the days as well as the hours and the minutes!
children.prevalue: And Passepartout s famous family watch which had always kept London time would have betrayed this fact if it had marked the days as well as the hours and the minutes

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Phileas Fogg, then, had won the twenty thousand pounds; but, as he had spent nearly nineteen thousand on the way, the pecuniary gain was small.  His object was, however, to be victorious, and not to win money.  He divided the one thousand pounds that remained between Passepartout and the unfortunate Fix, against whom he cherished no grudge.  He deducted, however, from Passepartout's share the cost of the gas which had burned in his room for nineteen hundred and twenty hours, for the sake of regularity.
children.prevalue: Phileas Fogg then had won the twenty thousand pounds but as he had spent nearly nineteen thousand on the way the pecuniary gain was small His object was however to be victorious and not to win money He divided the one thousand pounds that remained between Passepartout and the unfortunate Fix against whom he cherished no grudge He deducted however from Passepartout s share the cost of the gas which had burned in his room for nineteen hundred and twenty hours for the sake of regularity

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: That evening, Mr. Fogg, as tranquil and phlegmatic as ever, said to Aouda: Is our marriage still agreeable to you?
children.prevalue: That evening Mr Fogg as tranquil and phlegmatic as ever said to Aouda Is our marriage still agreeable to you

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Mr. Fogg, replied she, it is for me to ask that question.  You were ruined, but now you are rich again.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg replied she it is for me to ask that question You were ruined but now you are rich again

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Pardon me, madam; my fortune belongs to you.  If you had not suggested our marriage, my servant would not have gone to the Reverend Samuel Wilson's, I should not have been apprised of my error, and--
children.prevalue: Pardon me madam my fortune belongs to you If you had not suggested our marriage my servant would not have gone to the Reverend Samuel Wilson s I should not have been apprised of my error and

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Dear Mr. Fogg! said the young woman.
children.prevalue: Dear Mr Fogg said the young woman

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Dear Aouda! replied Phileas Fogg.
children.prevalue: Dear Aouda replied Phileas Fogg

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It need not be said that the marriage took place forty-eight hours after, and that Passepartout, glowing and dazzling, gave the bride away.  Had he not saved her, and was he not entitled to this honour?
children.prevalue: It need not be said that the marriage took place forty eight hours after and that Passepartout glowing and dazzling gave the bride away Had he not saved her and was he not entitled to this honour

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The next day, as soon as it was light, Passepartout rapped vigorously at his master's door.  Mr. Fogg opened it, and asked, What's the matter, Passepartout?
children.prevalue: The next day as soon as it was light Passepartout rapped vigorously at his master s door Mr Fogg opened it and asked What s the matter Passepartout

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: What is it, sir?  Why, I've just this instant found out--
children.prevalue: What is it sir Why I ve just this instant found out

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: That we might have made the tour of the world in only seventy-eight days.
children.prevalue: That we might have made the tour of the world in only seventy eight days

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: No doubt, returned Mr. Fogg, by not crossing India.  But if I had not crossed India, I should not have saved Aouda; she would not have been my wife, and--
children.prevalue: No doubt returned Mr Fogg by not crossing India But if I had not crossed India I should not have saved Aouda she would not have been my wife and

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Mr. Fogg quietly shut the door.
children.prevalue: Mr Fogg quietly shut the door

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Phileas Fogg had won his wager, and had made his journey around the world in eighty days.  To do this he had employed every means of conveyance--steamers, railways, carriages, yachts, trading-vessels, sledges, elephants.  The eccentric gentleman had throughout displayed all his marvellous qualities of coolness and exactitude.  But what then?  What had he really gained by all this trouble?  What had he brought back from this long and weary journey?

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Nothing, say you?  Perhaps so; nothing but a charming woman, who, strange as it may appear, made him the happiest of men!
children.prevalue: Nothing say you Perhaps so nothing but a charming woman who strange as it may appear made him the happiest of men

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Truly, would you not for less than that make the tour around the world?
children.prevalue: Truly would you not for less than that make the tour around the world
